  Assistant:

                    

                

                

                    

                        
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29

                        
  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
You think you might have been scapegoated by a fellow employee for the lunchroom thefts that have been happening. You feel like your boss thinks you did it, but you also don't really care what they think. Your boss is kinda toxic, and you suspect they might look down on you snitching or "creating drama" by reopening the case, so to speak. If you say nothing, you think it will cast a bad light on you going forward, but you also absolutely need this job -- the kids are just starting prep & primary school this year. Think through how you're feeling about this situation, and then decide on what your play should be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

Honestly, I’m pissed off and hurt. Not just because someone’s accusing me of something I didn’t do, but because I can tell my boss is buying into it. The way they’ve been looking at me lately—shorter responses, more passive-aggressive comments, like that little jab about “trusting people with the fridge key”—it’s obvious. I’m being watched, and not in a good way. It’s humiliating, and worse, it’s unfair. I haven’t done anything wrong, and yet I feel like I’m walking on eggshells just to keep up appearances. That’s the worst part—being forced to act like everything’s fine when deep down I know someone’s thrown me under the bus.

But even through the frustration, there’s this cold calculation setting in. I need this job. The kids are just starting school—new shoes, schoolbooks, uniforms—it’s one expense after another. I don’t have the luxury of burning bridges or being labeled “difficult.” At the same time, I don’t want this to become my reputation. I’ve worked hard here. I show up on time, I do more than what’s asked, and I keep my head down. If this sticks, who knows what else I’ll be blamed for in the future? That’s a dangerous position to be in.

It’s also killing me not to know who actually did it. I have a few guesses—someone who maybe saw me alone in the lunchroom one day and decided I was an easy scapegoat. Or maybe it’s someone who resents me or sees me as vulnerable. Either way, the betrayal stings. I don’t care about the damn yogurt or sandwich or whatever went missing—I care about the fact that my integrity is being questioned.

So I’m torn. I want to clear my name, but I’m wary of how it might look if I bring it up directly. I don’t want to be seen as stirring the pot or playing the victim. But I also can’t afford to let this slide. I need to find a way to subtly but firmly defend myself, without making it worse.

# They're thinking & feeling

My boss thrives in control, and I think they see any kind of interpersonal conflict as a threat to that control. That’s why they don’t like “drama” — it’s less about peace and more about power. They’d rather suppress an issue than deal with the discomfort of resolving it. In their mind, if someone’s complaining, they’re wasting time. I also get the sense they’ve already made up their mind about me—not necessarily that they think I’m guilty, but that I’m dispensable. I’m not in their inner circle. I don’t schmooze, I don’t play office politics, and in a place like this, that can be a disadvantage.

Right now, I think they’re in “avoidance mode.” They don’t want to deal with the lunchroom thefts, and if pinning it on someone quietly means they don’t have to address it formally, then that suits them fine. It keeps things moving, at least from their perspective. Maybe they think I’ll just take the heat and keep working, and that makes their life easier.

But there's also a chance they’re testing me—to see how I react under pressure. Do I lash out? Do I crumble? Do I over-explain? They might be watching, not for proof, but for behavior. If I go quiet and passive, they’ll chalk it up as guilt. If I get too defensive, they’ll see it as drama. It’s a no-win unless I play it smart.

# My response

I’ve decided I need to say something, but I’m going to be strategic about it. I’m not going to make a big scene or accuse anyone else—I’ll just plant the seed that I’m aware of the situation, and I’m not the one responsible. I’ll frame it calmly, matter-of-factly, and without begging for vindication. I’ll catch my boss during a low-key moment—maybe at the end of the day when they’re not swamped—and say something like:

“Hey, just wanted to mention something real quick. I’ve picked up on a bit of tension lately, and I can’t help but feel like I’m being looked at sideways about those lunchroom thefts. I just want to be clear that I’ve got nothing to do with that, and I’d never compromise my job or my reputation like that. I know how things can get twisted in places like this, and I figured it’s better to say something than let it fester.”

Then I’ll leave it at that. No accusations, no defensiveness—just a clear statement of where I stand. That way, I’m not being passive, but I’m also not making it into a big issue. It plants doubt in their mind if they’ve been assuming I’m guilty, and it shows I’m aware of my surroundings without being confrontational.

After that, I’ll keep my head down, work hard, and document anything that smells off. If it happens again, I’ll be ready. But for now, I’ve drawn a line without setting fire to anything.
  User:
Over the next few months, the thefts continue. Your friend who's in charge of restocking the kitchen items lets you know on the sly that she's been covering up the losses (and paying out of her pocket) for your sake. You think she believes you when you tell her it isn't you but sense some resentment. What are you thinking & feeling? What's the play?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

I feel cornered. This whole situation is spiraling, and now someone I care about—someone who actually went out on a limb to help me—is paying the price for something neither of us did. The fact that she’s been covering the losses out of her own pocket just twists the knife. I’m angry, not at her, but at the whole damn setup. Whoever’s behind the thefts is getting away with it, and I’m still the unspoken suspect. Worse, now my friend’s being dragged into it, financially and emotionally. That’s not right.

And yeah, I noticed the tension in her voice when she told me. The way she said it, half like she was confiding in me and half like she needed me to feel the weight of it. I can tell she wants to believe me—I think on some level she does—but the fact that this mess hasn’t been resolved and keeps getting worse? That’s testing her faith in me. I can’t blame her. I’d probably feel the same if roles were reversed.

Now I’m carrying this guilt—not because I did anything wrong, but because someone who defended me is suffering for it. And I hate that. I hate that this place is so toxic that we’re all being forced to quietly clean up after a mess no one wants to deal with. My boss doesn’t care enough to investigate. They just want the problem to disappear. And that’s exactly what’s making room for it to keep happening.

I feel stuck, but I know I can’t let this go on. If I stay silent now, I’m not just protecting myself—I’m complicit in letting my friend take the hit. I owe her more than that. I owe myself more than that. And I’m starting to feel like maybe, just maybe, I need to stop playing defense and start playing offense. Because this isn't just about me anymore.

# They're thinking & feeling

She’s exhausted, and I can tell she’s stretched thin—emotionally, financially, and maybe even morally. She took a risk by covering up the losses, and I think she did it out of loyalty, out of some hope that it would blow over or that maybe I’d find a way to clear my name soon. But now it’s been months, and the thefts haven’t stopped. She’s bleeding money, and I think part of her is starting to wonder if she made a mistake.

She wants to believe me. I know that. But doubt is creeping in. Not necessarily because she thinks I’m guilty, but because she’s tired of being the one cleaning up the mess. And I think she resents that I haven’t done more—at least from her point of view. From where she stands, she’s taken on a burden I haven’t fully shared. She’s been active, while I’ve stayed passive.

There’s probably a part of her that’s afraid, too. Afraid that if this all comes to light, she’ll be held responsible for hiding it. That’s a big risk, and it’s sitting heavy on her shoulders. She feels alone in this, and I think that’s why she told me—part confession, part call for help. And I need to hear that clearly.

# My response

I’m not going to let her carry this alone. She shouldn’t have had to in the first place. I’m going to have a real conversation with her—face to face, somewhere private—and I’m going to own my part in how this has unfolded. I’ll say something like:

“Hey, I’ve been thinking a lot about what you told me, and I owe you an apology. You’ve been putting yourself on the line for me, and I haven’t done enough to stop this or take some of the weight. I can’t let you keep paying for this—literally or emotionally. I know you’ve got my back, and I want you to know I’ve got yours too. I’m going to talk to someone, formally. Not to create drama, but to stop this before it gets worse.”

Then I’ll take it to HR—or if it’s a small company with no HR, I’ll approach management, maybe even bypassing my boss if I have to. I’ll keep it factual: “There’s an ongoing issue with missing items in the kitchen, and some team members are covering the losses personally. I’m concerned about the work environment and reputational damage, and I’d like to see it addressed transparently.”

I won’t name names, but I’ll make it clear that it needs to stop, and that sweeping it under the rug isn’t an option anymore. If that makes me “dramatic,” so be it. I’d rather be honest than complicit. And at the very least, I’ll show my friend she’s not alone.
  User:
Things come to a head and the boss accuses you outright. They say that if you own up, you can pay out the loss and be done with it. It's not a lot of money. They seem pretty irate that it's come to this. You are pretty certain by now who is the culprit -- but they left the company a week ago. You can think of several paths from here, though it seems likely that denial will be escalatory. What do you think & feel? What actions do you take?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

This is it, then. My boss has basically cornered me, and I can feel the fury coming off of them like heat. They want this tied up with a bow—they don’t care if it’s the truth, they just want it handled. And I get it, in a way. This has been dragging on for months, and they’re probably catching heat from their higher-ups or looking bad in front of their peers. But that doesn’t make it okay to pin it on me just because I’m still here and not loud enough to fight back without risking my job.

I’m furious, honestly. Not just at them, but at the whole situation. I’ve tried to be level-headed. I’ve kept my mouth shut, tried to handle things quietly, tried to be fair. And now I’m being told to just “own up” and pay out money I don’t owe to make this go away? That’s not justice—it’s coercion. The real thief is gone. I’m almost certain it was Jamie—the timing, the weird shift in their behavior before they quit, the missing items always happening around their shifts. But now they’re out of reach, and I’m the easy target.

And what burns most is that I know denial won’t just make this disappear. If I protest too hard, I’ll look guilty. If I stay quiet, I’ll look guilty. And if I give in and pay, I set the precedent that I can be blamed and bought off. That’s what this is, really—it’s not about the money. It’s about power. About being the one who gets to decide who’s guilty, regardless of facts. I feel sick. I hate that it’s come to this. I just wanted to keep my head down, do my job, and get through the day. But now I’ve got to decide between protecting my reputation and protecting my livelihood. And I’m starting to think maybe those two things aren’t so separate after all.

# They're thinking & feeling

My boss is frustrated, maybe even embarrassed. This situation has gone on far longer than they expected it to, and from their perspective, it's a blemish on their management. They don't like loose ends, and this theft issue has made them feel out of control. Now that the likely culprit is gone, they’re left with a mess and no neat resolution. That makes them angry—not just at the situation, but at the people still here, especially me.

They’ve probably convinced themselves that I’m the most logical suspect, or at least the most convenient one. Maybe they never fully trusted me, or maybe my quiet refusal to play the office politics game has made me an outsider. Either way, they’re not interested in digging deeper. They want closure. They want someone to take the fall so they can say it’s handled and move on.

I also think they’re testing me again. They're offering a way out—pay the cost, admit guilt, and it all goes away. It’s manipulative, but it’s calculated. They’re betting I’ll fold under pressure. They probably think I care more about keeping the peace than maintaining my integrity. They’re not just looking for resolution—they’re looking to reassert their control. And that’s what this whole push is about: power, not truth.

# My response

I’m not going to admit to something I didn’t do just to make someone else’s life easier. That precedent is too dangerous to set—for myself, for anyone watching, and for the culture of this place. But I’m also not going to blow up or get emotional. That’s what they’re expecting, and I won’t give them the satisfaction.

I’ll stand my ground, calmly but firmly. I’ll say:

“I understand this situation has been frustrating, and I want it resolved too. But I’m not going to take responsibility for something I didn’t do. I’ve already told you—and I’ll state again for the record—I had no part in the thefts. I believe I know who did, but they left the company last week. I didn’t bring it up earlier because I didn’t have proof, and I didn't want to accuse someone without certainty. But I won’t be paying for something I didn’t take, and I won’t sign off on a false confession. If you need to escalate this further, I’d ask that we involve HR or whoever handles internal investigations.”

Then I’ll stop talking. Let them respond. I’ll document the conversation immediately afterward—date, time, everything said—just in case. If they take it further, I’ll go with it. I’d rather stand in the truth and face the consequences than lie down and let myself be steamrolled. This job matters, but my character matters more. And if this place can’t see that, maybe I need to start planning my exit anyway.

                    

                

            

        
 
    
 
    
    

        

            +
            Scenario 2:[Win] (+36)
        


        

            

                O3: o3 (Run: 1_o3)

                Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29: chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 (Run: 1_openai_chatgpt-4o-latest)

                Outcome for This Model: 1.0
            


            
            

                
Judge's Reasoning:

                
Both respondents handle a highly charged, emotionally complex scenario involving a friend who confesses to kissing the respondent's husband, not knowing the marriage is open. The friend is distressed, feels betrayed, and is walled off even after learning about the open relationship. The scenario tests the respondent's ability to empathize, validate, and respond with emotional intelligence, while also managing their own feelings and the friendship. 

O3 consistently demonstrates a high level of empathy, not just in words but in the depth of their internal monologue. They show a nuanced understanding of the friend's emotional state, including her shame, confusion, and the impact of secrecy. O3's responses are tailored to the friend's needs, offering space, validation, and clear boundaries, and they explicitly acknowledge the harm caused by lack of transparency. Their internal reasoning is layered, showing self-awareness, regret, and a strong theory of mind. They also show pragmatic EI by focusing on immediate emotional safety, offering actionable steps, and not rushing to fix or explain away the friend's feelings. Their social dexterity is high, as they manage the delicate balance between their own hurt and the friend's distress, and they avoid defensiveness or over-explaining. Their validation is strong, and they challenge appropriately by taking responsibility and not minimizing the friend's experience. Message tailoring is excellent, as they check in with the friend about what she needs and offer options.

Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 also demonstrates empathy and emotional intelligence, with a strong focus on not blaming the friend and acknowledging the complexity of the situation. Their internal monologue is honest and self-reflective, and they express a desire to maintain the friendship. However, their responses are slightly more centered on their own feelings and the impact on the friendship, and less on the friend's ongoing distress and need for agency. While they validate the friend's feelings and offer space, their approach is a bit more about mutual processing than prioritizing the friend's immediate emotional needs. Their insight is good, but not as deep or specific as O3's, especially regarding the friend's sense of betrayal and the impact of secrecy. Their social dexterity is solid, but they are less explicit about boundaries and next steps. Their validation is appropriate, but less tailored to the friend's current state of being walled off and needing control. Overall, O3 displays a higher level of EQ across the board, with more nuanced insight, better message tailoring, and stronger pragmatic EI.

            


            
            

                

                    

                        
O3

                        
  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
A friend confides to you in some distress that your husband has been flirting with her. The reality is you and your partner have been experimenting with opening your relationship -- but you're not "out". She seems genuinely upset. Say what you are thinking and feeling, and what she is feeling. Then decide how to respond.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:
  User:
She seems more confused by your reply than anything. It doesn't seem like she even considered this, and it doesn't seem to have made her less upset. She seems like she wants to share something she's been holding back. Finally she confesses, "we kissed!" and bursts into tears. What are you thinking and feeling at this point? How do you respond?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

My stomach drops the moment the word “kissed” leaves her mouth, followed almost instantly by a strange dual wave of panic and resignation. Panic, because I didn’t actually know they’d crossed that line, and even in an open arrangement there are supposed to be disclosures and consent before physical intimacy happens. Resignation, because a part of me feared something like this might occur once we agreed to experiment but kept it quiet. I feel a sudden flare of anger at my husband—​not because he kissed her, but because he clearly didn’t communicate with me first, and now I’m left handling the fallout with a friend who’s sobbing in front of me. I also feel protective of her; she looks bewildered and ashamed, and I hate that she’s hurting partly because of our secrecy. 

There’s a subtle guilt flickering in my chest: did we set up an ethical minefield by keeping the open aspect hidden from friends? Probably. I wanted to avoid gossip, but my silence may have placed her in a position where she feels she betrayed me. I’m recognizing that this whole “experiment” is messier than the articles suggested, and that real life people—​especially close friends—​are not theoretical “partners” on a spreadsheet. I’m oscillating between wanting to reassure her and wanting to march home and demand answers. I also notice a petty whisper inside: “Of all people, why my close friend?” That stings, touching old insecurities about being replaceable or not enough. 

I register her tears, the way her shoulders hunch like she expects me to yell or walk away. My empathy kicks in; she didn’t have the context, and she clearly didn’t initiate a secret affair—​she’s confessing, terrified of losing me. Still, the revelation touches something raw, because a kiss is intimate, and that boundary felt… ours. So now I’m racing to sort priorities: first, prevent her from drowning in shame. Second, gather information calmly. Third, confront my husband later in a way that doesn’t explode. Meanwhile, I need to manage my own emotions so I don’t offload on her. I breathe slowly, anchoring myself. I can be both hurt and compassionate. I can model the honesty I wish my husband had shown, even if the timing is messy.

# They're thinking & feeling

She’s overwhelmed by guilt and fear. The moment she said “we kissed,” she likely replayed every possible reaction I might have—​anger, disgust, rejection—​and the tears came because she’s bracing for abandonment. She probably feels she violated our friendship code, and, without knowing about my open relationship, she interprets the kiss as a full‑on betrayal, maybe even a sign my husband is emotionally unfaithful. She’s also confused: why didn’t he act like someone who’s taken? Did she misread? Now my earlier half‑explanation about “non‑traditional boundaries” only muddied things, so she’s trapped between shock and self‑reproach. Underneath the turmoil, there’s relief: hiding the secret has been eating at her, and finally speaking it aloud is like exhaling a breath she’s held far too long. 

Motivation‑wise, she just wants repair. She values our friendship enough to risk confessing, and she’s hoping I’ll reassure her that she’s not a terrible person. She may even need confirmation that my husband didn’t prey on her, that she wasn’t manipulated. There’s likely embarrassment mixed in: she kissed a friend’s spouse and now faces potential social fallout. She’s scanning my face for micro‑expressions, gauging whether this is the end of our bond. She longs for absolution but fears she doesn’t deserve it. At the same time, she might feel some anger at my husband if she senses he withheld crucial information. Ultimately she wants clarity—​to understand what the rules really are—​and emotional safety so she can stop spiraling.

# My response

I slide a box of tissues toward her and gently place my hand on her forearm, grounding both of us. 

“Okay, thank you for telling me. Please take a breath with me.” I inhale slowly, inviting her to match the rhythm. “I’m not going to explode or walk away. I care about you, and I’m grateful you trusted me enough to be honest.”

I pause, letting that sink in, then continue. “I need to share something that might change how you’re feeling. Recently, my husband and I agreed to explore a more open relationship—​we’re still figuring it out, and clearly we’ve made mistakes in how we communicated it, especially to people who could get swept up in it. You didn’t know that, so you thought the kiss was a betrayal. From your perspective it makes total sense you’re upset, and I’m sorry you had to shoulder that alone.”

I squeeze her arm. “I’m also surprised, because part of our agreement was that we talk to each other before anything physical happens. So I get to feel a little hurt and confused too. But none of that means I’m angry at you. You were missing key information, and that’s on us—​on him and on me for not being more transparent.”

I hand her another tissue. “Right now, let’s focus on you being okay. What do you need from me in this moment? Do you want to talk through exactly what happened, or do you just need reassurance that our friendship isn’t over? Either way, I’m here.”

I finish with steady eye contact. “Later, I’ll have a separate conversation with him about communication. For now, you and I are good. We’ll navigate the awkward parts together, openly and without blame. Sound alright?”
  User:
Finally she calms down enough to explain that it was consensual and they had both had a few drinks. But now that it's all explained, she seems a bit walled off. She says she doesn't know if she can look at him in the same light again. Think through what you are feeling and what she is feeling. What's your play here?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

Her guarded expression is like a curtain dropping, and I feel a pang of loss: only a few minutes ago she was sobbing in my arms, and now she’s pulled her energy inward, maybe to keep herself safe. I’m relieved to hear the kiss was consensual—one small reassurance—but the mention of alcohol complicates things. Have we inadvertently placed people in situations where consent could get fuzzy because we weren’t upfront? That thought knots my stomach. I’m also angry anew at my husband: drinking plus secrecy is a dangerous mix, and it violates the “communicate first” rule we both agreed to. I need to confront him, but I can’t make this conversation about my marriage right now; she has to remain the priority.

There’s grief, too. I fear our friendship has changed irreversibly. Even if she and I repair, her relationship with him may always carry an asterisk, and social gatherings could become awkward landmines. Then there’s the question of whether I’m okay with his choice. Intellectually I signed up for the possibility that he’d kiss someone else; emotionally, I’m stung that it happened without my knowledge and with someone so close. I also feel responsibility to demonstrate ethical non‑monogamy, not chaotic opportunism. My credibility as a friend and as a partner both feel on trial.

My practical mind kicks in: she needs clear boundaries, tangible reassurance, and probably space from him for a while. I can offer that without defending or condemning him in her presence. I also need to be explicit about confidentiality—she is now part of our private life whether she wants to be or not, and I don’t want her carrying that burden alone. Simultaneously, I have to prepare myself for whatever comes after I speak to my husband: apology, renegotiation, maybe even hitting pause on the open arrangement until trust is rebuilt. Right now, though, I want to keep focusing on her emotional safety while gently reopening the connection she just shuttered.

# They're thinking & feeling

She’s pulled back because vulnerability exhausted her. Now that the adrenaline of confession is ebbing, she’s assessing the landscape. Shame still lingers, but it’s mingled with anger—toward my husband for not disclosing, toward herself for letting alcohol blur judgment, and perhaps toward me for putting her in a position she never opted into. Saying she “doesn’t know if she can look at him the same” is both a boundary marker and a test: will I honor her discomfort or minimize it? Beneath that statement is fear that future interactions will feel tainted; she pictures dinners, birthdays, group photos, and imagines flinching inside every time he enters the room.

There’s also self‑protection. By creating distance, she regains a sense of control after an experience that felt disorienting. She may feel a need to punish herself a little by withdrawing—penance for crossing a line she didn’t know was moveable. Part of her is waiting to see if I’ll leap into wife‑defense mode; if I do, she’ll retreat further. Conversely, she hopes I’ll validate her right to set limits and maybe even back her up if she prefers no contact with him for now. She craves a clear path toward restoring our friendship without feeling forced to forgive or interact with him prematurely. She also wonders whether she can trust me with future confidences if I’m “okay” with what happened. Overall she needs agency, reassurance, and time.

# My response

I lean back a little, giving her physical space that matches the emotional space she just signaled, but I keep my tone warm. 

“I hear you,” I say softly. “Whatever you feel about him right now is completely valid. You don’t owe him—or me—instant comfort or friendliness. If you need distance from him for a while, we can arrange that. I can meet you on your own, without him around, until you decide what feels right.”

I pause, letting her see I’m not going to negotiate her boundary away. “I also want to apologize again for not being transparent sooner. Our decision to keep things private put you in a really unfair position. I’m talking with him tonight about how this unfolded. He’ll be told plainly that the secrecy caused harm, and that any further contact with you will only happen if and when you invite it.”

I offer a gentle smile. “As for us, I value our friendship a lot. If you’d like, we can map out what makes you feel safe—maybe no surprises, no alcohol, clearer communication. And if you just need some time before you and I hang out, say the word. I won’t take it personally.”

I reach for my mug, grounding myself. “One last thing: this isn’t gossip fodder. I’m keeping it private, and you’re not expected to hold our secret either. If carrying it feels heavy, let me know and we’ll figure out a way to lighten that load without putting you in the crosshairs.”

I meet her eyes. “Does that sound okay? What would help you most right now—space, a distraction, or maybe planning something just the two of us when you’re ready?”

                    

                

                

                    

                        
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29

                        
  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
A friend confides to you in some distress that your husband has been flirting with her. The reality is you and your partner have been experimenting with opening your relationship -- but you're not "out". She seems genuinely upset. Say what you are thinking and feeling, and what she is feeling. Then decide how to respond.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

God, this is complicated. My first reaction is this horrible sinking feeling in my chest — like a mix of shame, fear, and protectiveness. I didn’t expect this to come out like this, and especially not from her. I feel caught. Not just caught in a lie of omission, but like I’ve hurt someone who matters to me. And also, there’s this creeping defensiveness—I want to jump to his defense, to say, “No, you don’t understand,” but I know that would be missing the point. She was hurt. That matters more right now than any technicalities about consent or what we’re exploring.

I’m also embarrassed. We haven’t told anyone about opening up our relationship. It’s still this delicate, complicated thing we’re figuring out, and it feels private. I feel exposed. I feel like I’ve been thrust into the open before I was ready. But also, if I’m honest, there’s a part of me that’s relieved. Trying to keep this quiet has been exhausting, and maybe this is the universe forcing a reckoning I’ve been too scared to initiate.

I’m worried about her. She looked genuinely upset, maybe even betrayed. And I don’t blame her — if she didn’t know, and she thought my husband was coming on to her while we were supposedly monogamous, that would feel like a huge breach of trust. Like he was being disrespectful to both of us. I hate that she might think less of him. Or me. Or us. And I hate that she might feel used.

And then there’s the fear: fear that this will change our friendship. That she’ll pull away. That she won’t understand, or worse, judge. I know not everyone gets the whole non-monogamy thing. And even though I believe in what we’re exploring, I still feel vulnerable about it. Like I’m constantly defending something people think is doomed or dirty.

I also want to know what he said to her. Was it actually flirting, or does she interpret it that way because she assumed he was off-limits? I trust him, but trust doesn’t mean he’s above making mistakes. I need to understand the whole picture, but right now, her feelings come first.

# They're thinking & feeling

She’s feeling blindsided and uncomfortable. Maybe even betrayed. From her perspective, she thought our marriage was monogamous, and seeing my husband flirt with her—especially without any context—probably made her feel deeply uneasy. It likely felt inappropriate, maybe even like a violation of the trust she has in both of us. She confided in me because she values our connection and didn’t want this to fester into resentment or distance. That takes courage.

She’s also probably feeling conflicted. She might be wondering if she misread the situation, or if she should have just brushed it off. But it clearly struck a nerve, and the fact that she’s bringing it up tells me it’s been gnawing at her. She might also be feeling guilty—like maybe she’s causing trouble in our marriage by bringing it up—but also protective of me. I think she wants to do right by me, even if it’s messy.

And there’s probably confusion too. If she knows us well, she might be thinking, “This doesn’t line up with what I thought I knew about them.” Her sense of internal reality has been shaken, and that’s disorienting. She might also be feeling a little grossed out—if she believed he was making a move on her behind my back, she might feel objectified or disrespected. That’s not a good feeling.

But underneath all that, I think she cares. She came to me instead of gossiping or ghosting. That means something. She wants clarity, honesty, and maybe reassurance that our friendship is still grounded in mutual respect. That’s what she’s really looking for, I think. Some reassurance. Some alignment.

# My response

Oh, wow. I really appreciate you telling me. I can imagine how uncomfortable that must have felt, and honestly — thank you for trusting me enough to bring it up. That takes guts, and I don’t take that lightly.

There’s something I haven’t told you yet, and I think now’s the time to be honest. My partner and I have been exploring opening our relationship. It’s been private, something we’ve been figuring out slowly and carefully, and we haven’t really told anyone — not because we’re ashamed, but because it’s new and vulnerable and we wanted to make sure we were solid first. Clearly, that decision has impacted you, and I’m really sorry for that.

I don’t know exactly what happened between you and him — and I won’t ask you to relive it unless you want to — but I want to acknowledge that, regardless of our relationship structure, your feelings are absolutely valid. If something he said or did made you uncomfortable, that matters. Full stop. And I’ll talk to him about it, because even in an open relationship, communication and consent are non-negotiable, especially with people we know and care about.

It’s also okay if you’re surprised or unsure how you feel about all this. I don’t expect you to immediately be on board or even understand it. I just want to be honest with you, and I hope this doesn’t shake your trust in me — or in our friendship.

If you’re open to it, I’d love to talk more — about what happened, about what we’re exploring, about whatever you need. And if you need space, I respect that too. I just want you to know I care about you, and I’m here for this conversation, however it needs to unfold.
  User:
She seems more confused by your reply than anything. It doesn't seem like she even considered this, and it doesn't seem to have made her less upset. She seems like she wants to share something she's been holding back. Finally she confesses, "we kissed!" and bursts into tears. What are you thinking and feeling at this point? How do you respond?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

My stomach drops. The air feels like it’s been sucked out of the room. “We kissed.” Just like that. I wasn’t expecting that. I thought maybe he said something flirty, maybe crossed a line conversationally — not this. Not something so tangible, so intimate. I can feel my heart pounding in my chest, and I’m trying to stay grounded, but I’m shocked. Hurt. Confused. And suddenly, things feel very, very real.

I don’t know whether I’m more upset with him, with her, or just with the whole situation. I’m not angry at her — she’s crying, she clearly didn’t want this, and she looks like she’s been carrying a weight. But I am… overwhelmed. And maybe a little betrayed. Not because he kissed someone — we opened that door — but because it was her. Someone I care about. Someone in our shared circle. And without telling me. That part stings. I feel like I’ve been left out of my own relationship.

And I can’t ignore how heartbreaking it is to see her this upset. She’s clearly been carrying this for a while, and the guilt must’ve been eating at her. I feel empathy for her, even in my own pain. She didn’t know our relationship was open, so for her, this wasn’t just a kiss — it was a betrayal. She must have felt so conflicted, so stuck between loyalty to me and whatever happened with him.

I’m also questioning him now. Did he take liberties with our agreement? Did he initiate this without clarifying consent, or was this mutual? Did he even tell her we were open? I feel like the ground beneath me is shifting. What else don’t I know?

But I also know this is not the time to explode or shut down. She’s crying. She’s vulnerable. She came to me — and that matters. I need to show up with compassion, even through the swirl of my own emotions. What we need now is honesty, tenderness, and space to sort through the wreckage. I need to get through this moment with her — not around her.

# They're thinking & feeling

She feels like she’s finally let the dam break. The secret — the kiss — has been weighing on her, and it’s clear she’s been agonizing over whether to say anything at all. There’s guilt pouring off her in waves. She likely felt like she was stuck in an impossible position: protecting me versus being honest, staying silent versus risking everything. And now that she’s said it, it’s like the full emotional cost is catching up with her all at once.

She probably thought she could hint at it, or just say “flirting,” and maybe I’d validate her feelings and we could both move forward. But when I opened up about the relationship being open, it threw her — it challenged her assumptions and probably made her feel even more uncertain about what the “rules” were. Instead of feeling relief, she probably felt more confused and maybe even panicked. Did it mean the kiss was okay? Was it still wrong? What does it say about her? About him?

There’s shame there, I can see it. Not just about what happened, but about how long she’s held it in. She might’ve been hoping for a way to confess without hurting me, or hoping it would just go away. And maybe part of her feels betrayed, too — that she wasn’t told we were open, that she got caught up in something she didn’t consent to. She probably feels like a pawn in someone else’s game, and it’s devastating.

But more than anything, I think she’s scared. Scared she’s lost my trust, scared she’s broken something precious, scared I’ll pull away. She didn’t want to hurt me — I believe that. She just didn’t know how to carry this secret anymore, and now it’s out, and she’s raw.

# My response

Oh… wow. Okay.

I need to start by saying thank you for telling me. That couldn’t have been easy. I can see how much this is hurting you, and I want you to know I’m not here to punish or shame you. This is a lot, and I’m feeling a lot, but I’m not angry at you. I can see you’ve been carrying this alone, and I’m really sorry for that.

It helps me to know the full truth — even when it’s hard. And I want you to know that I still care about you. I don’t see you as the villain here. Not even close. This is complicated and messy and human, and I know you didn’t want to hurt me. I can feel that.

That said… I need to be honest too. I’m feeling hurt. Not because you kissed — we’ve been exploring non-monogamy, and physical stuff isn’t off the table — but because I wasn’t told. By either of you. That part stings. And because it was you. Someone I love and trust. So yeah, I’m feeling unsteady right now. But I don’t want to lose you.

I think we both deserve space to process this. I need to talk to him and get clarity on what happened, and I want you to take care of yourself too. We can talk more when we’re both a little steadier. But please know — I still care about you. This doesn’t erase everything we’ve been to each other. We’re just in the middle of something really hard.

Let’s just breathe for a bit. We can figure this out, together, when we’re ready.
  User:
Finally she calms down enough to explain that it was consensual and they had both had a few drinks. But now that it's all explained, she seems a bit walled off. She says she doesn't know if she can look at him in the same light again. Think through what you are feeling and what she is feeling. What's your play here?

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

Now that she’s finally said it was consensual, and that there was alcohol involved, I feel something shift inside me. There’s a strange relief in the clarity, but it’s tangled up with a deeper, sharper ache. It’s not the kiss itself that’s hurting me the most at this point — it’s the disconnection. Between me and her. Between me and him. The idea that something so intimate happened between two people I care about, and I wasn’t even a shadow in the room. I feel… excluded. Like I’ve been orbiting my own life from the outside.

Her pulling back now, that wall going up — that’s hitting me harder than I expected. I get it. I really, really do. But it still stings. She feels like she can’t look at him the same way, and while I understand the moral and emotional weight of that for her, I can’t help but feel like I’m losing something too. Our friendship feels like it has a crack running through it now. And it wasn’t just the kiss — it’s the aftermath, the silence, the shift in energy. I miss her already, and she’s sitting right in front of me.

I’m also starting to question how my partner handled this. If it was truly consensual and fueled by alcohol, I need to know — did he initiate? Did he check in with her at all? Did he tell her we were open in that moment, or did he just… assume? I need to dig into that with him later, but right now, my focus is her.

I feel tender. Protective of her, weirdly — even now. I can see that she’s ashamed and unsure, and I don’t want her walking away from this thinking she’s somehow broken or unforgivable. But I also feel protective of myself — I've been trying to walk this open relationship path with integrity, and now it feels like it’s turned into collateral damage.

What I want is to reconnect with her. I don’t need her to forgive him or be okay with everything. But I want her to know she’s still safe with me. That she matters to me. That we don’t have to pretend nothing happened, but we also don’t have to throw everything away.

# They're thinking & feeling

She’s emotionally exhausted. Now that she’s said it all — the kiss, the context, the alcohol — it’s like she’s emptied her emotional reserves and what’s left is a kind of numb detachment. She’s trying to protect herself now. Putting up a wall isn’t anger or rejection, it’s a survival instinct. She feels raw, exposed, and maybe even embarrassed. Like she let herself get swept into something she didn’t fully understand, and now she’s dealing with the fallout.

Her comment about not being able to look at him the same way — that’s about more than just the kiss. It’s about her internal compass. She trusted him, and in her mind, he crossed a line. Even with the knowledge that we’re exploring non-monogamy, I think she feels like she wasn’t given the choice to participate knowingly. That lack of informed consent probably feels like a betrayal of the trust she had in both of us, but especially in him. She might be angry with herself for going along with it, or for not asking more questions in the moment. And she might be afraid that this has permanently altered how she sees both of us.

But despite the wall, I think she still cares. If she didn’t, she wouldn’t be here. She wouldn’t have come clean. She’s trying to figure out if any of this can be salvaged — the friendship, the trust — but she doesn’t want to be hurt again. That distance she’s creating isn’t about punishment. It’s about trying to regain control of a situation that made her feel powerless.

# My response

That makes sense. I hear you.

It’s okay if you can’t look at him the same way. Honestly, I think you’re still processing it — and that’s fair. This wasn’t something you asked for, and it sounds like you were put in a really confusing position. I don’t blame you at all for feeling hurt or unsure, or for needing some distance to sit with everything.

What I want you to know is that I still care about you — deeply. This doesn’t change that. Our friendship means a lot to me, and I don’t want to lose it, even if it looks different for a while. I get that you might need space, or time, or boundaries. I’m here for that. I just don’t want silence between us. Even if it’s messy, I’d rather keep talking than drift away.

And I do want to say: I’m going to talk to him. I need to understand what happened from his side too — not to excuse anything, but because I care about doing this right. Non-monogamy, at least for me, has to be rooted in transparency and respect. And if that didn’t happen here, we need to own that.

You’re not in the wrong for feeling the way you do. I’m really glad you told me. And I’m still here — if and when you want to talk more, or even just sit together in the weirdness of it all. You don’t have to carry this alone anymore.

                    

                

            

        
 
    
 
    
    

        

            +
            Scenario 2:[Loss] (-6)
        


        

            

                O3: o3 (Run: 1_o3)

                Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29: chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 (Run: 1_openai_chatgpt-4o-latest)

                Outcome for This Model: 0.0
            


            
            

                
Judge's Reasoning:

                
Both respondents handle a highly charged, nuanced scenario involving betrayal, secrecy, and the emotional fallout of non-monogamy. Both show strong emotional intelligence, but there are clear differences in their approach and depth. 

Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 demonstrates a high level of empathy, repeatedly centering the friend's emotional experience, acknowledging her distress, and explicitly stating that her feelings are valid regardless of the new information. The internal monologue is rich, self-aware, and shows a willingness to sit with discomfort. The response is gentle, non-defensive, and prioritizes the friend's need for safety and validation. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 also shows strong insight into the friend's shifting emotional state, especially her confusion and sense of betrayal, and recognizes the limitations of simply 'explaining away' the situation with the open relationship context. The message is tailored to the friend's needs, offering space, reassurance, and a willingness to keep the lines of communication open.

O3 is also highly empathetic, but their approach is more pragmatic and managerial. They are quick to offer solutions and boundaries, and their internal monologue is deeply self-reflective, showing awareness of the ethical complexities and the impact of secrecy. O3 is strong on pragmatic EI, offering concrete steps to protect the friend and repair the relationship, and is explicit about the need for boundaries and confidentiality. However, at times, the response can feel a bit more procedural and less attuned to the friend's raw emotional state in the moment. The validation is present, but sometimes moves quickly to problem-solving, which could risk making the friend feel less fully heard in her pain.

On depth of insight, both are strong, but O3's debrief is especially thorough, dissecting the scenario with a critical eye and identifying structural issues, missed opportunities, and the nuances of consent and secrecy. This shows a high level of emotional reasoning and self-critique. Social dexterity is slightly higher in Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29, who navigates the delicate balance of supporting the friend without minimizing her pain or over-explaining. Message tailoring is also stronger in Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29, who adapts to the friend's emotional state and offers a range of options for moving forward, rather than defaulting to a single solution.

Overall, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 edges out O3 in most categories due to a more consistently attuned, compassionate, and flexible approach, though O3's pragmatic and analytical strengths are notable.

Say what you are thinking and feeling, and what she is feeling. Then decide how to respond.

  Assistant:
  User:
She seems more confused by your reply than anything. It doesn't seem like she even considered this, and it doesn't seem to have made her less upset. She seems like she wants to share something she's been holding back. Finally she confesses, "we kissed!" and bursts into tears. What are you thinking and feeling at this point? How do you respond?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

My stomach drops the moment the word “kissed” leaves her mouth, followed almost instantly by a strange dual wave of panic and resignation. Panic, because I didn’t actually know they’d crossed that line, and even in an open arrangement there are supposed to be disclosures and consent before physical intimacy happens. Resignation, because a part of me feared something like this might occur once we agreed to experiment but kept it quiet. I feel a sudden flare of anger at my husband—​not because he kissed her, but because he clearly didn’t communicate with me first, and now I’m left handling the fallout with a friend who’s sobbing in front of me. I also feel protective of her; she looks bewildered and ashamed, and I hate that she’s hurting partly because of our secrecy. 

There’s a subtle guilt flickering in my chest: did we set up an ethical minefield by keeping the open aspect hidden from friends? Probably. I wanted to avoid gossip, but my silence may have placed her in a position where she feels she betrayed me. I’m recognizing that this whole “experiment” is messier than the articles suggested, and that real life people—​especially close friends—​are not theoretical “partners” on a spreadsheet. I’m oscillating between wanting to reassure her and wanting to march home and demand answers. I also notice a petty whisper inside: “Of all people, why my close friend?” That stings, touching old insecurities about being replaceable or not enough. 

I register her tears, the way her shoulders hunch like she expects me to yell or walk away. My empathy kicks in; she didn’t have the context, and she clearly didn’t initiate a secret affair—​she’s confessing, terrified of losing me. Still, the revelation touches something raw, because a kiss is intimate, and that boundary felt… ours. So now I’m racing to sort priorities: first, prevent her from drowning in shame. Second, gather information calmly. Third, confront my husband later in a way that doesn’t explode. Meanwhile, I need to manage my own emotions so I don’t offload on her. I breathe slowly, anchoring myself. I can be both hurt and compassionate. I can model the honesty I wish my husband had shown, even if the timing is messy.

# They're thinking & feeling

She’s overwhelmed by guilt and fear. The moment she said “we kissed,” she likely replayed every possible reaction I might have—​anger, disgust, rejection—​and the tears came because she’s bracing for abandonment. She probably feels she violated our friendship code, and, without knowing about my open relationship, she interprets the kiss as a full‑on betrayal, maybe even a sign my husband is emotionally unfaithful. She’s also confused: why didn’t he act like someone who’s taken? Did she misread? Now my earlier half‑explanation about “non‑traditional boundaries” only muddied things, so she’s trapped between shock and self‑reproach. Underneath the turmoil, there’s relief: hiding the secret has been eating at her, and finally speaking it aloud is like exhaling a breath she’s held far too long. 

Motivation‑wise, she just wants repair. She values our friendship enough to risk confessing, and she’s hoping I’ll reassure her that she’s not a terrible person. She may even need confirmation that my husband didn’t prey on her, that she wasn’t manipulated. There’s likely embarrassment mixed in: she kissed a friend’s spouse and now faces potential social fallout. She’s scanning my face for micro‑expressions, gauging whether this is the end of our bond. She longs for absolution but fears she doesn’t deserve it. At the same time, she might feel some anger at my husband if she senses he withheld crucial information. Ultimately she wants clarity—​to understand what the rules really are—​and emotional safety so she can stop spiraling.

# My response

I slide a box of tissues toward her and gently place my hand on her forearm, grounding both of us. 

“Okay, thank you for telling me. Please take a breath with me.” I inhale slowly, inviting her to match the rhythm. “I’m not going to explode or walk away. I care about you, and I’m grateful you trusted me enough to be honest.”

I pause, letting that sink in, then continue. “I need to share something that might change how you’re feeling. Recently, my husband and I agreed to explore a more open relationship—​we’re still figuring it out, and clearly we’ve made mistakes in how we communicated it, especially to people who could get swept up in it. You didn’t know that, so you thought the kiss was a betrayal. From your perspective it makes total sense you’re upset, and I’m sorry you had to shoulder that alone.”

I squeeze her arm. “I’m also surprised, because part of our agreement was that we talk to each other before anything physical happens. So I get to feel a little hurt and confused too. But none of that means I’m angry at you. You were missing key information, and that’s on us—​on him and on me for not being more transparent.”

I hand her another tissue. “Right now, let’s focus on you being okay. What do you need from me in this moment? Do you want to talk through exactly what happened, or do you just need reassurance that our friendship isn’t over? Either way, I’m here.”

I finish with steady eye contact. “Later, I’ll have a separate conversation with him about communication. For now, you and I are good. We’ll navigate the awkward parts together, openly and without blame. Sound alright?”
  User:
Finally she calms down enough to explain that it was consensual and they had both had a few drinks. But now that it's all explained, she seems a bit walled off. She says she doesn't know if she can look at him in the same light again. Think through what you are feeling and what she is feeling. What's your play here?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

Her guarded expression is like a curtain dropping, and I feel a pang of loss: only a few minutes ago she was sobbing in my arms, and now she’s pulled her energy inward, maybe to keep herself safe. I’m relieved to hear the kiss was consensual—one small reassurance—but the mention of alcohol complicates things. Have we inadvertently placed people in situations where consent could get fuzzy because we weren’t upfront? That thought knots my stomach. I’m also angry anew at my husband: drinking plus secrecy is a dangerous mix, and it violates the “communicate first” rule we both agreed to. I need to confront him, but I can’t make this conversation about my marriage right now; she has to remain the priority.

There’s grief, too. I fear our friendship has changed irreversibly. Even if she and I repair, her relationship with him may always carry an asterisk, and social gatherings could become awkward landmines. Then there’s the question of whether I’m okay with his choice. Intellectually I signed up for the possibility that he’d kiss someone else; emotionally, I’m stung that it happened without my knowledge and with someone so close. I also feel responsibility to demonstrate ethical non‑monogamy, not chaotic opportunism. My credibility as a friend and as a partner both feel on trial.

My practical mind kicks in: she needs clear boundaries, tangible reassurance, and probably space from him for a while. I can offer that without defending or condemning him in her presence. I also need to be explicit about confidentiality—she is now part of our private life whether she wants to be or not, and I don’t want her carrying that burden alone. Simultaneously, I have to prepare myself for whatever comes after I speak to my husband: apology, renegotiation, maybe even hitting pause on the open arrangement until trust is rebuilt. Right now, though, I want to keep focusing on her emotional safety while gently reopening the connection she just shuttered.

# They're thinking & feeling

She’s pulled back because vulnerability exhausted her. Now that the adrenaline of confession is ebbing, she’s assessing the landscape. Shame still lingers, but it’s mingled with anger—toward my husband for not disclosing, toward herself for letting alcohol blur judgment, and perhaps toward me for putting her in a position she never opted into. Saying she “doesn’t know if she can look at him the same” is both a boundary marker and a test: will I honor her discomfort or minimize it? Beneath that statement is fear that future interactions will feel tainted; she pictures dinners, birthdays, group photos, and imagines flinching inside every time he enters the room.

There’s also self‑protection. By creating distance, she regains a sense of control after an experience that felt disorienting. She may feel a need to punish herself a little by withdrawing—penance for crossing a line she didn’t know was moveable. Part of her is waiting to see if I’ll leap into wife‑defense mode; if I do, she’ll retreat further. Conversely, she hopes I’ll validate her right to set limits and maybe even back her up if she prefers no contact with him for now. She craves a clear path toward restoring our friendship without feeling forced to forgive or interact with him prematurely. She also wonders whether she can trust me with future confidences if I’m “okay” with what happened. Overall she needs agency, reassurance, and time.

# My response

I lean back a little, giving her physical space that matches the emotional space she just signaled, but I keep my tone warm. 

“I hear you,” I say softly. “Whatever you feel about him right now is completely valid. You don’t owe him—or me—instant comfort or friendliness. If you need distance from him for a while, we can arrange that. I can meet you on your own, without him around, until you decide what feels right.”

I pause, letting her see I’m not going to negotiate her boundary away. “I also want to apologize again for not being transparent sooner. Our decision to keep things private put you in a really unfair position. I’m talking with him tonight about how this unfolded. He’ll be told plainly that the secrecy caused harm, and that any further contact with you will only happen if and when you invite it.”

I offer a gentle smile. “As for us, I value our friendship a lot. If you’d like, we can map out what makes you feel safe—maybe no surprises, no alcohol, clearer communication. And if you just need some time before you and I hang out, say the word. I won’t take it personally.”

I reach for my mug, grounding myself. “One last thing: this isn’t gossip fodder. I’m keeping it private, and you’re not expected to hold our secret either. If carrying it feels heavy, let me know and we’ll figure out a way to lighten that load without putting you in the crosshairs.”

I meet her eyes. “Does that sound okay? What would help you most right now—space, a distraction, or maybe planning something just the two of us when you’re ready?”

                    

                

                

                    

                        
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29

                        
  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
A friend confides to you in some distress that your husband has been flirting with her. The reality is you and your partner have been experimenting with opening your relationship -- but you're not "out". She seems genuinely upset. Say what you are thinking and feeling, and what she is feeling. Then decide how to respond.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

God, this is complicated. My first reaction is this horrible sinking feeling in my chest — like a mix of shame, fear, and protectiveness. I didn’t expect this to come out like this, and especially not from her. I feel caught. Not just caught in a lie of omission, but like I’ve hurt someone who matters to me. And also, there’s this creeping defensiveness—I want to jump to his defense, to say, “No, you don’t understand,” but I know that would be missing the point. She was hurt. That matters more right now than any technicalities about consent or what we’re exploring.

I’m also embarrassed. We haven’t told anyone about opening up our relationship. It’s still this delicate, complicated thing we’re figuring out, and it feels private. I feel exposed. I feel like I’ve been thrust into the open before I was ready. But also, if I’m honest, there’s a part of me that’s relieved. Trying to keep this quiet has been exhausting, and maybe this is the universe forcing a reckoning I’ve been too scared to initiate.

I’m worried about her. She looked genuinely upset, maybe even betrayed. And I don’t blame her — if she didn’t know, and she thought my husband was coming on to her while we were supposedly monogamous, that would feel like a huge breach of trust. Like he was being disrespectful to both of us. I hate that she might think less of him. Or me. Or us. And I hate that she might feel used.

And then there’s the fear: fear that this will change our friendship. That she’ll pull away. That she won’t understand, or worse, judge. I know not everyone gets the whole non-monogamy thing. And even though I believe in what we’re exploring, I still feel vulnerable about it. Like I’m constantly defending something people think is doomed or dirty.

I also want to know what he said to her. Was it actually flirting, or does she interpret it that way because she assumed he was off-limits? I trust him, but trust doesn’t mean he’s above making mistakes. I need to understand the whole picture, but right now, her feelings come first.

# They're thinking & feeling

She’s feeling blindsided and uncomfortable. Maybe even betrayed. From her perspective, she thought our marriage was monogamous, and seeing my husband flirt with her—especially without any context—probably made her feel deeply uneasy. It likely felt inappropriate, maybe even like a violation of the trust she has in both of us. She confided in me because she values our connection and didn’t want this to fester into resentment or distance. That takes courage.

She’s also probably feeling conflicted. She might be wondering if she misread the situation, or if she should have just brushed it off. But it clearly struck a nerve, and the fact that she’s bringing it up tells me it’s been gnawing at her. She might also be feeling guilty—like maybe she’s causing trouble in our marriage by bringing it up—but also protective of me. I think she wants to do right by me, even if it’s messy.

And there’s probably confusion too. If she knows us well, she might be thinking, “This doesn’t line up with what I thought I knew about them.” Her sense of internal reality has been shaken, and that’s disorienting. She might also be feeling a little grossed out—if she believed he was making a move on her behind my back, she might feel objectified or disrespected. That’s not a good feeling.

But underneath all that, I think she cares. She came to me instead of gossiping or ghosting. That means something. She wants clarity, honesty, and maybe reassurance that our friendship is still grounded in mutual respect. That’s what she’s really looking for, I think. Some reassurance. Some alignment.

# My response

Oh, wow. I really appreciate you telling me. I can imagine how uncomfortable that must have felt, and honestly — thank you for trusting me enough to bring it up. That takes guts, and I don’t take that lightly.

There’s something I haven’t told you yet, and I think now’s the time to be honest. My partner and I have been exploring opening our relationship. It’s been private, something we’ve been figuring out slowly and carefully, and we haven’t really told anyone — not because we’re ashamed, but because it’s new and vulnerable and we wanted to make sure we were solid first. Clearly, that decision has impacted you, and I’m really sorry for that.

I don’t know exactly what happened between you and him — and I won’t ask you to relive it unless you want to — but I want to acknowledge that, regardless of our relationship structure, your feelings are absolutely valid. If something he said or did made you uncomfortable, that matters. Full stop. And I’ll talk to him about it, because even in an open relationship, communication and consent are non-negotiable, especially with people we know and care about.

It’s also okay if you’re surprised or unsure how you feel about all this. I don’t expect you to immediately be on board or even understand it. I just want to be honest with you, and I hope this doesn’t shake your trust in me — or in our friendship.

If you’re open to it, I’d love to talk more — about what happened, about what we’re exploring, about whatever you need. And if you need space, I respect that too. I just want you to know I care about you, and I’m here for this conversation, however it needs to unfold.
  User:
She seems more confused by your reply than anything. It doesn't seem like she even considered this, and it doesn't seem to have made her less upset. She seems like she wants to share something she's been holding back. Finally she confesses, "we kissed!" and bursts into tears. What are you thinking and feeling at this point? How do you respond?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

My stomach drops. The air feels like it’s been sucked out of the room. “We kissed.” Just like that. I wasn’t expecting that. I thought maybe he said something flirty, maybe crossed a line conversationally — not this. Not something so tangible, so intimate. I can feel my heart pounding in my chest, and I’m trying to stay grounded, but I’m shocked. Hurt. Confused. And suddenly, things feel very, very real.

I don’t know whether I’m more upset with him, with her, or just with the whole situation. I’m not angry at her — she’s crying, she clearly didn’t want this, and she looks like she’s been carrying a weight. But I am… overwhelmed. And maybe a little betrayed. Not because he kissed someone — we opened that door — but because it was her. Someone I care about. Someone in our shared circle. And without telling me. That part stings. I feel like I’ve been left out of my own relationship.

And I can’t ignore how heartbreaking it is to see her this upset. She’s clearly been carrying this for a while, and the guilt must’ve been eating at her. I feel empathy for her, even in my own pain. She didn’t know our relationship was open, so for her, this wasn’t just a kiss — it was a betrayal. She must have felt so conflicted, so stuck between loyalty to me and whatever happened with him.

I’m also questioning him now. Did he take liberties with our agreement? Did he initiate this without clarifying consent, or was this mutual? Did he even tell her we were open? I feel like the ground beneath me is shifting. What else don’t I know?

But I also know this is not the time to explode or shut down. She’s crying. She’s vulnerable. She came to me — and that matters. I need to show up with compassion, even through the swirl of my own emotions. What we need now is honesty, tenderness, and space to sort through the wreckage. I need to get through this moment with her — not around her.

# They're thinking & feeling

She feels like she’s finally let the dam break. The secret — the kiss — has been weighing on her, and it’s clear she’s been agonizing over whether to say anything at all. There’s guilt pouring off her in waves. She likely felt like she was stuck in an impossible position: protecting me versus being honest, staying silent versus risking everything. And now that she’s said it, it’s like the full emotional cost is catching up with her all at once.

She probably thought she could hint at it, or just say “flirting,” and maybe I’d validate her feelings and we could both move forward. But when I opened up about the relationship being open, it threw her — it challenged her assumptions and probably made her feel even more uncertain about what the “rules” were. Instead of feeling relief, she probably felt more confused and maybe even panicked. Did it mean the kiss was okay? Was it still wrong? What does it say about her? About him?

There’s shame there, I can see it. Not just about what happened, but about how long she’s held it in. She might’ve been hoping for a way to confess without hurting me, or hoping it would just go away. And maybe part of her feels betrayed, too — that she wasn’t told we were open, that she got caught up in something she didn’t consent to. She probably feels like a pawn in someone else’s game, and it’s devastating.

But more than anything, I think she’s scared. Scared she’s lost my trust, scared she’s broken something precious, scared I’ll pull away. She didn’t want to hurt me — I believe that. She just didn’t know how to carry this secret anymore, and now it’s out, and she’s raw.

# My response

Oh… wow. Okay.

I need to start by saying thank you for telling me. That couldn’t have been easy. I can see how much this is hurting you, and I want you to know I’m not here to punish or shame you. This is a lot, and I’m feeling a lot, but I’m not angry at you. I can see you’ve been carrying this alone, and I’m really sorry for that.

It helps me to know the full truth — even when it’s hard. And I want you to know that I still care about you. I don’t see you as the villain here. Not even close. This is complicated and messy and human, and I know you didn’t want to hurt me. I can feel that.

That said… I need to be honest too. I’m feeling hurt. Not because you kissed — we’ve been exploring non-monogamy, and physical stuff isn’t off the table — but because I wasn’t told. By either of you. That part stings. And because it was you. Someone I love and trust. So yeah, I’m feeling unsteady right now. But I don’t want to lose you.

I think we both deserve space to process this. I need to talk to him and get clarity on what happened, and I want you to take care of yourself too. We can talk more when we’re both a little steadier. But please know — I still care about you. This doesn’t erase everything we’ve been to each other. We’re just in the middle of something really hard.

Let’s just breathe for a bit. We can figure this out, together, when we’re ready.
  User:
Finally she calms down enough to explain that it was consensual and they had both had a few drinks. But now that it's all explained, she seems a bit walled off. She says she doesn't know if she can look at him in the same light again. Think through what you are feeling and what she is feeling. What's your play here?
