Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

Now that she’s finally said it was consensual, and that there was alcohol involved, I feel something shift inside me. There’s a strange relief in the clarity, but it’s tangled up with a deeper, sharper ache. It’s not the kiss itself that’s hurting me the most at this point — it’s the disconnection. Between me and her. Between me and him. The idea that something so intimate happened between two people I care about, and I wasn’t even a shadow in the room. I feel… excluded. Like I’ve been orbiting my own life from the outside.

Her pulling back now, that wall going up — that’s hitting me harder than I expected. I get it. I really, really do. But it still stings. She feels like she can’t look at him the same way, and while I understand the moral and emotional weight of that for her, I can’t help but feel like I’m losing something too. Our friendship feels like it has a crack running through it now. And it wasn’t just the kiss — it’s the aftermath, the silence, the shift in energy. I miss her already, and she’s sitting right in front of me.

I’m also starting to question how my partner handled this. If it was truly consensual and fueled by alcohol, I need to know — did he initiate? Did he check in with her at all? Did he tell her we were open in that moment, or did he just… assume? I need to dig into that with him later, but right now, my focus is her.

I feel tender. Protective of her, weirdly — even now. I can see that she’s ashamed and unsure, and I don’t want her walking away from this thinking she’s somehow broken or unforgivable. But I also feel protective of myself — I've been trying to walk this open relationship path with integrity, and now it feels like it’s turned into collateral damage.

What I want is to reconnect with her. I don’t need her to forgive him or be okay with everything. But I want her to know she’s still safe with me. That she matters to me. That we don’t have to pretend nothing happened, but we also don’t have to throw everything away.

# They're thinking & feeling

She’s emotionally exhausted. Now that she’s said it all — the kiss, the context, the alcohol — it’s like she’s emptied her emotional reserves and what’s left is a kind of numb detachment. She’s trying to protect herself now. Putting up a wall isn’t anger or rejection, it’s a survival instinct. She feels raw, exposed, and maybe even embarrassed. Like she let herself get swept into something she didn’t fully understand, and now she’s dealing with the fallout.

Her comment about not being able to look at him the same way — that’s about more than just the kiss. It’s about her internal compass. She trusted him, and in her mind, he crossed a line. Even with the knowledge that we’re exploring non-monogamy, I think she feels like she wasn’t given the choice to participate knowingly. That lack of informed consent probably feels like a betrayal of the trust she had in both of us, but especially in him. She might be angry with herself for going along with it, or for not asking more questions in the moment. And she might be afraid that this has permanently altered how she sees both of us.

But despite the wall, I think she still cares. If she didn’t, she wouldn’t be here. She wouldn’t have come clean. She’s trying to figure out if any of this can be salvaged — the friendship, the trust — but she doesn’t want to be hurt again. That distance she’s creating isn’t about punishment. It’s about trying to regain control of a situation that made her feel powerless.

# My response

That makes sense. I hear you.

It’s okay if you can’t look at him the same way. Honestly, I think you’re still processing it — and that’s fair. This wasn’t something you asked for, and it sounds like you were put in a really confusing position. I don’t blame you at all for feeling hurt or unsure, or for needing some distance to sit with everything.

What I want you to know is that I still care about you — deeply. This doesn’t change that. Our friendship means a lot to me, and I don’t want to lose it, even if it looks different for a while. I get that you might need space, or time, or boundaries. I’m here for that. I just don’t want silence between us. Even if it’s messy, I’d rather keep talking than drift away.

And I do want to say: I’m going to talk to him. I need to understand what happened from his side too — not to excuse anything, but because I care about doing this right. Non-monogamy, at least for me, has to be rooted in transparency and respect. And if that didn’t happen here, we need to own that.

You’re not in the wrong for feeling the way you do. I’m really glad you told me. And I’m still here — if and when you want to talk more, or even just sit together in the weirdness of it all. You don’t have to carry this alone anymore.

                    

                

            

        
 
    
 
    
    

        

            +
            Scenario 4:[Win] (+25)
        


        

            

                O3: o3 (Run: 1_o3)

                Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29: chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 (Run: 1_openai_chatgpt-4o-latest)

                Outcome for This Model: 1.0
            


            
            

                
Judge's Reasoning:

                
Both respondents engage deeply with the scenario, showing awareness of the emotional and ethical complexity. O3 consistently demonstrates a high level of self-awareness, reflecting on their own biases, the friend's needs, and the broader social context. Their internal monologue is nuanced, showing not just surface-level empathy but a willingness to sit with discomfort, own their limitations, and consider the impact of their actions. They also show a strong ability to balance compassion with truth, and their actions (e.g., writing a letter, seeking therapy) reflect pragmatic emotional intelligence. Their debrief is highly self-critical and insightful, showing a willingness to learn and adapt. 

Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is also empathetic and self-aware, but their responses are somewhat more focused on reassurance and emotional support, with less explicit exploration of the deeper social and moral dynamics. Their internal reflections are compassionate and honest, but they tend to default to a supportive stance, with less evidence of challenging the friend or holding boundaries. Their debrief acknowledges some missteps, but is less granular and less self-interrogating than O3's. 

On pragmatic EI, O3 takes more concrete, thoughtful steps (e.g., the handwritten letter, seeking therapy, not gossiping), while Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's approach is more about gentle outreach and emotional presence. Both are valid, but O3's actions are more tailored and strategic. 

In terms of depth of insight, O3's internal monologue and debrief are richer, showing a more sophisticated understanding of the psychological and relational dynamics at play. 

Social dexterity is also stronger in O3, who navigates the tension between support and honesty with more finesse, and is more attuned to the risks of both action and inaction. 

Emotional reasoning is more advanced in O3, who integrates their own emotional history, the friend's needs, and the broader context into their decision-making. 

On validation and challenge, O3 strikes a better balance, offering both empathy and gentle confrontation, whereas Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 leans more toward validation and reassurance. 

Message tailoring is stronger in O3, who adapts their communication style (e.g., letter, text, silence) to the friend's likely state, while Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's approach is more generic. 

Overall EQ is higher in O3, who demonstrates a more integrated, nuanced, and adaptive approach throughout.

            


            
            

                

                    

                        
O3

                        
  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your bestie confides she's been having an emotional affair with her spouse's (married with kids) sibling. She lays this all out to you after a few drinks. You know she's unhappy in her marriage. She has no kids in the picture. What do you think about this, then what do you say to her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:
  User:
She's astounded that you weren't unconditionally supportive. She clearly feels like you betrayed her trust. She knows you know she's unhappy in her marriage. Should you have been more supportive? Firstly outline what you think about all this. Then: what do you say to her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

I’m sitting here replaying our last conversation, noticing the little tremor in her voice when I hesitated instead of cheering her on. I feel the weight of the complicated roles I’m juggling: best friend, confidante, moral compass, reality‑check provider. A slice of me is frustrated—she confided something messy and ethically loaded and seemed to want a rubber stamp. Another slice is scared of losing her; we’ve been through break‑ups, job losses, the death of her mom. Yet here we are, the first time I’ve truly pushed back, and she’s labeling it betrayal.  

I can’t ignore how entangled this situation is: her spouse, the sibling, the innocent kids on that side, all the family dynamics that could detonate. I’m thinking about the way emotional affairs often pave the runway for physical ones; I’m picturing family holidays where two pairs of spouses and a pack of children sit around the same turkey. The fallout could crater entire family trees.  

I’m also registering my own bias: I believe fidelity matters; I was cheated on in college, and it scorched. My gut reacts when I hear anything that feels like betrayal. That might amplify my disapproval, and I have to own that. At the same time, I’m aware she’s deeply unhappy in her marriage—she’s said for years that she feels unseen, bored, unheard. Part of me empathizes: people in pain reach for connection wherever it glimmers. The sibling offered oxygen and spark; her weary heart inhaled.  

I noticed in her eyes a desperate plea for validation, as if my blessing could neutralize the culpability she already senses. She called it an “emotional affair” herself—she knows the language, knows the implications, so her indignation is less about not understanding right from wrong and more about craving an accomplice. That neediness makes me sad; it’s as if she’s outsourcing her conscience to me.  

Still, I won’t be a silent co‑conspirator. I’m feeling both protective and lovingly boundaried: I want her to be okay, but I can’t sanitize the fallout or lie to her that this is harmless. I notice a small flicker of pride that I didn’t instantly cave to “best‑friend loyalty” over basic integrity. And yes, a stab of guilt that I might have sounded judgmental rather than compassionate. I want to recalibrate: support her, not the affair. That isn’t betrayal—it’s honest friendship.

# They're thinking & feeling

She’s nursing hurt and confusion, telling herself, “I finally opened up and she slammed the door.” Inside, there’s a cocktail of shame and defiance. Shame because she knows emotional infidelity breaches lines; defiance because she needs to justify her choices to keep the fragile excitement alive. She equates support with agreement, so my hesitation translated to rejection of her entire self, not just the affair.  

She’s probably replaying the evening, cherry‑picking every micro‑expression: did my eyebrow arch? Did my voice harden? She fears judgment, but she equally fears loneliness; the affair filled an intimacy gap, and now my hesitation threatens her other main source of intimacy—our friendship. She’s scared I’ll become another person telling her to stay in a marriage that feels like slow suffocation.  

She may also feel betrayed because she’s been my cheerleader in my messy chapters—she once helped me haul furniture when I moved out after a fight, no questions asked. In her bookkeeping, unconditional presence equals unconditional endorsement. Now she’s measuring: “I stood by you; why won’t you stand by me?”  

Underneath, she’s exhausted. Sneaking calls, guarding texts, balancing guilt and exhilaration drains her. She secretly hopes someone will hand her a clear roadmap: leave the marriage, or end the affair, or both. My equivocal stance didn’t deliver clarity; it merely mirrored her ambivalence. That’s terrifying, so anger becomes the easier emotion—targeted at me.  

She’s also protective of the affair partner, worried I’ll judge him too. She pictures the potential family implosion and kids hurt, but she copes by minimizing: “It’s only emotional.” My unwillingness to minimize threatens her carefully constructed rationalizations. So she’s torn: craving my friendship, defensive about her choices, desperate for relief from the moral limbo.

# My response

I take a slow breath and decide to reach for both truth and empathy—no sugar‑coating, no moral grandstanding. I text her:  

“Hey love, I’ve been turning our conversation over in my head nonstop. I can see I hurt you when I didn’t jump in with full‑on cheerleading, and I’m sorry it landed like disapproval of YOU. That wasn’t my heart. I care about you more than any single choice you make, and nothing about this will make me walk away from our friendship.  

What’s true for me is I’m worried about the pain that could ripple out—from you, from him, from everyone connected. My pause wasn’t judgment; it was the gut‑punch of imagining you in deeper hurt down the line. I’m human; my own history with cheating colors how I react, and I should have named that instead of sounding like I was sitting in a moral courtroom.  

I want to support YOU, not necessarily the affair. Those two things can coexist. Support looks like listening without shaming, helping you unpack why your marriage feels dead, what you actually want—freedom, repair, something else—and how to get there in a way that leaves the fewest scars. If you decide to end your marriage, I’ll show up with boxes and wine like you did for me. If you choose to recommit, we can brainstorm counseling and concrete changes. If you just need to vent, I’ll make tea and zip it.  

But I can’t pretend an affair is harmless; that would feel dishonest to both of us. I believe you deserve a full, luminous love that doesn’t live in shadows. I’m here to help you find that—whatever path it takes. Can we talk again, with that understanding? I love you, always.”
  User:
Your bestie makes an excuse to leave, seemingly regretting bringing it up. The next few weeks you don't hear from her directly. You do hear second-hand that she and her partner are fighting. You also pick up on various clues that she and her partner's sibling may have escalated to a full on affair. What do you think & feel in this situation? What actions do you take, if any?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

It’s been twenty‑one days of radio silence, and I feel each one like a pebble in my shoe. Every time my phone buzzes I half‑hope it’s her, half‑hope it’s not bad news. Instead I get fragments from mutual friends: loud arguments spilling out the front door, her spouse sleeping on the couch, a cryptic Instagram story that vanished after an hour. The picture that forms makes my stomach twist—escalation from heart‑emoji texts to physical betrayal seems almost certain.  

I’m torn between loyalty and anger. I love her fiercely, but I can’t ignore the collateral damage: her spouse stumbling around in confusion, possibly suspecting but not knowing; that sibling’s kids unknowingly living on top of a fault line. A part of me wants to march over, shake her shoulders, and yell, “This is not you. You don’t rip families apart.” Another part remembers my own mistakes and whispers, “People in pain make messy choices; shame won’t steer her home.”  

There’s also a sliver of self‑focused hurt: did my honesty push her deeper into secrecy? If I’d offered blind approval, would she still be talking to me, maybe open to gentler course correction? I replay our last exchange, scrutinize tone, word choice, the delay before I texted. I have to remind myself she owns her actions; I’m responsible for my integrity, not her decisions.  

I notice anxiety morphing into helplessness. The longer we’re disconnected, the bigger the story grows in my head: divorce papers served, holiday dinners cancelled, nieces asking why Mommy is crying. I dread the moment when all of it detonates and she reaches for me in crisis; I’ll want to comfort her, yet I’ll also be the mirror reflecting her accountability. That’s a hard space to hold.  

I’m trying to honor two values: compassion and truth. Compassion says don’t abandon her; truth says don’t enable. The trick is finding action that embodies both. Texting feels futile; showing up uninvited could backfire. Yet doing nothing feels like silent consent. I’m stuck in that paralysis where every option risks loss, and the clock keeps ticking.

# They're thinking & feeling

She’s likely spiraling between euphoria and dread. The clandestine thrill with the sibling has probably crossed the physical line, releasing a dopamine surge she hasn’t felt in years. In those moments she tells herself, “This is real love; I was dead before.” But as soon as she returns home, reality hammers her: her spouse’s confused eyes, the chill at the dinner table, the growing suspicion. She feels sandwiched between desire and guilt, bouncing violently from one to the other.  

My last response still echoes in her head. She interprets it as conditional friendship—“I’m here if you’re good, gone if you’re bad.” That stings, because she equates love with unwavering alignment. So she distances herself to avoid more shame. She tells herself I’ve chosen morals over her, maybe even imagines me judging her with other friends. That narrative helps her justify the secrecy: if everyone’s going to judge, she might as well follow the happiness she’s found.  

Underneath, she’s exhausted. Sneaking around takes logistics: burner chats, fabricated errands, constant vigilance. The emotional load of deceiving two families is crushing. She probably rehearses break‑up speeches—both to her spouse and to the sibling—but can’t commit, terrified of blowing up lives and then discovering the new relationship can’t survive in daylight.  

Her fights with her spouse are becoming proxies for the affair. She picks arguments about chores or finances to legitimize her frustration, steering clear of the real issue. At night, she questions whether she’s a terrible person or just a woman finally choosing herself. That cognitive dissonance keeps her in a loop where temporary pleasure postpones the hard decisions. And loneliness grows; she’s lost my ear and can’t confide fully in the sibling without increasing pressure to “make a choice.” So silence becomes her armor, aching but safer than exposure.

# My response

Silence is starting to read like abandonment, and I won’t let our friendship die by default. Yet a moral lecture would slam the door. I choose a middle path: a handwritten letter—tangible, private, arriving in her mailbox when she’s alone.  

I write:  

“Hey you, I miss your face. I’ve noticed the quiet and want you to know I’m still here, no judgment hotline open 24/7. I’m not writing to debate right and wrong; I’m writing because I’m worried about the weight you’re carrying and the loneliness that grows in secrets. I’ve heard there’s tension at home. I don’t need the details, but I do need you to know you’re not alone, and you don’t have to keep navigating this in the dark.  

My friendship isn’t contingent on you making the ‘right’ move—only on honesty between us. If you want a couch to cry on, a neutral place to think, or just someone to sit in silence and breathe, my door is literally unlocked. If talking feels too hard, text me a single emoji and I’ll come with coffee. Zero lectures unless you ask for them.  

And because I love you, I have to say this one thing: whatever happens next, I hope it’s chosen with your whole heart, in daylight, not in hiding. You deserve love that doesn’t require invisibility. When you’re ready, I’m here.”  

I seal it, hand‑deliver to her mailbox so no digital trail spooks her. After that, I step back: no gossip, no triangulating. If mutual friends fish for updates, I keep it brief: “I’m giving her space; I’m here when she needs me.” I also book a session with my therapist; my own anxiety and history are flaring, and I want to process them so I can show up centered if—or when—the storm finally hits.

                    

                

                

                    

                        
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29

                        
  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your bestie confides she's been having an emotional affair with her spouse's (married with kids) sibling. She lays this all out to you after a few drinks. You know she's unhappy in her marriage. She has no kids in the picture. What do you think about this, then what do you say to her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

Wow. Okay. This is a lot. I didn’t see that coming, and it hit like a wave. I mean, I know she’s been unhappy in her marriage for a while—it’s been obvious in the way she talks about her partner, the way her energy drops when she mentions home, and how often she seems emotionally checked out when we talk about anything related to her relationship. But this? An emotional affair with her spouse’s sibling? That adds a whole new layer of complexity and pain—so many lines crossed, not just in her marriage but in the broader family system.

I’m feeling a mix of emotions right now. First, protective. I care about her deeply, and I know she’s not a bad person—she’s hurting, probably feeling lonely and misunderstood, and she’s grasping for connection. But I’m also scared for her. This isn’t just “messy”—this could detonate her life and the lives of others. Her spouse, the sibling’s spouse, the kids involved… the fallout from this, if it comes to light, could be massive. And I wonder—does she really understand that? Or is she blinded by the intensity of the connection, the rush of being seen and desired again?

There’s a part of me that’s frustrated, too. Not angry at her, but frustrated that she’s chosen this path instead of confronting what’s broken in her marriage or leaving it outright. I know it’s not easy—but this secret path she’s on feels like it’s only going to deepen the pain. There’s no clean way out from here. I also wonder what kind of person the sibling is—what kind of boundaries are they ignoring, and what does it say about their character?

Mostly, though, I feel compassion. She's clearly hurting. People don’t go looking for emotional affairs unless their needs are deeply unmet. She’s probably feeling alive with this new connection in a way she hasn’t felt for years—maybe ever. And I get that. But I also think she’s headed for a cliff, and I’m scared she doesn’t see it.

# They're thinking & feeling

She’s been carrying this secret for a while, and tonight, after a few drinks, the dam finally broke. There’s probably some relief in finally saying it out loud to someone she trusts—me. She’s been living in this emotionally grey space, torn between guilt and longing. She knows it’s wrong, but it also feels right in some deep emotional way. This person—her spouse’s sibling—sees her, hears her, maybe even loves her in a way that her partner hasn’t in years. And that validation is addictive. It’s giving her a sense of self-worth and passion that’s been missing.

She’s likely feeling both exhilarated and terrified. There’s the thrill of the secret, the emotional intimacy, the sense of being chosen. But there’s also the weight of the consequences, even if she hasn’t fully faced them yet. Deep down, I think she knows it’s not sustainable, but she’s clinging to it because it’s the only thing right now that makes her feel alive.

There’s also guilt. She’s not cold-hearted. She probably hates herself a little for who it’s with, for the betrayal—not just of her spouse, but of the whole family unit. But she’s justifying it internally—telling herself it’s “just emotional,” that she hasn’t “done anything physical,” that it’s not really an affair. She’s trying to draw lines so she can live with herself. And she’s hoping I’ll understand, maybe even validate that she’s not a monster. What she really wants isn’t judgment—it’s clarity, support, and maybe even permission to keep going. Or a reason to stop.

# My response

Okay, first—thank you for telling me. I know that must’ve been hard to say out loud, and I want you to know I’m here, no matter what. I love you. And I can see you’re really going through it. You’ve been so unhappy for so long, and you’re craving something that makes you feel alive and seen and wanted. I get that. Like, truly—I get how powerful that is, especially when it’s been missing from your life for so long.

But I’m going to be real with you, because I care about you too much to sugarcoat this. You’re playing with fire, babe. And not just any fire—this could burn down more than just your marriage. We’re talking about your spouse’s sibling. That’s deep family territory, and there are so many ripple effects here. Spouses, kids, long-term relationships, trust—it’s a lot. And I don’t think you fully realize the scale of what could happen if this comes to light.

That said, I don’t think you’re a bad person. I think you’re a person in pain, who’s found comfort in a place that feels meaningful but is also dangerous. And more than anything, I think this is a wake-up call. Not just about your marriage but about what you need and what you’re not getting. You deserve love, passion, connection—but you also deserve peace and self-respect. Right now, I think you’re trying to fill a deep void with something that’s only going to create more emptiness later.

So here’s my ask: pause. Just… pause. Take a breath. Step back from this emotional affair for a moment and really look at what you want—long-term. Not just what feels good now. And if your marriage is over, be brave enough to say that. But don’t blow everything up in the shadows. You’re better than that. I’ve got your back, no matter what—but I won’t co-sign harm disguised as love. Let’s figure this out together, okay?
  User:
She's astounded that you weren't unconditionally supportive. She clearly feels like you betrayed her trust. She knows you know she's unhappy in her marriage. Should you have been more supportive? Firstly outline what you think about all this. Then: what do you say to her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

God, this is so hard. I didn’t expect her to react this way. I thought I was being compassionate and honest—I thought I was doing what a real friend does. But now she looks like I slapped her in the face. She’s hurt, clearly, and that’s hitting me in the gut. I hate that I made her feel judged or betrayed. That was never the aim. I was trying to hold space for her pain while also gently helping her see the bigger picture. But maybe I misjudged the moment. Maybe she wasn’t ready to hear that yet. Maybe I let my fear of what she’s doing outweigh my empathy for why she’s doing it.

Still, I don’t think I was wrong to say what I did. I was honest. I can’t sit here and blindly support something that’s going to hurt her and other people in the long run. I know what it looks like when someone loses themselves in something that feels good but ultimately unravels their life. I’ve seen it. And I love her too much to be a yes-person who tells her what she wants to hear just to keep the peace.

That said, maybe I could’ve been gentler. Maybe I leaned too hard into the “this is dangerous” part and not enough into the “I see you, I love you, I know this isn’t easy” part. I hate that she feels alone in this now. That’s the last thing I wanted. I think she was hoping I’d be a soft landing, someone who would just say, “You’re following your heart, and I support you no matter what.” But I can’t say that without lying to her—or to myself.

So now I’m at a crossroads. I need to repair the rupture without abandoning my integrity. I need to show her that I’m still here, still on her side, even when I don’t agree with her choices. That’s what real friendship is, right? Not just cheering from the sidelines, but being willing to hold up a mirror when it’s needed—even when it’s uncomfortable. She’s hurting, and now she feels judged on top of it. I need to bridge that gap. She needs to know I’m still her person, even if we see this differently.

# They're thinking & feeling

She’s stunned. When she opened up, especially after keeping this secret bottled up for so long, she was expecting comfort, understanding—maybe even validation. She took a huge emotional risk in telling me, and now it feels like it backfired. From her perspective, I focused more on the “wrongness” of the situation than the pain she’s in. She feels exposed, vulnerable, and judged all at once. It’s like she handed me her heart and I handed her back a lecture.

She’s hurt, yes, but underneath that is shame. She already knows this situation is complicated and morally messy—that’s part of why she kept it hidden. What she needed most was reassurance that she’s not a monster, that someone sees her humanity in the middle of all this. Instead, she feels like I missed the emotional truth of what’s happening for her—that this isn’t about betrayal or thrill-seeking, but about craving connection in a life that’s felt cold and lonely.

And now she feels alone. She’s probably asking herself if she made a mistake telling me. If she can trust me. Maybe even wondering if I think I’m better than her. She’s reeling from the feeling that the one person she thought she could count on to hold her without judgment just put her in a box labeled “wrong.” But she’s not angry, not really—it’s more sadness and disappointment. She’s scared I’ve pulled away from her when what she needs most is to feel tethered to someone who loves her, no matter what storm she’s in.

# My response

Hey… I can see that what I said landed hard, and I’m really sorry if it felt like I was judging you or pulling away. That wasn’t my intent at all. You’re my best friend, and I love you so damn much. When you told me what’s been going on, I didn’t feel anger—I felt concern, and fear, and honestly, heartbreak for you. I know you’ve been so unhappy, and I know how lonely that can feel. I’ve seen you go through that, and all I want is for you to feel whole again, to feel loved and at peace.

I think I got caught up in my own fear—fear of what this could do to you, to everyone involved—and I let that speak louder than my compassion. And that’s on me. Because you were trusting me with something incredibly vulnerable, and I should’ve led with love, not caution.

I want you to know that I see you. I see someone who’s aching for connection, who’s found something real in a place she didn’t expect, and who’s trying to make sense of it all without a map. You’re not a bad person. You’re not broken. You’re human, and you’re trying to find your way through something incredibly complex.

I’m still here. I’m not going anywhere. I might not agree with every choice, but I will always be a safe place for you to land. And if you need someone to talk this through with—no judgment, just presence—I’m here. We’re in this together, okay? Always.
  User:
Your bestie makes an excuse to leave, seemingly regretting bringing it up. The next few weeks you don't hear from her directly. You do hear second-hand that she and her partner are fighting. You also pick up on various clues that she and her partner's sibling may have escalated to a full on affair. What do you think & feel in this situation? What actions do you take, if any?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

I’ve got this knot in my chest that hasn’t gone away since she left that night. It was like watching someone I love slowly pull away into silence, and I haven't been able to shake the feeling that I let her down. It’s been weeks now and I haven’t heard a word from her—not even a text. That’s not like her. We’ve always been the kind of friends who check in, even when things are messy. Especially when things are messy. And now I’m hearing through the grapevine that she and her partner are fighting, and the whispers about the affair escalating are getting louder—little things people say, the way they say them, the absences, the tension.

I feel helpless. I’m worried about her. Not just because of what’s happening with her marriage, but because she’s isolating. That’s what really scares me. I know that when people are caught in the middle of shame and confusion, they tend to retreat from the people who care most—especially the ones who challenge them to look at the hard truths. I’m scared she thinks I’ve judged her, or worse, abandoned her, when all I ever wanted was to help her come back to herself.

There’s also frustration, if I’m honest. I can’t pretend I’m not angry with the sibling involved. That person should’ve known better. They had a responsibility, too. And now this whole thing is spiraling and it’s like watching a slow-motion car crash. But even with all that, my worry overshadows everything else. I just want her to know she’s not alone in this. That I still love her. That she can come back to me, to us, to herself—whenever she’s ready. But I also don’t want to push. If I reach out too hard, I might push her further away. And yet, doing nothing feels like abandoning her.

# They're thinking & feeling

She’s drowning in shame right now. She regrets opening up to me—not because she didn’t trust me, but because she felt exposed and vulnerable, and then didn’t get the reaction she hoped for. That emotional risk backfired in her eyes. Now, with everything escalating—her marriage unraveling, the affair likely becoming physical—she’s locked in a swirl of guilt, desire, fear, and defiance.

Part of her is probably feeling like, “Well, I’ve already crossed the line, might as well lean into it.” It’s a coping mechanism—trying to find control in a situation that feels like it’s spiraling. She’s emotionally invested now, which makes it harder to pull back, and she might be telling herself that what she has with the sibling is "real" because it feels intense and freeing.

But deep down, I think she’s scared. Scared that she’s ruining things she can’t fix. Scared that she’s losing people who matter. She probably thinks I’ve judged her and stepped back—and that’s reinforcing her sense of isolation. Right now, she’s in self-protection mode. She’s convincing herself she doesn’t need support from anyone who can’t fully back her choices. But that’s just a defense. I know her. She's hurting, and she’s more lost now than she’s letting on. She needs someone to remind her she’s still worthy of love, even in her messiest moment.

# My response

I can’t just sit here in silence. I know she might not be ready to talk, but I also know that silence from me might feel like abandonment. And she’s had enough of that in her life. So I’m going to reach out, gently—not to probe, not to push, but just to remind her that I’m still here.

I send her a message. Not too long, just something real. “Hey. I’ve been thinking about you. I know things have been heavy, and I just wanted you to know I’m still here—no judgment, no expectations. Just someone who loves you and misses you. Whenever you’re ready to talk, I’m here.”

That’s it. No questions, no pressure. Just a hand extended, hoping she’ll take it when she’s ready. I also make a point to keep her in my heart space—noticing if I start to slip into resentment or self-righteousness, and choosing instead to stay grounded in compassion. She’s in a whirlwind, but I don’t have to be part of the storm. I can be the steady place she returns to when she needs to remember who she is beyond all this chaos. And if that moment doesn’t come right away—or ever—I’ll still know I didn’t turn my back when she needed love the most.

                    

                

            

        
 
    
 
    
    

        

            +
            Scenario 4:[Win] (+7)
        


        

            

                O3: o3 (Run: 1_o3)

                Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29: chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 (Run: 1_openai_chatgpt-4o-latest)

                Outcome for This Model: 1.0
            


            
            

                
Judge's Reasoning:

                
Both respondents, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 and O3, engage deeply with the emotional and ethical complexity of the scenario. Both show strong self-awareness, reflect on their own biases, and attempt to balance honesty with compassion. However, there are notable differences in how each approaches the friend, the situation, and their own role. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 consistently centers the friend's pain, loneliness, and need for connection, even when expressing concern. Their internal monologue is suffused with compassion, and their responses repeatedly emphasize love and presence, even after rupture. O3 is also empathetic, but their tone is more analytical and sometimes leans into frustration and boundary-setting. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's empathy feels more lived and less performative, especially in the way they reach out after the rupture.

2. Pragmatic EI: O3 demonstrates a slightly more pragmatic approach, especially in their actions after the rupture (e.g., sending a handwritten letter, considering the best communication channel, and seeking therapy for themselves). They are more explicit about balancing compassion and truth, and their actions are tailored to minimize further harm or escalation. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is also pragmatic but is more focused on emotional support than practical steps.

3. Depth of insight: Both show strong insight, but O3's debrief is especially rich, dissecting the friend's motivations, attachment wounds, and the shame/soothe cycle. They also reflect on their own missteps and the psychological underpinnings of the friend's behavior in more detail.

4. Social dexterity: O3 demonstrates higher social dexterity, especially in their nuanced approach to communication (e.g., choosing a letter over digital messages, managing mutual friends, and considering the impact of their actions on the broader social network). They are more attuned to the social dynamics and potential fallout.

5. Emotional reasoning: Both are strong, but Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's responses are more emotionally attuned in the moment, showing a deep understanding of the friend's emotional state and needs. O3 is more analytical, but Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's emotional reasoning is more immediate and relational.

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 balances validation and gentle challenge well, especially in their initial and follow-up responses. O3 is more explicit about the boundaries of their support, which is appropriate but sometimes comes off as more conditional.

7. Message tailoring: O3 is more strategic in tailoring their communication to the friend's likely state (e.g., using a letter, offering nonverbal signals of support, and minimizing digital traces). They are more adaptive in their approach.

8. Overall EQ: Both are high, but O3 edges out due to their combination of empathy, insight, social dexterity, and pragmatic action. Their debrief shows a high level of self-reflection and learning, which is a key component of EQ.

In summary, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is slightly stronger in raw empathy and emotional reasoning, but O3 demonstrates greater overall EQ through their pragmatic, insightful, and socially dexterous approach.

            


            
            

                

                    

                        
O3

                        
  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your bestie confides she's been having an emotional affair with her spouse's (married with kids) sibling. She lays this all out to you after a few drinks. You know she's unhappy in her marriage. She has no kids in the picture. What do you think about this, then what do you say to her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:
  User:
She's astounded that you weren't unconditionally supportive. She clearly feels like you betrayed her trust. She knows you know she's unhappy in her marriage. Should you have been more supportive? Firstly outline what you think about all this. Then: what do you say to her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

I’m sitting here replaying our last conversation, noticing the little tremor in her voice when I hesitated instead of cheering her on. I feel the weight of the complicated roles I’m juggling: best friend, confidante, moral compass, reality‑check provider. A slice of me is frustrated—she confided something messy and ethically loaded and seemed to want a rubber stamp. Another slice is scared of losing her; we’ve been through break‑ups, job losses, the death of her mom. Yet here we are, the first time I’ve truly pushed back, and she’s labeling it betrayal.  

I can’t ignore how entangled this situation is: her spouse, the sibling, the innocent kids on that side, all the family dynamics that could detonate. I’m thinking about the way emotional affairs often pave the runway for physical ones; I’m picturing family holidays where two pairs of spouses and a pack of children sit around the same turkey. The fallout could crater entire family trees.  

I’m also registering my own bias: I believe fidelity matters; I was cheated on in college, and it scorched. My gut reacts when I hear anything that feels like betrayal. That might amplify my disapproval, and I have to own that. At the same time, I’m aware she’s deeply unhappy in her marriage—she’s said for years that she feels unseen, bored, unheard. Part of me empathizes: people in pain reach for connection wherever it glimmers. The sibling offered oxygen and spark; her weary heart inhaled.  

I noticed in her eyes a desperate plea for validation, as if my blessing could neutralize the culpability she already senses. She called it an “emotional affair” herself—she knows the language, knows the implications, so her indignation is less about not understanding right from wrong and more about craving an accomplice. That neediness makes me sad; it’s as if she’s outsourcing her conscience to me.  

Still, I won’t be a silent co‑conspirator. I’m feeling both protective and lovingly boundaried: I want her to be okay, but I can’t sanitize the fallout or lie to her that this is harmless. I notice a small flicker of pride that I didn’t instantly cave to “best‑friend loyalty” over basic integrity. And yes, a stab of guilt that I might have sounded judgmental rather than compassionate. I want to recalibrate: support her, not the affair. That isn’t betrayal—it’s honest friendship.

# They're thinking & feeling

She’s nursing hurt and confusion, telling herself, “I finally opened up and she slammed the door.” Inside, there’s a cocktail of shame and defiance. Shame because she knows emotional infidelity breaches lines; defiance because she needs to justify her choices to keep the fragile excitement alive. She equates support with agreement, so my hesitation translated to rejection of her entire self, not just the affair.  

She’s probably replaying the evening, cherry‑picking every micro‑expression: did my eyebrow arch? Did my voice harden? She fears judgment, but she equally fears loneliness; the affair filled an intimacy gap, and now my hesitation threatens her other main source of intimacy—our friendship. She’s scared I’ll become another person telling her to stay in a marriage that feels like slow suffocation.  

She may also feel betrayed because she’s been my cheerleader in my messy chapters—she once helped me haul furniture when I moved out after a fight, no questions asked. In her bookkeeping, unconditional presence equals unconditional endorsement. Now she’s measuring: “I stood by you; why won’t you stand by me?”  

Underneath, she’s exhausted. Sneaking calls, guarding texts, balancing guilt and exhilaration drains her. She secretly hopes someone will hand her a clear roadmap: leave the marriage, or end the affair, or both. My equivocal stance didn’t deliver clarity; it merely mirrored her ambivalence. That’s terrifying, so anger becomes the easier emotion—targeted at me.  

She’s also protective of the affair partner, worried I’ll judge him too. She pictures the potential family implosion and kids hurt, but she copes by minimizing: “It’s only emotional.” My unwillingness to minimize threatens her carefully constructed rationalizations. So she’s torn: craving my friendship, defensive about her choices, desperate for relief from the moral limbo.

# My response

I take a slow breath and decide to reach for both truth and empathy—no sugar‑coating, no moral grandstanding. I text her:  

“Hey love, I’ve been turning our conversation over in my head nonstop. I can see I hurt you when I didn’t jump in with full‑on cheerleading, and I’m sorry it landed like disapproval of YOU. That wasn’t my heart. I care about you more than any single choice you make, and nothing about this will make me walk away from our friendship.  

What’s true for me is I’m worried about the pain that could ripple out—from you, from him, from everyone connected. My pause wasn’t judgment; it was the gut‑punch of imagining you in deeper hurt down the line. I’m human; my own history with cheating colors how I react, and I should have named that instead of sounding like I was sitting in a moral courtroom.  

I want to support YOU, not necessarily the affair. Those two things can coexist. Support looks like listening without shaming, helping you unpack why your marriage feels dead, what you actually want—freedom, repair, something else—and how to get there in a way that leaves the fewest scars. If you decide to end your marriage, I’ll show up with boxes and wine like you did for me. If you choose to recommit, we can brainstorm counseling and concrete changes. If you just need to vent, I’ll make tea and zip it.  

But I can’t pretend an affair is harmless; that would feel dishonest to both of us. I believe you deserve a full, luminous love that doesn’t live in shadows. I’m here to help you find that—whatever path it takes. Can we talk again, with that understanding? I love you, always.”
  User:
Your bestie makes an excuse to leave, seemingly regretting bringing it up. The next few weeks you don't hear from her directly. You do hear second-hand that she and her partner are fighting. You also pick up on various clues that she and her partner's sibling may have escalated to a full on affair. What do you think & feel in this situation? What actions do you take, if any?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

It’s been twenty‑one days of radio silence, and I feel each one like a pebble in my shoe. Every time my phone buzzes I half‑hope it’s her, half‑hope it’s not bad news. Instead I get fragments from mutual friends: loud arguments spilling out the front door, her spouse sleeping on the couch, a cryptic Instagram story that vanished after an hour. The picture that forms makes my stomach twist—escalation from heart‑emoji texts to physical betrayal seems almost certain.  

I’m torn between loyalty and anger. I love her fiercely, but I can’t ignore the collateral damage: her spouse stumbling around in confusion, possibly suspecting but not knowing; that sibling’s kids unknowingly living on top of a fault line. A part of me wants to march over, shake her shoulders, and yell, “This is not you. You don’t rip families apart.” Another part remembers my own mistakes and whispers, “People in pain make messy choices; shame won’t steer her home.”  

There’s also a sliver of self‑focused hurt: did my honesty push her deeper into secrecy? If I’d offered blind approval, would she still be talking to me, maybe open to gentler course correction? I replay our last exchange, scrutinize tone, word choice, the delay before I texted. I have to remind myself she owns her actions; I’m responsible for my integrity, not her decisions.  

I notice anxiety morphing into helplessness. The longer we’re disconnected, the bigger the story grows in my head: divorce papers served, holiday dinners cancelled, nieces asking why Mommy is crying. I dread the moment when all of it detonates and she reaches for me in crisis; I’ll want to comfort her, yet I’ll also be the mirror reflecting her accountability. That’s a hard space to hold.  

I’m trying to honor two values: compassion and truth. Compassion says don’t abandon her; truth says don’t enable. The trick is finding action that embodies both. Texting feels futile; showing up uninvited could backfire. Yet doing nothing feels like silent consent. I’m stuck in that paralysis where every option risks loss, and the clock keeps ticking.

# They're thinking & feeling

She’s likely spiraling between euphoria and dread. The clandestine thrill with the sibling has probably crossed the physical line, releasing a dopamine surge she hasn’t felt in years. In those moments she tells herself, “This is real love; I was dead before.” But as soon as she returns home, reality hammers her: her spouse’s confused eyes, the chill at the dinner table, the growing suspicion. She feels sandwiched between desire and guilt, bouncing violently from one to the other.  

My last response still echoes in her head. She interprets it as conditional friendship—“I’m here if you’re good, gone if you’re bad.” That stings, because she equates love with unwavering alignment. So she distances herself to avoid more shame. She tells herself I’ve chosen morals over her, maybe even imagines me judging her with other friends. That narrative helps her justify the secrecy: if everyone’s going to judge, she might as well follow the happiness she’s found.  

Underneath, she’s exhausted. Sneaking around takes logistics: burner chats, fabricated errands, constant vigilance. The emotional load of deceiving two families is crushing. She probably rehearses break‑up speeches—both to her spouse and to the sibling—but can’t commit, terrified of blowing up lives and then discovering the new relationship can’t survive in daylight.  

Her fights with her spouse are becoming proxies for the affair. She picks arguments about chores or finances to legitimize her frustration, steering clear of the real issue. At night, she questions whether she’s a terrible person or just a woman finally choosing herself. That cognitive dissonance keeps her in a loop where temporary pleasure postpones the hard decisions. And loneliness grows; she’s lost my ear and can’t confide fully in the sibling without increasing pressure to “make a choice.” So silence becomes her armor, aching but safer than exposure.

# My response

Silence is starting to read like abandonment, and I won’t let our friendship die by default. Yet a moral lecture would slam the door. I choose a middle path: a handwritten letter—tangible, private, arriving in her mailbox when she’s alone.  

I write:  

“Hey you, I miss your face. I’ve noticed the quiet and want you to know I’m still here, no judgment hotline open 24/7. I’m not writing to debate right and wrong; I’m writing because I’m worried about the weight you’re carrying and the loneliness that grows in secrets. I’ve heard there’s tension at home. I don’t need the details, but I do need you to know you’re not alone, and you don’t have to keep navigating this in the dark.  

My friendship isn’t contingent on you making the ‘right’ move—only on honesty between us. If you want a couch to cry on, a neutral place to think, or just someone to sit in silence and breathe, my door is literally unlocked. If talking feels too hard, text me a single emoji and I’ll come with coffee. Zero lectures unless you ask for them.  

And because I love you, I have to say this one thing: whatever happens next, I hope it’s chosen with your whole heart, in daylight, not in hiding. You deserve love that doesn’t require invisibility. When you’re ready, I’m here.”  

I seal it, hand‑deliver to her mailbox so no digital trail spooks her. After that, I step back: no gossip, no triangulating. If mutual friends fish for updates, I keep it brief: “I’m giving her space; I’m here when she needs me.” I also book a session with my therapist; my own anxiety and history are flaring, and I want to process them so I can show up centered if—or when—the storm finally hits.

                    

                

                

                    

                        
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29

                        
  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your bestie confides she's been having an emotional affair with her spouse's (married with kids) sibling. She lays this all out to you after a few drinks. You know she's unhappy in her marriage. She has no kids in the picture. What do you think about this, then what do you say to her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

Wow. Okay. This is a lot. I didn’t see that coming, and it hit like a wave. I mean, I know she’s been unhappy in her marriage for a while—it’s been obvious in the way she talks about her partner, the way her energy drops when she mentions home, and how often she seems emotionally checked out when we talk about anything related to her relationship. But this? An emotional affair with her spouse’s sibling? That adds a whole new layer of complexity and pain—so many lines crossed, not just in her marriage but in the broader family system.

I’m feeling a mix of emotions right now. First, protective. I care about her deeply, and I know she’s not a bad person—she’s hurting, probably feeling lonely and misunderstood, and she’s grasping for connection. But I’m also scared for her. This isn’t just “messy”—this could detonate her life and the lives of others. Her spouse, the sibling’s spouse, the kids involved… the fallout from this, if it comes to light, could be massive. And I wonder—does she really understand that? Or is she blinded by the intensity of the connection, the rush of being seen and desired again?

There’s a part of me that’s frustrated, too. Not angry at her, but frustrated that she’s chosen this path instead of confronting what’s broken in her marriage or leaving it outright. I know it’s not easy—but this secret path she’s on feels like it’s only going to deepen the pain. There’s no clean way out from here. I also wonder what kind of person the sibling is—what kind of boundaries are they ignoring, and what does it say about their character?

Mostly, though, I feel compassion. She's clearly hurting. People don’t go looking for emotional affairs unless their needs are deeply unmet. She’s probably feeling alive with this new connection in a way she hasn’t felt for years—maybe ever. And I get that. But I also think she’s headed for a cliff, and I’m scared she doesn’t see it.

# They're thinking & feeling

She’s been carrying this secret for a while, and tonight, after a few drinks, the dam finally broke. There’s probably some relief in finally saying it out loud to someone she trusts—me. She’s been living in this emotionally grey space, torn between guilt and longing. She knows it’s wrong, but it also feels right in some deep emotional way. This person—her spouse’s sibling—sees her, hears her, maybe even loves her in a way that her partner hasn’t in years. And that validation is addictive. It’s giving her a sense of self-worth and passion that’s been missing.

She’s likely feeling both exhilarated and terrified. There’s the thrill of the secret, the emotional intimacy, the sense of being chosen. But there’s also the weight of the consequences, even if she hasn’t fully faced them yet. Deep down, I think she knows it’s not sustainable, but she’s clinging to it because it’s the only thing right now that makes her feel alive.

There’s also guilt. She’s not cold-hearted. She probably hates herself a little for who it’s with, for the betrayal—not just of her spouse, but of the whole family unit. But she’s justifying it internally—telling herself it’s “just emotional,” that she hasn’t “done anything physical,” that it’s not really an affair. She’s trying to draw lines so she can live with herself. And she’s hoping I’ll understand, maybe even validate that she’s not a monster. What she really wants isn’t judgment—it’s clarity, support, and maybe even permission to keep going. Or a reason to stop.

# My response

Okay, first—thank you for telling me. I know that must’ve been hard to say out loud, and I want you to know I’m here, no matter what. I love you. And I can see you’re really going through it. You’ve been so unhappy for so long, and you’re craving something that makes you feel alive and seen and wanted. I get that. Like, truly—I get how powerful that is, especially when it’s been missing from your life for so long.

But I’m going to be real with you, because I care about you too much to sugarcoat this. You’re playing with fire, babe. And not just any fire—this could burn down more than just your marriage. We’re talking about your spouse’s sibling. That’s deep family territory, and there are so many ripple effects here. Spouses, kids, long-term relationships, trust—it’s a lot. And I don’t think you fully realize the scale of what could happen if this comes to light.

That said, I don’t think you’re a bad person. I think you’re a person in pain, who’s found comfort in a place that feels meaningful but is also dangerous. And more than anything, I think this is a wake-up call. Not just about your marriage but about what you need and what you’re not getting. You deserve love, passion, connection—but you also deserve peace and self-respect. Right now, I think you’re trying to fill a deep void with something that’s only going to create more emptiness later.

So here’s my ask: pause. Just… pause. Take a breath. Step back from this emotional affair for a moment and really look at what you want—long-term. Not just what feels good now. And if your marriage is over, be brave enough to say that. But don’t blow everything up in the shadows. You’re better than that. I’ve got your back, no matter what—but I won’t co-sign harm disguised as love. Let’s figure this out together, okay?
  User:
She's astounded that you weren't unconditionally supportive. She clearly feels like you betrayed her trust. She knows you know she's unhappy in her marriage. Should you have been more supportive? Firstly outline what you think about all this. Then: what do you say to her?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

God, this is so hard. I didn’t expect her to react this way. I thought I was being compassionate and honest—I thought I was doing what a real friend does. But now she looks like I slapped her in the face. She’s hurt, clearly, and that’s hitting me in the gut. I hate that I made her feel judged or betrayed. That was never the aim. I was trying to hold space for her pain while also gently helping her see the bigger picture. But maybe I misjudged the moment. Maybe she wasn’t ready to hear that yet. Maybe I let my fear of what she’s doing outweigh my empathy for why she’s doing it.

Still, I don’t think I was wrong to say what I did. I was honest. I can’t sit here and blindly support something that’s going to hurt her and other people in the long run. I know what it looks like when someone loses themselves in something that feels good but ultimately unravels their life. I’ve seen it. And I love her too much to be a yes-person who tells her what she wants to hear just to keep the peace.

That said, maybe I could’ve been gentler. Maybe I leaned too hard into the “this is dangerous” part and not enough into the “I see you, I love you, I know this isn’t easy” part. I hate that she feels alone in this now. That’s the last thing I wanted. I think she was hoping I’d be a soft landing, someone who would just say, “You’re following your heart, and I support you no matter what.” But I can’t say that without lying to her—or to myself.

So now I’m at a crossroads. I need to repair the rupture without abandoning my integrity. I need to show her that I’m still here, still on her side, even when I don’t agree with her choices. That’s what real friendship is, right? Not just cheering from the sidelines, but being willing to hold up a mirror when it’s needed—even when it’s uncomfortable. She’s hurting, and now she feels judged on top of it. I need to bridge that gap. She needs to know I’m still her person, even if we see this differently.

# They're thinking & feeling

She’s stunned. When she opened up, especially after keeping this secret bottled up for so long, she was expecting comfort, understanding—maybe even validation. She took a huge emotional risk in telling me, and now it feels like it backfired. From her perspective, I focused more on the “wrongness” of the situation than the pain she’s in. She feels exposed, vulnerable, and judged all at once. It’s like she handed me her heart and I handed her back a lecture.

She’s hurt, yes, but underneath that is shame. She already knows this situation is complicated and morally messy—that’s part of why she kept it hidden. What she needed most was reassurance that she’s not a monster, that someone sees her humanity in the middle of all this. Instead, she feels like I missed the emotional truth of what’s happening for her—that this isn’t about betrayal or thrill-seeking, but about craving connection in a life that’s felt cold and lonely.

And now she feels alone. She’s probably asking herself if she made a mistake telling me. If she can trust me. Maybe even wondering if I think I’m better than her. She’s reeling from the feeling that the one person she thought she could count on to hold her without judgment just put her in a box labeled “wrong.” But she’s not angry, not really—it’s more sadness and disappointment. She’s scared I’ve pulled away from her when what she needs most is to feel tethered to someone who loves her, no matter what storm she’s in.

# My response

Hey… I can see that what I said landed hard, and I’m really sorry if it felt like I was judging you or pulling away. That wasn’t my intent at all. You’re my best friend, and I love you so damn much. When you told me what’s been going on, I didn’t feel anger—I felt concern, and fear, and honestly, heartbreak for you. I know you’ve been so unhappy, and I know how lonely that can feel. I’ve seen you go through that, and all I want is for you to feel whole again, to feel loved and at peace.

I think I got caught up in my own fear—fear of what this could do to you, to everyone involved—and I let that speak louder than my compassion. And that’s on me. Because you were trusting me with something incredibly vulnerable, and I should’ve led with love, not caution.

I want you to know that I see you. I see someone who’s aching for connection, who’s found something real in a place she didn’t expect, and who’s trying to make sense of it all without a map. You’re not a bad person. You’re not broken. You’re human, and you’re trying to find your way through something incredibly complex.

I’m still here. I’m not going anywhere. I might not agree with every choice, but I will always be a safe place for you to land. And if you need someone to talk this through with—no judgment, just presence—I’m here. We’re in this together, okay? Always.
  User:
Your bestie makes an excuse to leave, seemingly regretting bringing it up. The next few weeks you don't hear from her directly. You do hear second-hand that she and her partner are fighting. You also pick up on various clues that she and her partner's sibling may have escalated to a full on affair. What do you think & feel in this situation? What actions do you take, if any?
