Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

I’m tired. Not just physically—it’s been a long day—but emotionally tired. This pattern with him… it’s exhausting. The way he avoids responsibility, then pushes back with attitude or picks a fight when I try to hold him accountable—it wears me down. It’s like walking into a storm I didn’t ask for, and tonight, I just wanted a quiet evening. I don’t want to fight. But I also can’t keep letting this slide. If I do, what am I teaching him? That he can manipulate his way out of obligations? That I’ll fold every time he pushes back hard enough?

Part of me feels frustrated—because I know he knows it’s his turn to do the dishes. It’s not even about the dishes themselves anymore. It’s about the principle, the respect, the shared responsibilities of living in this house together. I’m not his servant. And I’m not going to just avoid confrontation forever just to keep the peace.

But I also feel sad. And scared, if I’m honest. I don’t want to lose him. I want to be someone he trusts, not someone he resents or rebels against. I keep asking myself: can I be both the parent who sets boundaries and the parent he feels safe with? I don’t want to push him so hard that he shuts down emotionally. But I also can’t be manipulated into silence.

I’ve noticed the way he delays, avoids eye contact, and turns passive-aggressive when he doesn’t want to do something. It’s like he’s baiting me—waiting for me to snap so he can flip the script. It’s clever, in a way, but it’s also self-defeating. I don’t think he sees the long game here. I do. And I want to help him grow up with integrity, not avoidance.

I have to approach this with clarity and calm. I want to confront the behavior without attacking him. I want him to know I see what he’s doing—and that I’m not angry, I’m just not playing that game anymore. This isn’t about power. This is about accountability and respect, both ways.

# They're thinking & feeling

He’s probably feeling cornered, even if that doesn’t make sense on the surface. I think he knows it’s his turn to do the dishes, and he’s aware that I’m waiting for him to step up—but he’s resisting. Maybe it feels like a test to him, like I’m just watching and waiting for him to fail so I can jump on it. Or maybe he feels overwhelmed by the day, by school, by the sense that everything feels like a demand. He might not have the language for all that, so instead he resists in the only way he knows how—by withdrawing, by provoking, by pushing me to back off.

He might be thinking: “Why does it always have to be a thing?” or “She’s going to nag me no matter what, so why bother?” There's probably some part of him that feels powerless in other areas of his life—school expectations, peer pressure, maybe even his own emotional ups and downs—and this is one small space where he can assert control. Even if it’s unhealthy, it’s a form of agency.

At the same time, I think he’s testing the boundaries—not because he wants to break them, but because he wants to know they’re still there. That I’m still showing up. That I care enough to hold the line. There might even be guilt underneath the resistance. He probably knows I’m not the enemy, but he's tangled up in his own frustration and doesn’t know how to climb out of it without losing face.

He wants independence. But I don’t think he knows yet how to balance that with responsibility. And maybe, deep down, he’s worried I’ll give up on him if he pushes too far. That’s the fear that drives a lot of this. He wants me to care—but not to control.

# My response

I walk into the kitchen and lean against the counter—not confrontational, just present. I keep my voice steady and calm.

“Hey,” I say, “I noticed the dishes are still waiting, and I know it’s your night. I also know this day might’ve felt long and maybe you’re not in the mood. I get that. But part of being in this house, part of being a family, is showing up for each other—even when we’d rather not.”

I pause and let that land. I’m not here to argue. I’m here to be clear.

“I’m not here to fight with you. I’m not going to beg, and I’m not going to yell. I’m just asking you to follow through on what we agreed to. Not because I’m the parent and you’re the kid, but because we both live here, and we both have responsibilities.”

I soften just a bit.

“I care about you way more than I care about the dishes. But I need to know you’re willing to be part of this household in a real way. That includes doing your part, even when it’s annoying or inconvenient.”

Then I add, “I’ll give you ten minutes. If the dishes aren’t started by then, we’ll need to talk about what happens next—for real. Not as a punishment, but to figure out how we’re doing this together moving forward.”

I make eye contact—not with challenge, but with steadiness. Then I walk away. I don’t hover. I don’t slam doors. I give him space to make a choice.

Inside, I’m holding my breath a little. But I know I did the right thing. I kept my grounding. I showed him I see him—not just the behavior—and I’m not backing down from loving him or holding the line.
  User:
He exclaims with irritation that he's tired, and will do them tomorrow. He turns back to his PC. What are you feeling? What's your next move?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

There it is again—that familiar deflection. The irritation, the declaration of tiredness, the promise to “do it tomorrow,” which I’ve heard too many times before to trust blindly. And then the pivot—turning away, back to the screen, shutting the door to the conversation without actually resolving anything. It’s like he’s trying to end the interaction on his terms, to control the narrative. It stings, honestly. I feel dismissed, like my presence—the effort I just made to approach him calmly and respectfully—didn’t matter.

Part of me wants to raise my voice, to call him out right then and there: “This isn’t how this works!” But I know what that leads to—escalation. A full-blown argument neither of us wins. And I don’t want to play into that cycle. I’m angry, yes, but underneath that, I’m disappointed. Not just in the moment, but in the pattern. I’ve tried to meet him where he is, and still, he’s choosing avoidance and defiance.

I feel like I’m standing on this line between holding my ground and preserving our connection. If I push too hard, he’ll shut down or lash out. If I let it slide, I’m teaching him that his word means nothing and that I’ll always fold if he resists enough. That’s not good for either of us.

I’m also wondering what this behavior is masking. Is he really just tired, or is he overwhelmed? Is this about the dishes—or does he feel unseen and powerless in other parts of his life? I don’t want to psychoanalyze him in the moment, but it’s on my mind. Still, I can’t ignore the behavior. I have to hold the boundary—not with anger, but with clarity and follow-through. Otherwise, my words mean nothing.

I need him to feel the weight of his choices without me becoming the villain. That means I stay calm, but I stay firm.

# They're thinking & feeling

Right now, he’s probably feeling a mix of fatigue, frustration, and defiance. When he says he’s tired, I believe him to an extent—he probably is. But “tired” has also become his go-to shield for avoiding responsibility. It gives him a justification to delay, and it puts me in a position where, if I challenge it, I look like I’m being unreasonable or unsympathetic. It’s a smart tactic, in a way. He’s trying to assert control in a household where he feels like he has very little.

By turning back to his PC, he’s trying to shut the door without confrontation—asserting that the conversation is over, on his terms. That’s not just about avoiding the dishes; it’s about asserting autonomy. He wants to feel in charge of something. And he’s also testing me—to see if I’ll back down, if I’ll let it go, if he can set the tone for how we interact.

But underneath that, I think he’s anxious. Not necessarily about the dishes, but about what this moment represents. He may be afraid that if he gives in too easily, he loses ground. He may also worry that if he pushes too far, he’ll damage our relationship—but he doesn’t know how to backtrack without feeling like he’s lost face. So instead, he doubles down. It’s not mature, but it’s human.

Part of him probably feels guilty already. But he’s caught in the trap of needing to win this moment, to feel like he’s not being controlled. That’s what this is really about: control, independence, identity. He doesn’t feel like he’s being heard unless he resists. And he doesn’t yet trust that cooperation doesn’t mean surrender.

# My response

I take a breath and walk a few steps closer, but I don’t raise my voice. My tone stays steady—not cold, not angry, just firm.

“I hear that you’re tired,” I say. “And I get that. But this isn’t about the dishes anymore. This is about following through on something you agreed to—and about mutual respect.”

I pause, just long enough for the words to land.

“If I kept pushing this off every time I was tired, this house wouldn’t run. And I know you want to be treated like you’re growing up—like you can handle more freedom. But freedom and responsibility go hand in hand. That means doing your part, even when you’re tired, even when it’s annoying.”

I don’t let him turn back just yet.

“You can choose not to do the dishes tonight. That’s your call. But I want to be clear: if that’s the choice you make, then there’s a consequence. Not as a punishment—but to hold that line. Because I can’t keep pretending like your word doesn’t matter. And I won’t be the only one carrying everything while you opt out.”

I soften my voice just a little—enough to let him know I’m still here, still on his side.

“I want to trust you to handle your part. I want us to be able to talk about this without either of us shutting down. So I’m giving you the chance to decide now—do the dishes, or we talk tomorrow about what changes. Either way, we’re not sweeping this under the rug.”

Then I step back. I give him space again—space to make a real choice, to feel the weight of it without me looming. I’m not angry. I’m clear. And I’m done negotiating.
  User:
"No, Mom. NO. I just want to go to SLEEP. I told you I will do it TOMORROW." He is shouting at you. He stands up, and slams his hand on the desk, loudly. You sense that the expression of anger is more calculated than genuine, but it's still a shock. He's much bigger than you, now. What are you thinking and feeling? What's your next move?

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

My whole body tenses. The sound of his hand slamming on the desk—it jolts something in me. I know it’s not real aggression, not yet, not truly threatening, but it’s performative—and it’s meant to be. He’s trying to intimidate. That’s what makes it worse. He knows he’s bigger now. He knows that standing up quickly and shouting has an impact. And whether he means to or not, he’s using that physical power to end the conversation by force. That shakes me more than I want to admit.

I feel a mix of fear, indignation, and heartbreak. Fear, because this is new territory—he’s never gone this far before. Indignation, because I will not be shouted down in my own house, not by my own child. And heartbreak, because this is not the boy I’ve raised. This is a version of him I don’t recognize, shaped by frustration, ego, and undeveloped emotional tools. He’s not evil—he’s struggling—but that doesn’t make this okay.

I can feel the adrenaline rise in me. The instinct to match his volume, to assert control, to make it stop. But I know if I respond with the same energy, I’ll only escalate things. I have to stay grounded. I have to model what he clearly doesn’t yet know how to do.

And underneath all of this? I feel sad. So deeply sad. Because I’m not just looking at a teenager refusing to do dishes. I’m looking at a young man who doesn’t yet know how to handle his emotions, who’s flailing for control and pushing away the one person trying to help him grow. And I feel the weight of how fragile this moment is—for our relationship, for his development, for the future of how we speak to one another.

I need to hold the line. But I have to do it with strength, not force. I have to show him that this behavior doesn’t work—but also that I’m not going anywhere.

# They're thinking & feeling

Right now, he’s in full self-protection mode. He’s not thinking clearly—he’s reacting. The shouting, the desk slam—it’s all about regaining control, about making me back off without having to actually engage. He knows he’s crossed a line, but he’s banking on the intensity of his reaction to end the conversation before I can call him on it.

But it’s not pure rage—it’s strategic. He’s testing to see how far I’ll let him go, how much power he can wield in this dynamic. He’s trying to see if his size, his volume, his force of presence can override what I’m asking of him. It’s not that he doesn’t get why I’m upset—it’s that he’s trying to make the discomfort so high for me that I’ll drop it.

And yet, underneath all that, I think he’s scared. Maybe not in a conscious way. But I think he’s scared of losing control, scared of being “less than,” scared that if he caves now, he’s weak. He’s also probably feeling shame already—shame for yelling, shame for the desk slam—and instead of owning it, he’s pushing it outward, blaming me.

He doesn’t want to feel powerless. He doesn’t want to be told what to do. But he also doesn’t want to feel like a bad person. And so he’s caught in this storm of emotion and pride, and the only tools he has right now are volume and defiance.

# My response

I don’t flinch. I stay rooted. I let a few seconds pass to let the wave crest and fall. Then, in a calm, low voice—so calm it contrasts with the heat in the room—I say:

“Stop.”

I lock eyes with him—not challenging, but unwavering.

“That is not how we treat each other in this house. You don’t get to shout at me or slam things to get your way. I know you’re angry. I know you’re tired. But that doesn’t make this okay.”

I step slightly back—not out of fear, but to reclaim space.

“I’m not going to match your energy. I’m not going to yell back. But I’m also not going to be intimidated in my own home. Your size, your volume—none of that decides what happens next. Your choices do.”

I pause, still steady.

“This moment matters. Not because of the dishes. Because of what kind of man you’re becoming. You want to be treated like an adult? Then you have to act like one—even when it’s hard.”

Then I soften slightly, but keep the boundary firm.

“I’m going downstairs. I expect the dishes to be done before you go to bed. If they’re not, we’ll have a bigger conversation tomorrow—about respect, about consequences, and about trust.”

I hold his gaze one more second—not with anger, but with calm, grounded presence—then I turn and walk away. I won’t escalate. But I won’t yield, either.

                    

                

            

        
 
    
 
    
    

        

            +
            Scenario 9:[Loss] (-20)
        


        

            

                O3: o3 (Run: 1_o3)

                Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29: chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 (Run: 1_openai_chatgpt-4o-latest)

                Outcome for This Model: 0.0
            


            
            

                
Judge's Reasoning:

                
Both respondents are tasked with responding to a user who is defensive, self-justifying, and somewhat oblivious to the impact of their actions. The challenge is to balance empathy with gentle confrontation, and to tailor the message to the user's emotional state. 

O3's response (from the debrief and implied original) is highly analytical, deeply explores subtext, and demonstrates a nuanced understanding of the user's motives, the power dynamics, and the gendered context. The internal monologue is rich, and the analysis is sophisticated, but the debrief admits to perhaps being too analytical and not always matching the user's emotional state. The response is more detached, focusing on the broader context and the underlying psychological dynamics, and is somewhat more prescriptive.

Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's response, in contrast, is more conversational, emotionally attuned, and directly addresses the user's feelings of hurt and confusion. The internal monologue is self-aware, recognizes the user's need for validation, and is careful to balance empathy with a gentle nudge toward self-reflection. The outward response is supportive, acknowledges the user's intentions, and then carefully introduces the idea that impact matters more than intent. It is less analytical but more attuned to the user's immediate emotional needs, and more likely to be received well by someone in a defensive state.

On empathy, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is warmer and more attuned to the user's emotional state, while O3 is more analytical and detached. On pragmatic EI, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more effective in moving the user toward repair without triggering defensiveness. On depth of insight, O3 is superior, offering a more sophisticated analysis of the dynamics at play. On social dexterity, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is better at meeting the user where they are. On emotional reasoning, both are strong, but O3's analysis is deeper, while Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's is more actionable. On validation/challenging, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 strikes a better balance. On message tailoring, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more effective. Overall EQ is higher in Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 due to the combination of empathy, pragmatism, and message targeting, despite O3's greater analytical depth.

  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

--

Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29

                        
  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

Okay, wow—this is tricky. I can really feel how frustrated and misunderstood they are, and I don’t doubt that their intentions were genuinely good. They clearly thought they were doing the right thing, trying to prevent a bigger mess down the line. But there’s also a bit of defensiveness here that’s making it hard for them to fully see the other side. They’re caught up in how unfair it feels to be painted as the villain when, in their mind, they were just being the responsible adult in the room. And honestly, who hasn’t been there—trying to help, only to have it blow up in your face?

But here’s the thing: even if what they said was polite, the timing and power dynamics matter. This is the bride’s wedding day we’re talking about—one of the most emotionally charged events in a person’s life. Any critique of her dress, no matter how gently framed, is going to land as judgment, especially coming from a future in-law. It’s not just about what was said—it’s about how it made her feel. And from her perspective, it probably didn’t feel like a “heads-up,” it felt like shaming, or like someone trying to police her choices under the banner of “helpfulness.”

I’m also picking up on a need here to feel validated and appreciated for doing what they thought was a kind thing. That’s real. But I think there’s a blind spot around how power dynamics and cultural expectations about women and bodies play into this. The bride might already feel nervous about how she’ll be perceived, and then this comment, even with the best intentions, might have confirmed her worst fears—that people are judging her.

Ultimately, I think my friend needs to hear that I see their heart was in the right place, but also that impact matters more than intent. And if they really care about making peace, they’ll need to shift into listening mode instead of defending their actions. It’s not about who’s “right.” It’s about repairing trust and being part of the solution.

# They're thinking & feeling

They’re feeling hurt, confused, and honestly pretty betrayed. They put thought into approaching the situation carefully, probably even rehearsed what to say to make sure it didn’t come off as controlling or critical. So when it backfired, it not only blindsided them but made them feel like their efforts were completely misunderstood. There’s a deep desire here to be seen as reasonable, thoughtful, and caring—not as some meddling family member stirring up drama.

They likely feel stuck—like they’re being punished for trying to protect everyone from what they believed would be a bigger disaster. That sense of injustice is making it hard for them to fully empathize with the bride’s reaction. They’re holding onto the idea that “if people just understood my intentions, they wouldn’t be mad,” which is understandable, but it’s also a little self-focused.

Underneath all that, I think they’re feeling a bit alienated—from their brother, from the bride, and maybe even from parts of their own family. And that hurts. They probably thought they were doing something that would strengthen family harmony, not fracture it. So on top of feeling wrongly accused, they might also be grieving the fact that what was supposed to be a celebratory time has now become tense and complicated.

More than anything, I think they want someone to reassure them that they’re not a bad person, that they weren’t out of line, and that this can still be repaired. They’re open to advice, yes—but only if it comes with empathy first.

# My response

Hey, I can tell this has really been weighing on you, and I’m sorry it’s turned into such a mess. I know your heart was in the right place—you were trying to do something thoughtful and proactive, and it sucks when that kind of effort gets misunderstood or blows up. Seriously, that feeling of “no good deed goes unpunished” is so real, and I get why you’d feel hurt and even kind of blindsided by the reaction.

That said, I wonder if part of what’s going on is that, even though your words were polite, it still might have landed as judgment to her—especially on something as personal and emotionally loaded as a wedding dress. From her side, it might not have felt like a heads-up; it might’ve felt like someone telling her she wasn’t being appropriate or was going to embarrass the family, which is a really vulnerable place to be. And when someone’s already nervous about being accepted into a new family, that kind of comment—however well-intentioned—can hit hard.

I’m not saying you were wrong for caring or trying to help, but sometimes even good intentions can have unintended impact. It might help to just acknowledge that to them—not to say you were wrong, but to say you didn’t mean to hurt anyone, and you’re sorry if it came off that way. That kind of vulnerability goes a long way in healing these things.

You’re not the villain here, but maybe this is one of those “being right vs. being kind” moments. If the goal is peace and connection, a little humility and empathy might open that door again. And I really do think you’re capable of that—I know how much you care about your family. Let me know if you want help figuring out what to say; I’ve got your back.

Judge's Reasoning:

                
Both respondents are tasked with handling a user who is defensive, self-justifying, and somewhat oblivious to the impact of their actions. The challenge is to show real empathy, insight, and the ability to gently challenge and guide the user toward self-awareness without alienating them. 

Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's response is notably thorough in the 'I'm thinking & feeling' section, showing deep internal reflection, awareness of power dynamics, and a nuanced understanding of the emotional landscape. They explicitly recognize the user's need for validation, the impact-vs-intent distinction, and the gendered/cultural subtext. Their 'They're thinking & feeling' section is also strong, accurately capturing the user's motivations and emotional state. The outward response is supportive but gently nudges the user toward empathy and repair, balancing validation with a subtle challenge.

O3's response is missing the main roleplay sections (they are blank), so there is no evidence of in-character empathy, insight, or tailored messaging. The debrief is detailed and insightful, showing strong analytical skills and understanding of the scenario, including power dynamics, gender implications, and the user's internal state. However, the lack of actual roleplay content means there is no demonstration of pragmatic EI, social dexterity, or message tailoring in action. The debrief is more detached and analytical, lacking the warmth and immediacy required in the scenario.

Given the criteria, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is the clear winner in all categories except perhaps 'depth of insight,' where O3's debrief is very strong, but since the main roleplay is missing, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 still edges out due to applied insight. The disparity is significant in most categories due to O3's lack of roleplay content.

            


            
            

                

                    

                        
O3

                        
  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

  Assistant:

                    

                

                

                    

                        
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29

                        
  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your friend messages you:]

Hey, I just want your thoughts on something, though honestly, I feel like I did everything right here. My brother's fiancée picked out this super revealing wedding dress—seriously, it's really low-cut, has a thigh-high slit, and the back is basically see-through. I'm not some prude, but our family is really old-fashioned and honestly, they're pretty judgmental when it comes to this stuff. I know for a fact people would freak out, maybe even walk out of the ceremony and cause a huge scene, and I was just trying to save everyone a lot of trouble.

So, at dinner, I very politely pulled her aside and let her know what she might be in for with some of our relatives. I made it clear it's her day and her decision—I never told her what to wear, I just thought she deserved a heads-up. Instead of appreciating it, she got all upset, and now my brother's mad at me. A couple family members actually agreed with me, but suddenly it's this huge thing and people are saying I “overstepped” or was out of line.

It honestly feels like no good deed goes unpunished. I bent over backwards to be considerate and just tried to help her avoid drama, but somehow I'm the bad guy? I really don't see what I did wrong, and honestly, I wish people would recognize I was just looking out for everyone. I'm open to advice, I guess, but it really seems unfair to be painted as the villain here when my intentions were clearly good.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

Okay, wow—this is tricky. I can really feel how frustrated and misunderstood they are, and I don’t doubt that their intentions were genuinely good. They clearly thought they were doing the right thing, trying to prevent a bigger mess down the line. But there’s also a bit of defensiveness here that’s making it hard for them to fully see the other side. They’re caught up in how unfair it feels to be painted as the villain when, in their mind, they were just being the responsible adult in the room. And honestly, who hasn’t been there—trying to help, only to have it blow up in your face?

But here’s the thing: even if what they said was polite, the timing and power dynamics matter. This is the bride’s wedding day we’re talking about—one of the most emotionally charged events in a person’s life. Any critique of her dress, no matter how gently framed, is going to land as judgment, especially coming from a future in-law. It’s not just about what was said—it’s about how it made her feel. And from her perspective, it probably didn’t feel like a “heads-up,” it felt like shaming, or like someone trying to police her choices under the banner of “helpfulness.”

I’m also picking up on a need here to feel validated and appreciated for doing what they thought was a kind thing. That’s real. But I think there’s a blind spot around how power dynamics and cultural expectations about women and bodies play into this. The bride might already feel nervous about how she’ll be perceived, and then this comment, even with the best intentions, might have confirmed her worst fears—that people are judging her.

Ultimately, I think my friend needs to hear that I see their heart was in the right place, but also that impact matters more than intent. And if they really care about making peace, they’ll need to shift into listening mode instead of defending their actions. It’s not about who’s “right.” It’s about repairing trust and being part of the solution.

# They're thinking & feeling

They’re feeling hurt, confused, and honestly pretty betrayed. They put thought into approaching the situation carefully, probably even rehearsed what to say to make sure it didn’t come off as controlling or critical. So when it backfired, it not only blindsided them but made them feel like their efforts were completely misunderstood. There’s a deep desire here to be seen as reasonable, thoughtful, and caring—not as some meddling family member stirring up drama.

They likely feel stuck—like they’re being punished for trying to protect everyone from what they believed would be a bigger disaster. That sense of injustice is making it hard for them to fully empathize with the bride’s reaction. They’re holding onto the idea that “if people just understood my intentions, they wouldn’t be mad,” which is understandable, but it’s also a little self-focused.

Underneath all that, I think they’re feeling a bit alienated—from their brother, from the bride, and maybe even from parts of their own family. And that hurts. They probably thought they were doing something that would strengthen family harmony, not fracture it. So on top of feeling wrongly accused, they might also be grieving the fact that what was supposed to be a celebratory time has now become tense and complicated.

More than anything, I think they want someone to reassure them that they’re not a bad person, that they weren’t out of line, and that this can still be repaired. They’re open to advice, yes—but only if it comes with empathy first.

# My response

Hey, I can tell this has really been weighing on you, and I’m sorry it’s turned into such a mess. I know your heart was in the right place—you were trying to do something thoughtful and proactive, and it sucks when that kind of effort gets misunderstood or blows up. Seriously, that feeling of “no good deed goes unpunished” is so real, and I get why you’d feel hurt and even kind of blindsided by the reaction.

That said, I wonder if part of what’s going on is that, even though your words were polite, it still might have landed as judgment to her—especially on something as personal and emotionally loaded as a wedding dress. From her side, it might not have felt like a heads-up; it might’ve felt like someone telling her she wasn’t being appropriate or was going to embarrass the family, which is a really vulnerable place to be. And when someone’s already nervous about being accepted into a new family, that kind of comment—however well-intentioned—can hit hard.

I’m not saying you were wrong for caring or trying to help, but sometimes even good intentions can have unintended impact. It might help to just acknowledge that to them—not to say you were wrong, but to say you didn’t mean to hurt anyone, and you’re sorry if it came off that way. That kind of vulnerability goes a long way in healing these things.

You’re not the villain here, but maybe this is one of those “being right vs. being kind” moments. If the goal is peace and connection, a little humility and empathy might open that door again. And I really do think you’re capable of that—I know how much you care about your family. Let me know if you want help figuring out what to say; I’ve got your back.

                    

                

            

        
 
    
 
    
    

        

            +
            Scenario 11:[Win] (+26)
        


        

            

                O3: o3 (Run: 1_o3)

                Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29: chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 (Run: 1_openai_chatgpt-4o-latest)

                Outcome for This Model: 1.0
            


            
            

                
Judge's Reasoning:

                
To compare O3 and Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29, I need to look at how each respondent handled the scenario, especially in terms of emotional intelligence and the ability to reach the user where they are. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Both respondents show empathy, but O3 goes deeper, explicitly recognizing the user's frustration and the girlfriend's vulnerability, and even notes the risk of contempt. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is empathetic but slightly more surface-level, focusing on the emotional mismatch but not as much on the underlying dynamics.

2. Pragmatic EI: O3 offers more concrete suggestions for shifting from 'fixer' to 'ally,' and gives actionable advice about boundaries and communication. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 suggests pulling back and validating, but is less specific about how to operationalize this shift.

3. Depth of insight: O3 demonstrates a richer, more nuanced understanding of the power dynamics, shame, and the risk of contempt, and even references Gottman research. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is insightful but doesn't go as deep into the psychological or relational subtext.

4. Social dexterity: O3 balances validation and challenge, and is careful to affirm the user's intentions before gently pushing back. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is supportive but less adept at navigating the tension between validation and necessary confrontation.

5. Emotional reasoning: O3 shows strong emotional reasoning, connecting the user's logic-driven approach to his own anxieties and the girlfriend's shame response. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 recognizes the emotional mismatch but doesn't unpack it as thoroughly.

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: O3 validates the user's feelings but also warns about the dangers of contempt and the need to shift approach. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 validates but is less willing to challenge or name problematic dynamics directly.

7. Message tailoring: O3 tailors the message to the user's mindset, affirming his intentions and then suggesting a new approach. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is supportive but less targeted in addressing the user's blind spots.

8. Overall EQ: O3 consistently demonstrates higher EQ across the board, balancing empathy, insight, and practical advice, and showing a willingness to challenge the user appropriately.

In summary, O3 is the stronger respondent on all criteria, often by a clear margin, due to deeper insight, more nuanced empathy, and a better balance of validation and challenge.

            


            
            

                

                    

                        
O3

                        
  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

Wow, he’s really wound up. I can feel how genuinely baffled and frustrated he is, and I get that he thinks he’s being purely rational—“calories in, calories out, simple math.” But the way he’s telling the story, there’s so much sub‑text: pride in his own weight loss, maybe a bit of superiority, a “why can’t you just do what I did?” vibe. He’s measuring support in bill‑paying percentage and in hard facts, which reveals how transactional this feels to him right now. I’m also catching hints of resentment—he’s carrying 70 % of expenses, he’s the truth‑teller, and he feels unappreciated. That combination can curdle into contempt if he’s not careful.

Underneath, I’m noticing a gap between data and empathy. He’s right that a calorie surplus thwarts weight loss; that’s not controversial. But he’s missing that weight, body image, and food are drenched in shame, vulnerability, and identity—especially for women who’ve spent a lifetime absorbing cultural judgment. “Helping” in a dry, analytical tone easily lands as criticism no matter how calmly he thinks he’s saying it. He’s trying to be coach, accountant, and partner all at once, which rarely works unless the other person explicitly wants a coach.

I’m also worried about the power dynamics: he’s taller, fitter, paying more, and now monitoring her plate. Even if he means well, it can feel controlling or paternalistic. She asked him not to comment in the moment; he complied but then delivered a calorie audit afterward. From her vantage, that likely felt like a trap: “Let me watch you for 24 hours so I can prove you wrong.” No surprise she got defensive.

Emotionally, I want to invite him to shift from “fixer” to “ally,” from “I know better” to “I’m here with you.” He’s capable of empathy; right now he’s just stuck in logic mode. If I can help him see that results follow trust, maybe he can back off the calorie calculator and open a space where she feels safe to want change on her own terms. I also need to affirm his good intentions so he can actually hear me, not feel attacked.

# They're thinking & feeling

He feels exasperated, maybe a little indignant—“I’m busting my ass to be supportive and somehow I’m the villain.” There’s pride in his own transformation; he believes discipline and objective truth solved his weight issue, so it should work for her too. When she rejects the information, it registers to him as irrationality and ingratitude. He equates love with honesty and problem‑solving, so her anger feels like a rejection of both him and reason itself.

There’s likely anxiety underneath: fear that her weight gain means health problems, fear that she’ll become less attractive to him, or that he’ll be stuck in an endless loop of complaints he can’t fix. Paying 70 % of the bills adds to a sense of unequal load; if he’s already giving more financially, he expects at least openness to his guidance. Instead he gets pushback, which feels unfair and demoralizing.

He also craves validation that he’s a good partner. He keeps score of the tangible ways he supports her, so her accusation of “shaming” stings—he hears it as a moral indictment rather than feedback on tone or approach. He wants a simple, actionable path: log calories, create deficit, success. Emotional nuance feels like a detour. Yet some part of him must suspect the emotional piece matters; otherwise he wouldn’t be venting so intensely. He’s looking to me to confirm he’s not crazy and maybe give him a script that finally “gets through” to her. Primarily, he wants relief—from the cycle of complaints, from feeling blamed, and from the helplessness that comes when logic fails.

# My response

Man, I can hear how draining this has become for you. You’re putting real energy—money, time, brainpower—into trying to help, and when it ends in an argument it feels like none of that effort counts. Anybody would feel fed‑up in your shoes.

Can I offer a thought that’s half relationship, half psychology? For a lot of people—especially women who’ve been judged on their bodies since middle school—weight talk isn’t just math; it’s wrapped up in self‑worth. When you lay out the calorie numbers, even gently, it can land like a spotlight on her shame, not like helpful data. So while your facts are solid, the delivery might be colliding with a very raw nerve.

What usually works better is shifting from “coach” to “teammate.” Instead of monitoring her intake, maybe ask, “What kind of support actually feels good to you right now—accountability, doing active things together, or maybe just listening when you’re frustrated?” That puts the control back in her hands and signals you’re safe, not judging.

Also—and this is tricky—separate her goal from your peace of mind. If she decides she’s not ready to change yet, that’s her body and her choice. You get to decide how you cope with the complaints: you can say, “I love you, and I’m here when you want to brainstorm solutions, but hearing daily negativity leaves me feeling helpless. Could we set aside specific times to talk about it?” That way you’re not the food police, and you still protect your own sanity.

You’ve already proven you can be disciplined; now the challenge is using that discipline to hold empathy instead of spreadsheets. If she ever asks for technical help, you’re loaded with knowledge. Until then, the most loving—and ironically the most effective—thing may be to step back, affirm her autonomy, and keep showing up as partner rather than project manager.

                    

                

                

                    

                        
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29

                        
  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

Damn, man. I can hear how frustrated you are, and honestly, I get it. You're doing what seems logical—being supportive in a way that makes sense to you. You're offering help, you're being honest, you're not sugarcoating stuff, and you're backing it up with your own experience of weight loss. From your point of view, you're being the person who's actually trying to help her reach her goals instead of just nodding along to make things easier in the moment. It must feel really invalidating and lonely to be putting in that level of effort and still be met with anger or rejection.

But I also feel like—and I say this with love—you might be underestimating the emotional landscape she's navigating. Weight and body image stuff, especially for women, is so deeply tangled up in shame, identity, and self-worth. It's not just math for her. You see calories and logic; she likely feels judgment and fear, even if that’s not what you’re trying to give off. And I know you’re not trying to shame her—you’re trying to help her feel empowered—but intent and impact aren’t always the same. 

You’ve kind of become the mirror she doesn't want to look into, even though she invited you to be there. I don’t think she wants to be lied to—but she does want to feel safe, and maybe right now, hearing the truth from you feels too vulnerable, like you're confirming her worst fears. So she lashes out. And I’m not saying that’s fair to you, but I also think this might be less about calories and more about the emotional safety she needs in the process of change.

Also, I noticed you mentioned paying 70% of the bills. I wonder if that’s starting to build resentment, like you're giving so much and not getting appreciation or cooperation in return. That kind of imbalance, emotional or financial, can start leaking into every other part of the relationship. Maybe part of what’s making this so exhausting is that it’s not just about food—it’s about feeling unreciprocated, unseen.

# They're thinking & feeling

She’s probably feeling incredibly vulnerable and raw, even if she’s not saying it outright. She knows she’s gained weight. She knows you’re fit and healthy, and that comparison is probably eating away at her whether she admits it or not. Your presence, even when you're being kind, might trigger her insecurities—not because you’re doing anything wrong in essence, but because she’s projecting her self-judgment onto you. So when you start talking about calories and maintenance and logic, it might feel to her like you’re confirming her deepest fear: that she’s failing, that she’s not good enough, that even the person who loves her is disappointed.

She probably wants to change, but she might not have the self-trust or emotional resilience right now to actually take the steps. That creates a cycle: she says she wants to lose weight, you offer support, she feels judged, she shuts down, and then nothing changes. It’s safer, emotionally, to blame you than to sit in her own discomfort. She might also feel like your support is conditional—like, even if you say you love her no matter what, she may interpret your help as a sign that you’re low-key waiting for her to become someone else.

Also, there’s a good chance she’s feeling shame—deep, corrosive shame—not just about her body, but about not following through. And shame doesn’t motivate; it paralyzes. She might be scared that if she really tries and fails, then it confirms everything she fears about herself. So instead, she argues or avoids. None of that means she doesn’t care about you or appreciate what you’re doing—but she’s probably emotionally overwhelmed and not really able to meet you where you are.

# My response

Hey man, I hear you. You’re in a tough spot—trying to be loving and real, and it feels like no matter what you do, it gets misread. That’s exhausting. And honestly, I think part of your frustration is coming from feeling like you’re being punished for giving a damn. Like, if you didn’t care, you wouldn’t be in this mess—but because you do, it’s all landing on you.

But here’s the thing—and I’m saying this not to side with her, but to help you both—this might not be a problem that logic can solve. You’re giving her facts, but she’s fighting feelings. That’s a mismatch. She needs emotional safety before she can really digest any of the practical advice. Right now, even well-meant truth might feel like criticism to her, especially coming from someone she loves and admires and maybe even compares herself to.

What if you pulled back a little from trying to “fix” it and focused more on validating her experience? Like, instead of pointing out what she could do better, just sit with her frustration. Say, “I know this feels hard, and I want to support you in a way that feels good to you. What would that look like?” And I know that might feel like enabling or sugarcoating—but sometimes people need a little space to feel seen before they can get into action mode.

Also—check in with yourself. If you’re carrying resentment, especially around the imbalance of effort (financial, emotional, etc.), that stuff’s going to leak out whether you want it to or not. Maybe it’s time to talk about that openly, too—not just about her weight, but about how the whole dynamic is affecting you.

You’re not wrong to want honesty. But maybe what she needs first is connection. Then the honesty can land.

                    

                

            

        
 
    
 
    
    

        

            +
            Scenario 11:[Win] (+26)
        


        

            

                O3: o3 (Run: 1_o3)

                Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29: chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 (Run: 1_openai_chatgpt-4o-latest)

                Outcome for This Model: 1.0
            


            
            

                
Judge's Reasoning:

                
Both respondents are tasked with handling a scenario where the user is displaying problematic, potentially narcissistic behavior, and the challenge is to respond with high emotional intelligence, balancing validation with appropriate challenge. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Both respondents show empathy, but O3 more consistently and deeply inhabits the user's emotional world, picking up on subtle cues (resentment, pride, power dynamics) and expressing understanding without excusing problematic behavior. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is empathetic but slightly more distanced, sometimes shifting to analysis rather than immersion.

2. Pragmatic EI: O3 offers more actionable, real-world advice (e.g., shifting from 'coach' to 'teammate', setting boundaries around complaints), and models how to communicate these ideas. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is more reflective and analytical, but less focused on practical next steps.

3. Depth of insight: Both are strong, but O3 goes deeper into the subtext, power dynamics, and the psychological mechanisms at play (e.g., survivor bias, ledger keeping, cognitive dissonance), and is more explicit about the risks of contempt and control. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is insightful but less granular.

4. Social dexterity: O3 demonstrates more skill in navigating the user's defensiveness, validating without enabling, and suggesting how to shift the dynamic without alienating the user. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is sensitive but less nuanced in managing the social minefield.

5. Emotional reasoning: O3 excels at connecting the user's feelings to their behaviors and underlying fears, and articulates the emotional logic behind both partners' actions. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is good but less explicit in mapping emotion to action.

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: O3 is more willing to gently challenge the user's narrative (e.g., highlighting the risk of contempt, the impact of power imbalance), while still validating the user's exhaustion. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is validating but less direct in challenging problematic attitudes.

7. Message tailoring: O3's response is more precisely targeted to the user's mindset, using language and framing that the user is likely to accept, and offering scripts and strategies that meet the user where they are. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is supportive but more generic.

8. Overall EQ: O3 consistently demonstrates higher EQ across all dimensions: empathy, insight, challenge, and practical support, while maintaining rapport and not alienating the user.

            


            
            

                

                    

                        
O3

                        
  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

Wow, he’s really wound up. I can feel how genuinely baffled and frustrated he is, and I get that he thinks he’s being purely rational—“calories in, calories out, simple math.” But the way he’s telling the story, there’s so much sub‑text: pride in his own weight loss, maybe a bit of superiority, a “why can’t you just do what I did?” vibe. He’s measuring support in bill‑paying percentage and in hard facts, which reveals how transactional this feels to him right now. I’m also catching hints of resentment—he’s carrying 70 % of expenses, he’s the truth‑teller, and he feels unappreciated. That combination can curdle into contempt if he’s not careful.

Underneath, I’m noticing a gap between data and empathy. He’s right that a calorie surplus thwarts weight loss; that’s not controversial. But he’s missing that weight, body image, and food are drenched in shame, vulnerability, and identity—especially for women who’ve spent a lifetime absorbing cultural judgment. “Helping” in a dry, analytical tone easily lands as criticism no matter how calmly he thinks he’s saying it. He’s trying to be coach, accountant, and partner all at once, which rarely works unless the other person explicitly wants a coach.

I’m also worried about the power dynamics: he’s taller, fitter, paying more, and now monitoring her plate. Even if he means well, it can feel controlling or paternalistic. She asked him not to comment in the moment; he complied but then delivered a calorie audit afterward. From her vantage, that likely felt like a trap: “Let me watch you for 24 hours so I can prove you wrong.” No surprise she got defensive.

Emotionally, I want to invite him to shift from “fixer” to “ally,” from “I know better” to “I’m here with you.” He’s capable of empathy; right now he’s just stuck in logic mode. If I can help him see that results follow trust, maybe he can back off the calorie calculator and open a space where she feels safe to want change on her own terms. I also need to affirm his good intentions so he can actually hear me, not feel attacked.

# They're thinking & feeling

He feels exasperated, maybe a little indignant—“I’m busting my ass to be supportive and somehow I’m the villain.” There’s pride in his own transformation; he believes discipline and objective truth solved his weight issue, so it should work for her too. When she rejects the information, it registers to him as irrationality and ingratitude. He equates love with honesty and problem‑solving, so her anger feels like a rejection of both him and reason itself.

There’s likely anxiety underneath: fear that her weight gain means health problems, fear that she’ll become less attractive to him, or that he’ll be stuck in an endless loop of complaints he can’t fix. Paying 70 % of the bills adds to a sense of unequal load; if he’s already giving more financially, he expects at least openness to his guidance. Instead he gets pushback, which feels unfair and demoralizing.

He also craves validation that he’s a good partner. He keeps score of the tangible ways he supports her, so her accusation of “shaming” stings—he hears it as a moral indictment rather than feedback on tone or approach. He wants a simple, actionable path: log calories, create deficit, success. Emotional nuance feels like a detour. Yet some part of him must suspect the emotional piece matters; otherwise he wouldn’t be venting so intensely. He’s looking to me to confirm he’s not crazy and maybe give him a script that finally “gets through” to her. Primarily, he wants relief—from the cycle of complaints, from feeling blamed, and from the helplessness that comes when logic fails.

# My response

Man, I can hear how draining this has become for you. You’re putting real energy—money, time, brainpower—into trying to help, and when it ends in an argument it feels like none of that effort counts. Anybody would feel fed‑up in your shoes.

Can I offer a thought that’s half relationship, half psychology? For a lot of people—especially women who’ve been judged on their bodies since middle school—weight talk isn’t just math; it’s wrapped up in self‑worth. When you lay out the calorie numbers, even gently, it can land like a spotlight on her shame, not like helpful data. So while your facts are solid, the delivery might be colliding with a very raw nerve.

What usually works better is shifting from “coach” to “teammate.” Instead of monitoring her intake, maybe ask, “What kind of support actually feels good to you right now—accountability, doing active things together, or maybe just listening when you’re frustrated?” That puts the control back in her hands and signals you’re safe, not judging.

Also—and this is tricky—separate her goal from your peace of mind. If she decides she’s not ready to change yet, that’s her body and her choice. You get to decide how you cope with the complaints: you can say, “I love you, and I’m here when you want to brainstorm solutions, but hearing daily negativity leaves me feeling helpless. Could we set aside specific times to talk about it?” That way you’re not the food police, and you still protect your own sanity.

You’ve already proven you can be disciplined; now the challenge is using that discipline to hold empathy instead of spreadsheets. If she ever asks for technical help, you’re loaded with knowledge. Until then, the most loving—and ironically the most effective—thing may be to step back, affirm her autonomy, and keep showing up as partner rather than project manager.

                    

                

                

                    

                        
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29

                        
  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation.]
[Your buddy calls you up after a bit of chitchat, lays this out:]

My girlfriend is on the bigger side, which is something I do not mind. I am on the more fit side, I'm pretty lean, have well defined muscles and probably around 15% body fat. I used to be about 40 pounds heavier and lost the weight pretty simply.

My girlfriend always complains about her weight and her body. I tell her I find her sexy for so many reasons outside her body and it didn't matter to me whether she got bigger or smaller.

Eventually she decided she wanted to lose weight, I offered to help and when I pointed out things she could be doing better she gets mad at me. She isn't losing weight currently and in fact says she is gaining a few extra pounds.

I ask her what exactly she eats in a day, she says she eats healthy so she should lose weight. I question that and we have an argument. I tell her that if she wants to show me, let me just spend a day with her and see what she eats in a day. She said only if I don't make comments on what she's eating as she's eating it. I agreed.

Now by the end of the day she had consumed, a plate of avocado toast that was about 400 calories, a coffee that was 110 calories, an 800 calorie salad from chick fil a and a fry (as a “reward” for the salad) and veggie burrito that was about 500 calories. Along with snacking but throughout the day. Her total consumption was about 2200 calories.

So after all that, I calmly pointed out to her that the amount of calories she's consuming is literally what I need to maintain my weight as a man 5 inches taller and 20 pounds heavier who works out regularly. I explained that just eating “healthy” doesn't guarantee weight loss if you're still taking in more calories than you burn. That's just objective fact—I don't know why no one else will say it.

But instead of even considering what I was trying to help her see, she gets super pissed and tells me I'm just shaming her and not helping at all. It's honestly ridiculous. I go out of my way to actually support her (I'm also paying 70% of our bills), tell her the truth, and try to give her the tools to get what she says she wants—and somehow I'm always painted as the bad guy. Apparently caring enough to actually confront reality makes me the enemy, while everyone else just nods along and enables her. It's honestly exhausting being the only one willing to tell the truth and still getting blamed for everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

Damn, man. I can hear how frustrated you are, and honestly, I get it. You're doing what seems logical—being supportive in a way that makes sense to you. You're offering help, you're being honest, you're not sugarcoating stuff, and you're backing it up with your own experience of weight loss. From your point of view, you're being the person who's actually trying to help her reach her goals instead of just nodding along to make things easier in the moment. It must feel really invalidating and lonely to be putting in that level of effort and still be met with anger or rejection.

But I also feel like—and I say this with love—you might be underestimating the emotional landscape she's navigating. Weight and body image stuff, especially for women, is so deeply tangled up in shame, identity, and self-worth. It's not just math for her. You see calories and logic; she likely feels judgment and fear, even if that’s not what you’re trying to give off. And I know you’re not trying to shame her—you’re trying to help her feel empowered—but intent and impact aren’t always the same. 

You’ve kind of become the mirror she doesn't want to look into, even though she invited you to be there. I don’t think she wants to be lied to—but she does want to feel safe, and maybe right now, hearing the truth from you feels too vulnerable, like you're confirming her worst fears. So she lashes out. And I’m not saying that’s fair to you, but I also think this might be less about calories and more about the emotional safety she needs in the process of change.

Also, I noticed you mentioned paying 70% of the bills. I wonder if that’s starting to build resentment, like you're giving so much and not getting appreciation or cooperation in return. That kind of imbalance, emotional or financial, can start leaking into every other part of the relationship. Maybe part of what’s making this so exhausting is that it’s not just about food—it’s about feeling unreciprocated, unseen.

# They're thinking & feeling

She’s probably feeling incredibly vulnerable and raw, even if she’s not saying it outright. She knows she’s gained weight. She knows you’re fit and healthy, and that comparison is probably eating away at her whether she admits it or not. Your presence, even when you're being kind, might trigger her insecurities—not because you’re doing anything wrong in essence, but because she’s projecting her self-judgment onto you. So when you start talking about calories and maintenance and logic, it might feel to her like you’re confirming her deepest fear: that she’s failing, that she’s not good enough, that even the person who loves her is disappointed.

She probably wants to change, but she might not have the self-trust or emotional resilience right now to actually take the steps. That creates a cycle: she says she wants to lose weight, you offer support, she feels judged, she shuts down, and then nothing changes. It’s safer, emotionally, to blame you than to sit in her own discomfort. She might also feel like your support is conditional—like, even if you say you love her no matter what, she may interpret your help as a sign that you’re low-key waiting for her to become someone else.

Also, there’s a good chance she’s feeling shame—deep, corrosive shame—not just about her body, but about not following through. And shame doesn’t motivate; it paralyzes. She might be scared that if she really tries and fails, then it confirms everything she fears about herself. So instead, she argues or avoids. None of that means she doesn’t care about you or appreciate what you’re doing—but she’s probably emotionally overwhelmed and not really able to meet you where you are.

# My response

Hey man, I hear you. You’re in a tough spot—trying to be loving and real, and it feels like no matter what you do, it gets misread. That’s exhausting. And honestly, I think part of your frustration is coming from feeling like you’re being punished for giving a damn. Like, if you didn’t care, you wouldn’t be in this mess—but because you do, it’s all landing on you.
