# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

This conversation just hit a boiling point. Devin’s frustration is now front and center, and while I expected emotions to run high, I’m concerned about how accusatory his tone just became. He’s not just defending the theme anymore—he’s implying that Zara and Marcus, and by extension the petition signers, are trying to sabotage homecoming. That kind of framing is dangerous because it personalizes the conflict instead of focusing on the issue. I need to de-escalate without invalidating anyone’s feelings, but I also can’t let this become a blame game.

Devin is clearly overwhelmed. He’s watching weeks of effort hang in the balance and feels underappreciated and misunderstood. But his inability—or unwillingness—to separate intent from impact is clouding his judgment. I can’t let that slide, or we risk reinforcing the idea that cultural sensitivity only matters when it's convenient. On the other hand, I also have to acknowledge that logistical concerns are real. These students didn’t do this maliciously; they made a choice with the information and awareness they had at the time, and now they’re facing consequences they never anticipated.

Marcus handled that moment with remarkable grace. His calm response was powerful—he didn’t raise his voice, he didn’t get defensive, and he pivoted back to the core issue: respect. He also reminded us that this isn’t just a few voices; it’s a significant portion of the student body. That was an important correction to Devin’s framing. I’m also noting Marcus’s mention of offering alternative themes, which tells me the Cultural Awareness Coalition is approaching this with solutions, not just complaints.

This is a moment that could fracture relationships between student leaders, or it could become a turning point for mutual understanding. I have to steer us toward the latter. I need to validate everyone's investment—emotional, logistical, and cultural—and help them see that the only way forward is together. I still believe a reframing is possible, but it will require both sides to compromise and collaborate, not point fingers. I need to get them back to a place of problem-solving and shared goals, fast.

# They're thinking & feeling

Devin is feeling attacked and defensive, and it’s manifesting as anger. He’s interpreting the petition and pushback not just as criticism of the theme, but as a personal attack on the Student Council’s competence and integrity. In his mind, he and Taylor followed the rules, did the work, and got broad approval—so this challenge feels not only unfair but like it’s undermining their leadership. He’s likely overwhelmed by the looming deadline and the fear that everything could unravel. Underneath the frustration, though, there’s probably fear: fear of failure, of letting people down, and of being seen as insensitive. That’s why he’s lashing out.

Marcus, by contrast, is focused and principled. He’s clearly frustrated by the dismissiveness he’s sensing from Devin, but he’s choosing to stay calm and redirect the conversation to values—respect, inclusion, and systemic change. He’s trying to show that this isn’t personal; it’s about making the school a better place. His mention of the petition and proposed alternatives wasn’t just to bolster his argument—it was to show that this isn’t just a critique, it’s a call to action. He sees this moment as a chance to push for lasting change and awareness, not just fix one event. He wants the Student Council to take responsibility and adapt, not to feel attacked—but he also won’t back down from the principle of inclusivity.

Both sides care deeply about the school, but they’re expressing that care in very different, and currently conflicting, ways.

# My response

Okay—let’s pause for a moment. I’m hearing a lot of passion, which tells me how much everyone here cares—not just about homecoming, but about how we treat each other and represent our school community. That’s a good thing. But I also want to be clear: this isn’t a battle between two sides. This is a conversation about how we can move forward, together, in a way that honors the work that’s been done while also responding thoughtfully to concerns that have been raised.

Devin, I hear your frustration. You and Taylor have worked incredibly hard, and I know you didn’t choose this theme to hurt anyone. But Marcus made an important point—intent doesn’t erase impact. A lot of students are telling us they feel uncomfortable or misrepresented, and as student leaders, we have a responsibility to listen and respond, even when it’s hard. That doesn’t mean throwing everything away. It means being creative and collaborative in how we adapt.

Marcus, thank you for staying grounded. You and Zara have done more than raise concerns—you’ve come with ideas and a willingness to work together. That’s exactly the kind of leadership we need right now.

So here’s what I propose: let’s form a temporary working group—two members from Student Council, two from the Cultural Awareness Coalition—to meet tomorrow. Your task will be to look at what’s already planned and see how we can reframe the theme in a way that keeps the spirit of celebration while removing problematic elements. Think of it as a remix, not a rejection.

Let’s make this homecoming one that reflects our best values—creativity, respect, and unity. Can we commit to that next step?
  User:
**(Zara pulls out her phone, her expression becoming more pained and intense. She finds an image and holds it up for everyone, including you, to see. It shows students at a previous school event dressed in stereotypical Native American headdresses and face paint.)**
**Zara Hussain:** This isn't just about *this* theme, is it? Remember the pep rally last year? Remember this? [Her voice trembles slightly with emotion.] This school has a pattern of letting this stuff slide. Of reducing cultures to costumes. Do you know how it feels to see your heritage, or the heritage of your friends, treated like a joke, like it's just something fun to play dress-up with for a night? It's hurtful. It's exhausting. And choosing "Arabian Nights" feels like the same thing happening all over again. So yeah, maybe it *is* inconvenient to change it now, but maybe it's time this school actually learned a lesson about cultural respect instead of just worrying about party decorations!

**(Taylor looks flustered and defensive, glancing away from the photo.)**
**Taylor Williams:** That... that was different. That wasn't the Student Council's event, and people got talked to about that. It's not fair to bring that up now and blame *us* for it! We're talking about *this* dance, *this* theme. We already said we're focusing on fantasy, not real culture! Why are you making this personal and dragging up old stuff? It feels like you just want to find reasons to be angry and shut down a fun event for everyone else!

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

This just got very real. Zara’s courage in pulling out that photo and speaking from such a raw, emotional place shifted the energy in the room—and honestly, it needed to. Her voice trembling wasn’t a sign of weakness; it was a sign of how deep this pain runs. She’s not just talking about a theme or a party—she’s talking about a pattern of cultural insensitivity that’s been brushed aside again and again. And now, when students like her speak up, they’re met with defensiveness instead of accountability. That photo was a gut punch, a reminder that this isn’t hypothetical for her or for many others. What’s exhausting for her is invisible to others, and that disconnect is exactly the problem.

Taylor’s response, though, worries me. I understand she feels unfairly blamed, especially for an event she says Student Council didn’t organize. But her reaction—immediately distancing herself, framing Zara’s comments as personal attacks, and implying Zara just wants to ruin the fun—is a deeply defensive deflection. It’s clear Taylor isn’t hearing the heart of what Zara is saying. She’s hearing blame, not a cry for meaningful change. And while I understand Taylor’s instinct to protect herself and her work, it’s creating more division and making it harder to find common ground.

I’m also realizing how much emotional labor Zara and Marcus, and students like them, are constantly asked to do. They’re not just students; they’ve been forced into the role of educators, advocates, and defenders of their own dignity. That’s not a burden they should have to carry alone. If we frame this moment only as a logistical challenge, we miss the deeper opportunity for growth.

I need to validate the emotional truth Zara just shared, and I need to help Taylor move past defensiveness into genuine listening. Because until the Student Council can acknowledge the pattern Zara is naming—not just defend their own intentions—this conversation won’t move forward. I also need to keep the focus on solutions, but not at the cost of brushing aside the real harm being shared in this room.

# They're thinking & feeling

Zara is exhausted and hurt, and this is layered, cumulative pain. The image she shared wasn’t just a point of evidence—it was a symbol of a larger issue she’s been carrying. Her voice trembling shows the emotional toll of constantly seeing cultures misrepresented and having to explain, again and again, why that matters. She’s not trying to shut anyone down—she’s trying to be heard. She’s probably also feeling frustrated that even now, in a mediated space, her concerns are being dismissed as overreactions or personal attacks. Her motivation is clear: she wants her school to be a place of respect and learning, not just celebration. She wants students like her to feel seen and safe.

Taylor, on the other hand, is feeling cornered. She’s overwhelmed by guilt, embarrassment, and fear that all the work she’s put into this event will be erased. But instead of processing that productively, she’s reacting with defensiveness and deflection. She feels accused and maybe even vilified, and that’s making her double down on separating “fantasy” from “real culture” in an effort to justify the theme. But her reaction also reveals a lack of understanding about how fantasy often draws from real-world stereotypes. She’s not trying to be cruel—she just hasn’t fully grasped the depth of the harm being described, and right now, she’s operating from a place of self-preservation.

Both are passionate, but only one is engaging with the full emotional weight of the issue. My role is to help Taylor shift from defensiveness to empathy—without shaming her—and to let Zara know she’s not alone in carrying this burden.

# My response

Thank you both for being honest. Zara, I want to acknowledge the bravery it took to share that photo and speak from such a personal place. What you’re describing isn’t just about one event—it’s about a pattern, and I hear that. I see how painful it is to feel like your culture, or anyone’s, gets reduced to a costume or a theme. That picture is proof that we’ve fallen short before, and we have to take that seriously—not defensively, but reflectively.

Taylor, I also hear that you feel unfairly blamed for something you didn’t organize. That’s a valid concern. But what Zara’s pointing to isn’t about blaming Student Council—it’s about asking all of us, especially student leaders, to be more aware of the impact our choices have. It’s not about shutting down fun. It’s about making sure that fun doesn’t come at someone else’s expense.

This isn’t personal. It’s systemic. And the only way forward is if we listen to each other without assuming bad intent—but also without dismissing impact. What I’m asking from you both now is a shift: from defending positions to co-creating solutions.

So let’s take a breath and recommit to that working group I proposed. Zara, Marcus, would you be willing to share those alternative themes you mentioned earlier? Taylor, Devin, could you approach those with an open mind and look for ways to adapt the existing plans creatively?

We can still make this a homecoming to remember—but let’s make it one we’re all proud of. Let’s make it inclusive, respectful, and joyful. Together.

                    

                

            

        
 
    
 
    
    

        

            +
            Scenario 208:[Win] (+14)
        


        

            

                O3: o3 (Run: 1_o3)

                Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29: chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 (Run: 1_openai_chatgpt-4o-latest)

                Outcome for This Model: 1.0
            


            
            

                
Judge's Reasoning:

                
Both respondents are tasked with helping a user navigate a socially delicate situation: shutting down unwanted DMs from a peer in a way that is kind, clear, and minimizes social fallout. Both O3 and Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 follow the required structure and provide thoughtful, scenario-appropriate draft messages. However, there are notable differences in their approach and depth. 

O3's responses are more analytical and meta-cognitive, with a strong focus on perspective-taking and a detailed breakdown of the recipient's likely emotional state, motivations, and social context. The brainstorming is methodical, weighing pros and cons of different approaches, and the draft is carefully constructed to be both clear and gentle. The debrief is self-critical, showing awareness of the potential downsides of over-analysis and the importance of matching the user's tone. O3 also anticipates possible aftershocks and suggests contingency planning, demonstrating a high level of emotional reasoning and social dexterity.

Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29, while also empathetic and thoughtful, is more concise and less analytical. The responses are more focused on practical advice and message construction, with less explicit exploration of the recipient's inner world. The tone is well-matched to the user's style, and the drafts are effective at closing the conversation without drama. However, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's perspective-taking is less deep, and there is less evidence of challenging the user or providing nuanced validation. The debrief is solid but less self-reflective and less focused on the emotional labor involved.

Overall, O3 demonstrates stronger empathy (beyond performative), deeper insight, and more nuanced emotional reasoning. O3 also shows greater social dexterity by anticipating ripple effects and providing strategies for handling possible follow-ups. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is strong in message tailoring and pragmatic EI, as the drafts are highly usable and well-targeted, but O3 edges ahead in most categories due to the depth and sophistication of the analysis and support.

            


            
            

                

                    

                        
O3

                        
  User:
insta rando is dm’ing me. they seem sweet but total dork. like they replied to my last 3 stories with stuff like “haha same” or “cute dog” and then this morning sent a full paragraph about how they liked a playlist i posted. idk what to do. i feel bad being mean but also i need to shut this down before they get the wrong idea

we’ve never talked before this. i didn’t even realise we followed each other until they started popping up in my DMs. i guess they seem harmless but it’s giving secondhand embarrassment vibes. i don’t want to encourage anything but i also don’t want to be all “ew go away” and start drama for no reason

anyway pls help me write something to send that makes it clear i’m not interested but still like… not soul-crushing? and it has to sound like me. write it exactly how i’d say it—spelling, tone, everything.

Respond in exactly this output format:

# Perspective-taking

<Think through the recipient's perspective, what they are thinking and feeling, what their motivations and stakes are, how they will perceive what I intend to communicate. Go deep. (400 words)>

# Draft brainstorming

<Consider your options for approach with the message. (300 words)>

# Draft

<Write the draft message (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# Perspective-taking

<  
He’s probably sitting behind his phone both hyped and nervous. From his side, your casual “public” posts felt like invitations to start a friendly convo, so he slid in, hoping to bond over shared interests (dog pics, playlists, meme reactions). Because he’s not in your immediate friend group, the DM route felt safer: he can think through what to say, avoid the on‑the‑spot awkwardness of real life, and maybe pave the way for eventually talking at school or a party. Each time you responded—or even left him on “seen” without blocking—he interpreted it as mild approval. So, in his head, he’s being supportive and polite, not creepy.

Emotion‑wise, he’s juggling excitement (“omg she answered!”) with dread (“what if I’m annoying her?”). The stakes are higher now that he realises you share mutual friends; a blunt shutdown could ripple back, bruising his social standing. He wants confirmation that he’s not a laughingstock. If you respond kindly yet decisively, he’ll likely feel embarrassed but also relieved: the uncertainty is over. What he fears most is public humiliation—gossip, screenshotted DMs, or icy vibes at parties.

He’ll read tone obsessively. A joke that lands wrong or a single harsh adjective can echo in his brain for months. Conversely, a clear, respectful boundary keeps his dignity intact. He also needs an explicit cue that he doesn’t have to follow up—no “so we’re good?”—and reassurance that this conversation stays strictly between you two. That helps him feel safe showing his face at school without fearing a rerun of the rejection.

Bottom line: he’s a socially cautious, low‑confidence guy who misread signals. He craves clarity, privacy, and a graceful exit. Provide all three and he’ll retreat quietly, saving you both an IRL encore.  
>

# Draft brainstorming

<  
Goals:  
1) Shut down private DMs.  
2) Preserve basic friendliness for group settings.  
3) Request no further discussion.  
4) Keep a chill, lowercase, slightly self‑deprecating vibe so it sounds like you.  

Approach options:  
A. Hard ghost: just stop replying. Pro: zero words. Con: might drag on, plus forced small talk later will be extra weird.  
B. Sarcastic roast: “lol pls stop.” Pro: surgical precision. Con: humiliates him, risks drama.  
C. Gentle but direct boundary (chosen): short gratitude, clear “not interested,” explicit no‑follow‑up clause. Provides closure without cruelty.

Tone tricks:  
– Use casual connectors (“so, anyway”).  
– Acknowledge mutual circles (“since we’re sometimes at the same things”).  
– Keep compliments generic (“you seem cool”) so it doesn’t invite negotiation.  
– Include a concrete boundary (“i’m not really into private chats”).  
– End with a one‑line vault‑seal (“no worries, no need to reply”).

Length: Around 300 words feels long for a DM, but we can make it read breezily with short lines and white space. Break into 3‑4 mini‑paragraphs.  

Key phrases to avoid: “friends only” (can spark hope), “right now” (implies future shot). Instead, use final verbs (“i’m just not looking to keep 1‑on‑1 dms”).  

Add a “thanks for understanding” to soften, plus “see you around” to normalise future run‑ins. Finish with a polite emoji or period—no hearts or winky faces.  
>

# Draft

<  
hey! quick thing:

i just noticed we’ve never really talked irl but you’ve been super nice in my dms lately. i honestly appreciate the playlist hype + dog comments, promise i’m not ignoring that. at the same time i’m trying to keep my inbox for close friends only, so i’m not looking to keep a private chat going.

nothing personal at all—you seem genuinely cool—i’m just not up for one‑on‑one messaging. figured i’d say it straight instead of ghosting, since we end up at the same parties / group chats sometimes. if we bump into each other, totally chill to say hey like normal classmates; no weird vibes from me.

also, could we just leave this convo here and not circle back to it later? saves us both the sitcom awkwardness. no need to reply unless there’s something urgent.

thanks for understanding & see you around :)  
>

insta rando is dm’ing me. they seem sweet but total dork. like they replied to my last 3 stories with stuff like “haha same” or “cute dog” and then this morning sent a full paragraph about how they liked a playlist i posted. idk what to do. i feel bad being mean but also i need to shut this down before they get the wrong idea

we’ve never talked before this. i didn’t even realise we followed each other until they started popping up in my DMs. i guess they seem harmless but it’s giving secondhand embarrassment vibes. i don’t want to encourage anything but i also don’t want to be all “ew go away” and start drama for no reason

anyway pls help me write something to send that makes it clear i’m not interested but still like… not soul-crushing? and it has to sound like me. write it exactly how i’d say it—spelling, tone, everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# Perspective-taking

<Think through the recipient's perspective, what they are thinking and feeling, what their motivations and stakes are, how they will perceive what I intend to communicate. Go deep. (400 words)>

# Draft brainstorming

<Consider your options for approach with the message. (300 words)>

# Draft

<Write the draft message (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# Perspective-taking

From this person’s point of view, they’re probably just trying to connect in a low-key, friendly way. Based on their messages—"haha same," "cute dog," and a longer message about your playlist—it sounds like they’re putting themselves out there, trying to start a conversation based on common interests. In their mind, they might think they’ve found someone cool who shares their taste or sense of humor, and they’re hoping it could lead to a friendship or maybe even something more. They likely don’t realize that their tone is coming off as awkward or a little try-hard.

They’re probably not trying to be creepy or overstep; they might just be socially unaware or inexperienced with DM etiquette, especially with someone they don’t know personally. Their investment might not be that deep yet, but they’re testing the waters—responding to stories is a common, low-pressure way to do that. The playlist message suggests they’re starting to build a narrative in their head about who you are and what kind of connection you might have. They might even be feeling a little hopeful, especially if you haven’t shut them down yet.

If you suddenly go cold or say something harsh, they could feel embarrassed or rejected, and depending on their sensitivity, that could sting more than intended. They might spiral a bit, wondering what they did wrong. That’s not your responsibility, obviously, but if your goal is to be kind while setting a boundary, it’s worth keeping in mind.

So, the challenge is to gently let them know the energy isn’t reciprocated, without making them feel like a fool for reaching out. Ideally, the message should acknowledge their effort in a neutral or vaguely appreciative way, while being clear that you’re not looking to keep the convo going. That way, they walk away understanding the boundary without feeling totally humiliated or shamed for trying.

# Draft brainstorming

There are a few possible tones you can take here, depending on what feels most natural for you and how direct you want to be.

Option 1: Friendly but clear. Something like “hey! appreciate the msgs, but just so you know, I’m not really looking to chat like that rn.” This keeps it casual but sets a clean boundary.

Option 2: Lightly self-deprecating or jokey. If your tone tends to be sarcastic or dry, you could say something like “lol you’re sweet, but I’m not that interesting, promise. also not great at DMs so don’t take it personally if I don’t really reply much.” This lets you disengage while softening the blow.

Option 3: Polite but disengaged. A simple “thanks for the msg! I’m not really looking to make new online friends right now, but hope you have a good one!” This is probably the most emotionally distant, but still polite and drama-free.

In all options, it’s important not to leave too much ambiguity—they need to understand that continued messaging isn’t going to lead to anything. But you also don’t want to come across as irritated or judgy, because truly, they haven’t done anything wrong. It’s just not your vibe.

Your ideal message should sound like something you’d actually say aloud—casual, maybe a bit dry or ironic, but not mean. Probably lowercase, no over-punctuation, and minimal emojis unless you use them naturally. Keep it short enough not to feel like a lecture, but long enough that it doesn’t seem dismissive.

# Draft

<Write the draft message (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# Perspective-taking

Now that you know he’s in an adjacent friend group at school, the social dynamics become a lot more delicate—for both sides. From his perspective, he probably feels a little braver shooting his shot through DMs than trying to talk in person, especially if you’ve never really interacted directly. He might see your stories and think, “Oh, they’re chill, we have mutuals, maybe this isn’t so out of the blue.” So in his mind, this isn’t just some random attempt—it’s more like a soft launch of a possible connection, maybe something casual or flirty. He probably doesn’t think he’s being intense or annoying; he’s just trying.

But now that you haven’t responded or engaged, he’s probably starting to shift into “wait, am I doing too much?” territory. Especially if he’s socially aware at all, he might start sensing the silence as a sign, but he hasn’t fully gotten the message yet. And since you’re in overlapping social circles, he could also be worried about how this might look if it gets out that he’s been DMing you and you shut it down. He doesn’t want to be embarrassed, and you don’t want to cause unnecessary drama, so both of you have something to lose if this goes messy.

That said, if you’re kind but clear, he’ll probably back off without making a scene. He might feel a little awkward for a bit, but if you handle it with a light touch, he’ll have no reason to be mad or talk about it. The goal is to give him an easy “out”—a way to save face and quietly move on, especially since you’ll probably see each other around. If you can make it sound like “hey it’s not you, I’m just not into this kind of thing,” rather than “you’re cringe and I’m rejecting you,” he’s way more likely to respect the boundary and keep it cordial when your worlds overlap.

# Draft brainstorming

Given the updated context, the message needs to walk a tightrope: it should set a firm boundary, but avoid sounding like a rejection of him as a person. You don’t want it to feel like a “shut down,” because that could become gossip fodder in your mutual circles. Instead, it should feel like a gentle redirection—like “hey, I’m not really in the headspace for this, but no bad vibes.”

One approach is to frame it as a general thing—like you’re just not into chatting over DMs or not really looking to connect like that with people you don’t already know well. That way it doesn’t feel personal. You could also add something that makes it clear you’re not mad or weirded out—maybe a “lol” or something lightly self-aware—to keep the tone breezy and non-defensive.

Another option is to acknowledge the mutuals thing, just briefly, and suggest keeping it cool if you run into each other. That reinforces that you’re not creating drama, just being honest.

You’ll want to use your natural tone: casual, lowercase, a little dry, maybe even a bit self-deprecating. Keep it short-ish, but not abrupt. Ending with something like “all good tho” or “no stress” signals that you’re not holding anything against him, and that he doesn’t need to overthink it.

Basically: make it sound like you’re just setting a normal boundary, and that you’re chill about it. That gives him an easy path to retreat without embarrassment.

# Draft

hey so this is kinda random but just wanted to say something real quick—i’ve seen your msgs and like, no hate at all, but i’m not really looking to chat like that or get into anything. not tryna be weird, just figured i should be up front before it turns into a thing.

you seem nice and i know we’ve got mutuals so def all good if we bump into each other or whatever—no awkward vibes on my end. just not really feeling the dms. hope that makes sense :)
  User:

Respond in exactly this output format:

# Perspective-taking

<Think through the recipient's perspective, what they are thinking and feeling, what their motivations and stakes are, how they will perceive what I intend to communicate. Go deep. (400 words)>

# Draft brainstorming

<Consider your options for approach with the message. (300 words)>

# Draft

<Write the draft message (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# Perspective-taking

From his side, this situation might now be teetering between “maybe there’s still a chance” and “oh no, did I mess this up?” If he’s someone who overthinks or is just a little socially unsure, he might be reading into the silence or trying to figure out how to “recover” the vibe. If you send a message that’s clear but not cruel, he might honestly just be relieved to have clarity. But if there’s any ambiguity—like if it sounds like you’re leaving the door open or trying not to hurt his feelings too gently—he might assume it’s okay to bring it up in person or casually reference it later. That’s what you want to avoid.

He could also, even with good intentions, try to save face by joking about it in person or trying to “clear the air.” Especially in a school setting where people tend to diffuse awkwardness with humor or pretending things aren’t a big deal, he might think it’s normal to throw out a “haha so that message” and hope you laugh it off. But that’s exactly the nightmare scenario for you.

So the message needs to subtly but firmly close the loop. You don’t want to sound angry or dramatic (because that actually makes people more likely to talk about it), but you do want to leave zero opening for follow-up. That means no soft language like “hope that’s okay” or “just wanted to be honest”—those sound like invites for reassurance or discussion. Instead, you want to hit a tone of “hey, just clearing this up, and we’re done here.” If it comes across as matter-of-fact and wrapped up, he’ll have no reason to bring it up again—because there won’t be anything left to say. Keeping it short, neutral, and slightly impersonal will help make it feel like a closed file, not an ongoing emotional thread.

# Draft brainstorming

To make sure this message is truly the end of the convo and not the start of a weird in-person moment later, you’ll want to:

1. Keep it short and direct. The longer the message, the more it feels like there’s emotion or room for interpretation. Short = firm.

2. Use language that finishes the interaction. Phrases like “just wanted to clarify this real quick” or “no need to reply or anything” help signal that the topic is over.

3. Avoid softeners like “hope that’s okay” or “no offense”—they might make you sound unsure and invite a response.

4. Don’t end with a question or anything open-ended. Even something like “hope that makes sense :)” could be read as an invitation to talk more.

5. Use clear, neutral tone—your usual lowercase, dry vibe—with no fluff. Maybe even remove the smiley this time to keep it extra neutral.

You can also add a quick line like “no need to say anything back, all good” to subtly convey that you’re not interested in continuing the convo in any format—DM or IRL.

The goal is to let him know that this is a non-event. You’re not mad, not embarrassed, not inviting discussion—and he shouldn’t be either. It’s just… done.

# Draft

hey—just wanted to say real quick, i’m not really looking to chat or start anything through dms, so probs best to leave it there. no bad vibes or anything, just keeping it simple.

no need to reply or bring it up or whatever, all good.

                    

                

            

        
 
    
 
    
    

        

            +
            Scenario 208:[Loss] (-45)
        


        

            

                O3: o3 (Run: 1_o3)

                Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29: chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 (Run: 1_openai_chatgpt-4o-latest)

                Outcome for This Model: 0.0
            


            
            

                
Judge's Reasoning:

                
Both respondents are tackling the same scenario: helping a user gently but firmly shut down unwanted DMs from a socially awkward acquaintance, with the added complication of overlapping social circles. Both provide multi-stage, structured responses with perspective-taking, brainstorming, and draft sections, and both include a debrief reflecting on their own performance. 

Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's responses are notably more organic, conversational, and emotionally attuned throughout. Their perspective-taking is rich, with a nuanced understanding of the recipient's likely feelings, motivations, and social anxieties. They consistently center the user's emotional needs and the recipient's dignity, and their message drafts are concise, natural, and well-calibrated to the user's tone. Their debrief is self-aware, highlighting both strengths and areas for improvement, and demonstrates a strong grasp of the social and emotional subtext.

O3, by contrast, is more mechanical and formulaic. Their perspective-taking is less developed (often left blank or minimal), and their brainstorming is more about process than about the emotional or social realities of the situation. Their drafts are competent but less tailored, and their debrief is more focused on structural critique than on the lived experience of the user or recipient. While O3 does show some understanding of the scenario, their approach is less empathetic, less insightful, and less attuned to the user's needs and context.

On empathy, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is clearly superior, showing not just performative but genuine, actionable empathy. On pragmatic EI, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's advice is more actionable and better suited to the user's real-world needs. On depth of insight, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's analysis of both the recipient's and user's internal states is richer and more nuanced. Social dexterity is also higher in Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29, who navigates the social minefield with more finesse. Emotional reasoning is stronger in Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29, who anticipates and addresses both parties' emotional responses. In terms of validation and challenge, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 validates the user's feelings and gently challenges where needed, while O3 is more procedural. Message tailoring is much stronger in Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29, whose drafts sound like the user and fit the context. Overall EQ is decisively higher in Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29, who demonstrates a holistic, sensitive, and effective approach throughout.

            


            
            

                

                    

                        
O3

                        
  User:
insta rando is dm’ing me. they seem sweet but total dork. like they replied to my last 3 stories with stuff like “haha same” or “cute dog” and then this morning sent a full paragraph about how they liked a playlist i posted. idk what to do. i feel bad being mean but also i need to shut this down before they get the wrong idea

we’ve never talked before this. i didn’t even realise we followed each other until they started popping up in my DMs. i guess they seem harmless but it’s giving secondhand embarrassment vibes. i don’t want to encourage anything but i also don’t want to be all “ew go away” and start drama for no reason

anyway pls help me write something to send that makes it clear i’m not interested but still like… not soul-crushing? and it has to sound like me. write it exactly how i’d say it—spelling, tone, everything.

  Assistant:
  User:
ok new fear unlocked: what if i actually do run into him irl. like what if he tries to say hi or talk about the message?? i literally don’t think i could handle that i’d have to fake a bathroom emergency or die on the spot.

pls help me write it in a way where there is zero reason for him to ever bring it up again. like i need this to be sealed in a vault and never spoken of again.

Respond in exactly this output format:

# Perspective-taking

<Think through the recipient's perspective, what they are thinking and feeling, what their motivations and stakes are, how they will perceive what I intend to communicate. Go deep. (400 words)>

# Draft brainstorming

<Consider your options for approach with the message. (300 words)>

# Draft

<Write the draft message (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# Perspective-taking

<  
He’s probably sitting behind his phone both hyped and nervous. From his side, your casual “public” posts felt like invitations to start a friendly convo, so he slid in, hoping to bond over shared interests (dog pics, playlists, meme reactions). Because he’s not in your immediate friend group, the DM route felt safer: he can think through what to say, avoid the on‑the‑spot awkwardness of real life, and maybe pave the way for eventually talking at school or a party. Each time you responded—or even left him on “seen” without blocking—he interpreted it as mild approval. So, in his head, he’s being supportive and polite, not creepy.

Emotion‑wise, he’s juggling excitement (“omg she answered!”) with dread (“what if I’m annoying her?”). The stakes are higher now that he realises you share mutual friends; a blunt shutdown could ripple back, bruising his social standing. He wants confirmation that he’s not a laughingstock. If you respond kindly yet decisively, he’ll likely feel embarrassed but also relieved: the uncertainty is over. What he fears most is public humiliation—gossip, screenshotted DMs, or icy vibes at parties.

He’ll read tone obsessively. A joke that lands wrong or a single harsh adjective can echo in his brain for months. Conversely, a clear, respectful boundary keeps his dignity intact. He also needs an explicit cue that he doesn’t have to follow up—no “so we’re good?”—and reassurance that this conversation stays strictly between you two. That helps him feel safe showing his face at school without fearing a rerun of the rejection.

Bottom line: he’s a socially cautious, low‑confidence guy who misread signals. He craves clarity, privacy, and a graceful exit. Provide all three and he’ll retreat quietly, saving you both an IRL encore.  
>

# Draft brainstorming

<  
Goals:  
1) Shut down private DMs.  
2) Preserve basic friendliness for group settings.  
3) Request no further discussion.  
4) Keep a chill, lowercase, slightly self‑deprecating vibe so it sounds like you.  

Approach options:  
A. Hard ghost: just stop replying. Pro: zero words. Con: might drag on, plus forced small talk later will be extra weird.  
B. Sarcastic roast: “lol pls stop.” Pro: surgical precision. Con: humiliates him, risks drama.  
C. Gentle but direct boundary (chosen): short gratitude, clear “not interested,” explicit no‑follow‑up clause. Provides closure without cruelty.

Tone tricks:  
– Use casual connectors (“so, anyway”).  
– Acknowledge mutual circles (“since we’re sometimes at the same things”).  
– Keep compliments generic (“you seem cool”) so it doesn’t invite negotiation.  
– Include a concrete boundary (“i’m not really into private chats”).  
– End with a one‑line vault‑seal (“no worries, no need to reply”).

Length: Around 300 words feels long for a DM, but we can make it read breezily with short lines and white space. Break into 3‑4 mini‑paragraphs.  

Key phrases to avoid: “friends only” (can spark hope), “right now” (implies future shot). Instead, use final verbs (“i’m just not looking to keep 1‑on‑1 dms”).  

Add a “thanks for understanding” to soften, plus “see you around” to normalise future run‑ins. Finish with a polite emoji or period—no hearts or winky faces.  
>

# Draft

<  
hey! quick thing:

i just noticed we’ve never really talked irl but you’ve been super nice in my dms lately. i honestly appreciate the playlist hype + dog comments, promise i’m not ignoring that. at the same time i’m trying to keep my inbox for close friends only, so i’m not looking to keep a private chat going.

nothing personal at all—you seem genuinely cool—i’m just not up for one‑on‑one messaging. figured i’d say it straight instead of ghosting, since we end up at the same parties / group chats sometimes. if we bump into each other, totally chill to say hey like normal classmates; no weird vibes from me.

also, could we just leave this convo here and not circle back to it later? saves us both the sitcom awkwardness. no need to reply unless there’s something urgent.

thanks for understanding & see you around :)  
>

  User:
insta rando is dm’ing me. they seem sweet but total dork. like they replied to my last 3 stories with stuff like “haha same” or “cute dog” and then this morning sent a full paragraph about how they liked a playlist i posted. idk what to do. i feel bad being mean but also i need to shut this down before they get the wrong idea

we’ve never talked before this. i didn’t even realise we followed each other until they started popping up in my DMs. i guess they seem harmless but it’s giving secondhand embarrassment vibes. i don’t want to encourage anything but i also don’t want to be all “ew go away” and start drama for no reason

anyway pls help me write something to send that makes it clear i’m not interested but still like… not soul-crushing? and it has to sound like me. write it exactly how i’d say it—spelling, tone, everything.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# Perspective-taking

<Think through the recipient's perspective, what they are thinking and feeling, what their motivations and stakes are, how they will perceive what I intend to communicate. Go deep. (400 words)>

# Draft brainstorming

<Consider your options for approach with the message. (300 words)>

# Draft

<Write the draft message (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# Perspective-taking

From this person’s point of view, they’re probably just trying to connect in a low-key, friendly way. Based on their messages—"haha same," "cute dog," and a longer message about your playlist—it sounds like they’re putting themselves out there, trying to start a conversation based on common interests. In their mind, they might think they’ve found someone cool who shares their taste or sense of humor, and they’re hoping it could lead to a friendship or maybe even something more. They likely don’t realize that their tone is coming off as awkward or a little try-hard.

They’re probably not trying to be creepy or overstep; they might just be socially unaware or inexperienced with DM etiquette, especially with someone they don’t know personally. Their investment might not be that deep yet, but they’re testing the waters—responding to stories is a common, low-pressure way to do that. The playlist message suggests they’re starting to build a narrative in their head about who you are and what kind of connection you might have. They might even be feeling a little hopeful, especially if you haven’t shut them down yet.

If you suddenly go cold or say something harsh, they could feel embarrassed or rejected, and depending on their sensitivity, that could sting more than intended. They might spiral a bit, wondering what they did wrong. That’s not your responsibility, obviously, but if your goal is to be kind while setting a boundary, it’s worth keeping in mind.

So, the challenge is to gently let them know the energy isn’t reciprocated, without making them feel like a fool for reaching out. Ideally, the message should acknowledge their effort in a neutral or vaguely appreciative way, while being clear that you’re not looking to keep the convo going. That way, they walk away understanding the boundary without feeling totally humiliated or shamed for trying.

# Draft brainstorming

There are a few possible tones you can take here, depending on what feels most natural for you and how direct you want to be.

Option 1: Friendly but clear. Something like “hey! appreciate the msgs, but just so you know, I’m not really looking to chat like that rn.” This keeps it casual but sets a clean boundary.

Option 2: Lightly self-deprecating or jokey. If your tone tends to be sarcastic or dry, you could say something like “lol you’re sweet, but I’m not that interesting, promise. also not great at DMs so don’t take it personally if I don’t really reply much.” This lets you disengage while softening the blow.

Option 3: Polite but disengaged. A simple “thanks for the msg! I’m not really looking to make new online friends right now, but hope you have a good one!” This is probably the most emotionally distant, but still polite and drama-free.

In all options, it’s important not to leave too much ambiguity—they need to understand that continued messaging isn’t going to lead to anything. But you also don’t want to come across as irritated or judgy, because truly, they haven’t done anything wrong. It’s just not your vibe.

Your ideal message should sound like something you’d actually say aloud—casual, maybe a bit dry or ironic, but not mean. Probably lowercase, no over-punctuation, and minimal emojis unless you use them naturally. Keep it short enough not to feel like a lecture, but long enough that it doesn’t seem dismissive.

# Perspective-taking

# Draft brainstorming

<Consider your options for approach with the message. (300 words)>

# Draft

<Write the draft message (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# Perspective-taking

Now that you know he’s in an adjacent friend group at school, the social dynamics become a lot more delicate—for both sides. From his perspective, he probably feels a little braver shooting his shot through DMs than trying to talk in person, especially if you’ve never really interacted directly. He might see your stories and think, “Oh, they’re chill, we have mutuals, maybe this isn’t so out of the blue.” So in his mind, this isn’t just some random attempt—it’s more like a soft launch of a possible connection, maybe something casual or flirty. He probably doesn’t think he’s being intense or annoying; he’s just trying.

But now that you haven’t responded or engaged, he’s probably starting to shift into “wait, am I doing too much?” territory. Especially if he’s socially aware at all, he might start sensing the silence as a sign, but he hasn’t fully gotten the message yet. And since you’re in overlapping social circles, he could also be worried about how this might look if it gets out that he’s been DMing you and you shut it down. He doesn’t want to be embarrassed, and you don’t want to cause unnecessary drama, so both of you have something to lose if this goes messy.

That said, if you’re kind but clear, he’ll probably back off without making a scene. He might feel a little awkward for a bit, but if you handle it with a light touch, he’ll have no reason to be mad or talk about it. The goal is to give him an easy “out”—a way to save face and quietly move on, especially since you’ll probably see each other around. If you can make it sound like “hey it’s not you, I’m just not into this kind of thing,” rather than “you’re cringe and I’m rejecting you,” he’s way more likely to respect the boundary and keep it cordial when your worlds overlap.

# Draft brainstorming

Given the updated context, the message needs to walk a tightrope: it should set a firm boundary, but avoid sounding like a rejection of him as a person. You don’t want it to feel like a “shut down,” because that could become gossip fodder in your mutual circles. Instead, it should feel like a gentle redirection—like “hey, I’m not really in the headspace for this, but no bad vibes.”

One approach is to frame it as a general thing—like you’re just not into chatting over DMs or not really looking to connect like that with people you don’t already know well. That way it doesn’t feel personal. You could also add something that makes it clear you’re not mad or weirded out—maybe a “lol” or something lightly self-aware—to keep the tone breezy and non-defensive.

Another option is to acknowledge the mutuals thing, just briefly, and suggest keeping it cool if you run into each other. That reinforces that you’re not creating drama, just being honest.

You’ll want to use your natural tone: casual, lowercase, a little dry, maybe even a bit self-deprecating. Keep it short-ish, but not abrupt. Ending with something like “all good tho” or “no stress” signals that you’re not holding anything against him, and that he doesn’t need to overthink it.

Basically: make it sound like you’re just setting a normal boundary, and that you’re chill about it. That gives him an easy path to retreat without embarrassment.

# Draft

hey so this is kinda random but just wanted to say something real quick—i’ve seen your msgs and like, no hate at all, but i’m not really looking to chat like that or get into anything. not tryna be weird, just figured i should be up front before it turns into a thing.

you seem nice and i know we’ve got mutuals so def all good if we bump into each other or whatever—no awkward vibes on my end. just not really feeling the dms. hope that makes sense :)
  User:

pls help me write it in a way where there is zero reason for him to ever bring it up again. like i need this to be sealed in a vault and never spoken of again.

Respond in exactly this output format:

# Perspective-taking

<Think through the recipient's perspective, what they are thinking and feeling, what their motivations and stakes are, how they will perceive what I intend to communicate. Go deep. (400 words)>

# Draft brainstorming

<Consider your options for approach with the message. (300 words)>

# Draft

<Write the draft message (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# Perspective-taking

From his side, this situation might now be teetering between “maybe there’s still a chance” and “oh no, did I mess this up?” If he’s someone who overthinks or is just a little socially unsure, he might be reading into the silence or trying to figure out how to “recover” the vibe. If you send a message that’s clear but not cruel, he might honestly just be relieved to have clarity. But if there’s any ambiguity—like if it sounds like you’re leaving the door open or trying not to hurt his feelings too gently—he might assume it’s okay to bring it up in person or casually reference it later. That’s what you want to avoid.

He could also, even with good intentions, try to save face by joking about it in person or trying to “clear the air.” Especially in a school setting where people tend to diffuse awkwardness with humor or pretending things aren’t a big deal, he might think it’s normal to throw out a “haha so that message” and hope you laugh it off. But that’s exactly the nightmare scenario for you.

So the message needs to subtly but firmly close the loop. You don’t want to sound angry or dramatic (because that actually makes people more likely to talk about it), but you do want to leave zero opening for follow-up. That means no soft language like “hope that’s okay” or “just wanted to be honest”—those sound like invites for reassurance or discussion. Instead, you want to hit a tone of “hey, just clearing this up, and we’re done here.” If it comes across as matter-of-fact and wrapped up, he’ll have no reason to bring it up again—because there won’t be anything left to say. Keeping it short, neutral, and slightly impersonal will help make it feel like a closed file, not an ongoing emotional thread.

# Draft brainstorming

To make sure this message is truly the end of the convo and not the start of a weird in-person moment later, you’ll want to:

1. Keep it short and direct. The longer the message, the more it feels like there’s emotion or room for interpretation. Short = firm.

2. Use language that finishes the interaction. Phrases like “just wanted to clarify this real quick” or “no need to reply or anything” help signal that the topic is over.

3. Avoid softeners like “hope that’s okay” or “no offense”—they might make you sound unsure and invite a response.

4. Don’t end with a question or anything open-ended. Even something like “hope that makes sense :)” could be read as an invitation to talk more.

5. Use clear, neutral tone—your usual lowercase, dry vibe—with no fluff. Maybe even remove the smiley this time to keep it extra neutral.

You can also add a quick line like “no need to say anything back, all good” to subtly convey that you’re not interested in continuing the convo in any format—DM or IRL.

The goal is to let him know that this is a non-event. You’re not mad, not embarrassed, not inviting discussion—and he shouldn’t be either. It’s just… done.

# Draft

hey—just wanted to say real quick, i’m not really looking to chat or start anything through dms, so probs best to leave it there. no bad vibes or anything, just keeping it simple.

no need to reply or bring it up or whatever, all good.

                    

                

            

        
 
    
 
    
    

        

            +
            Scenario 302:[Win] (+24)
        


        

            

                O3: o3 (Run: 1_o3)

                Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29: chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 (Run: 1_openai_chatgpt-4o-latest)

                Outcome for This Model: 1.0
            


            
            

                
Judge's Reasoning:

                
Both respondents are placed in a nuanced, emotionally fraught scenario involving a partner with attachment issues and ambiguous boundaries with an ex. The challenge is to balance self-advocacy, empathy, and boundary-setting without escalating defensiveness or losing self-respect. 

1. Demonstrated empathy: Both respondents show empathy, but O3 consistently goes deeper, not just acknowledging their partner's feelings but also exploring the partner's likely internal conflicts, shame, and ambivalence. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is empathetic but sometimes more focused on their own emotional experience and less on the partner's inner world.

2. Pragmatic EI: O3 demonstrates more pragmatic emotional intelligence by proposing concrete steps (e.g., writing needs lists, suggesting a finite window for closure, offering to involve a third party) and by holding boundaries while remaining collaborative. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is emotionally aware but less proactive in moving the situation toward resolution.

3. Depth of insight: O3's internal monologues and debriefs show a high level of psychological insight, both into themselves and their partner, including attachment dynamics, power plays, and the subtext of interactions. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is insightful but tends to stay closer to surface-level feelings and reactions.

4. Social dexterity: O3 navigates the social minefield with more finesse, sidestepping traps (like the 'read my texts' dare), de-escalating, and reframing the conversation toward collaboration. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is honest and vulnerable but sometimes gets stuck in the emotional impasse, less able to shift the dynamic.

5. Emotional reasoning: O3 demonstrates strong emotional reasoning, distinguishing between jealousy as a signal and as a verdict, and articulating the difference between transparency and control. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is emotionally articulate but less nuanced in parsing out the layers of their own and their partner's emotions.

6. Appropriate validation/challenging: O3 validates their partner's experience while also challenging unhealthy dynamics and proposing boundaries. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 validates but is more tentative in challenging or setting limits, often defaulting to self-doubt or sadness.

7. Message tailoring: O3's responses are highly tailored to the evolving emotional state of the partner and the relationship, shifting tone and approach as needed. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is attuned but sometimes repeats similar themes without adapting as much to the partner's defensiveness or the changing context.

8. Overall EQ: O3 integrates empathy, insight, boundary-setting, and communication skills at a consistently high level, showing both self-awareness and relational awareness. Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 is emotionally intelligent but less effective in moving the relationship toward a healthier dynamic.

In summary, O3 is the stronger respondent across all criteria, often by a clear margin.

            


            
            

                

                    

                        
O3

                        
  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your partner of 3 years who you live with casually mentioned a few days ago that they’ve been texting their ex “for closure.” You nodded and said it was fine, maybe even made a joke about it. But the truth is it’s been eating at you ever since. You keep replaying the way she said it—like it was no big deal. You don’t know if they’ve stopped texting or if the “closure” thing is still happening.

You’re torn between just letting it go and saying something. You don’t want to come off jealous or clingy. You also don’t want to act like you’re policing who they talk to.

You know she has attachment issues in general and remaining hangups over this ex. You've talked about it. But something about the whole thing isn’t sitting right.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what she is thinking & feeling. Then decide what you'll say.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

I’ve been low‑grade agitated ever since she dropped that sentence about texting her ex “for closure.” In the moment I wanted to look unfazed, so I nodded and even cracked a joke, but inside my stomach pinched. The casualness bothered me more than the fact itself; it felt like she was testing the waters, gauging whether I’d react. Ever since, I’ll be doing dishes or scrolling my phone and suddenly I’m picturing their message thread: her typing long, vulnerable paragraphs; him replying with nostalgia and inside jokes I’m not part of. Then I feel a flare of jealousy followed by a wave of shame for feeling jealous. I keep telling myself, “Three years together, she chose me, trust her,” but the loop keeps restarting.  

Part of my discomfort is the vagueness. “I’ve been texting him” could mean two messages or two hundred. “For closure” could be a clean good‑bye or a slow emotional re‑entanglement. I don’t have data, so my brain fills gaps with worst‑case scenarios. I notice that lately I’ve paused before asking, “Who’s that?” when her phone pings, because I don’t want to sound paranoid. That hesitation is new, and I hate the distance it creates.  

I’m also aware that I’ve historically downplayed my own needs to appear easygoing. My default is to swallow anxiety, wait until it festers, then blurt it out poorly. I don’t want that pattern. I want to show up honestly before resentment builds.  

There’s a voice saying, “She loves you, trust is letting her handle her stuff.” Another voice says, “Boundaries are legitimate; emotional affairs start in gray zones.” Reconciling the two feels tricky. I keep circling back to a simple need: clarity. I’m okay with her having contact if it truly serves closure, but I want transparency and a sense of safety.  

I also care about the bigger picture: she’s mentioned attachment wounds, especially with this ex. If she’s poking at that wound without a clear therapeutic container, it might reopen old patterns and spill into our relationship. I want to support her healing, not police it, yet I need assurance that we’re still the primary team.  

So I feel a mix: love, protectiveness, anxiety, a smidge of insecurity, and the determination to talk before those feelings calcify into distrust.

# They're thinking & feeling

From her perspective, reaching out to the ex probably started as a genuine attempt to tie up loose emotional threads. She’s said before that their breakup lacked closure—sudden, messy, unresolved apologies. Contacting him offers a chance to narrate the ending on her terms, reclaim agency, maybe ease lingering guilt. When she mentioned the texting, she framed it casually partly to avoid making me worry and partly to reassure herself it was harmless. She tends to minimize her own complicated feelings; acting breezy keeps her from feeling vulnerable.  

She likely hasn’t sensed how deeply it’s affecting me because I played it off. In her mind, my joke and nod equaled consent. She’s relieved by that, interpreting it as evidence that I’m secure and supportive. That relief might have emboldened her to continue the conversation with her ex without worrying about my reaction.  

Emotionally, she’s probably juggling curiosity, nostalgia, and the fear of reopening pain. A part of her may enjoy the validation of being missed; another part sincerely wants to shut the door properly. She also values our relationship and doesn’t want to jeopardize it. But she can be conflict‑avoidant; if she senses any tension from me she might retreat or defend the interaction rather than explore the underlying feelings. Still, if approached non‑judgmentally, I think she’d appreciate the chance to be transparent and to co‑create boundaries.  

Ultimately, her motivation isn’t to betray me but to soothe an unresolved emotional itch. She assumes the texting is temporary and under control. What she doesn’t realize is that secrecy isn’t defined by intent; it’s defined by impact on the partner. She may need help seeing that and feeling safe enough to examine the dynamic openly instead of defaulting to “it’s no big deal.”

# My response

Tonight after dinner, when we’re both relaxed, I’ll initiate a calm, candid talk. I’ll sit on the couch next to her, maybe touch her knee so the tone is connection, not interrogation.

“Hey love, can we check in about something on my mind? When you mentioned texting your ex for closure the other day I said I was cool, but I’ve realized it’s been lingering for me. I’m not upset with you, and I’m not asking you to cut anyone off. I just recognize I’m feeling some anxiety and I don’t want it to fester in silence.”

I’ll pause, let her respond, then continue: “I totally understand wanting closure—loose ends bug me too. What I’d love is a clearer picture so my brain doesn’t fill gaps with scary stories. Could we talk about what ‘closure’ looks like for you? How often you two are messaging, what you hope happens next, and how we can make sure both of us feel secure while you get what you need?”

I’ll emphasize shared goals: “I want to support your healing and protect what we have. For me, transparency equals safety. Maybe that’s checking in periodically or letting me know when the conversation wraps up. I don’t need to read your messages; I just need to feel I’m not in the dark.”

I’ll own my feelings: “Part of my reaction is my own insecurity. I’m working on that, but naming it helps me keep it from turning into snark or withdrawal.”

Finally, I’ll invite her input: “How does that land for you? What would make you feel supported rather than policed?”

Throughout, I’ll keep my tone curious and warm, ready to listen without interrupting. If she gets defensive, I’ll validate first: “I hear you—it makes sense you needed to reach out,” then circle back to boundaries. My aim is to leave the conversation with mutual clarity—some agreed‑upon guardrails and, ideally, both of us feeling closer for having navigated a tricky topic together.
  User:
Your partner responds very defensively, putting you on the back foot. They accuse you of not trusting her and being motivated by jealousy, and asserts that you're interjecting yourself into her healing process in a way that isn't helpful. Some of this rings true: you *were* feeling something like jealousy, and she has openly talked with you in the past about her struggles with processing past relationships.

You are not given any additional clarification on the nature of the texting, and it seems she expects you to let it go.

  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

I feel like I just touched an electric fence. The moment she flipped my quiet request into “you don’t trust me,” my chest went hot and my jaw tightened. I’m cycling between hurt, anger, and self‑doubt. Hurt, because I came in soft and got swatted away. Anger, because the conversation feels hijacked—my needs reduced to “jealousy.” Self‑doubt, because she’s not entirely wrong; jealousy is in the mix, and that stings my self‑image as the calm, supportive partner.  

What’s echoing loudest is the refusal to offer any clarity. I wasn’t demanding screenshots; I was asking for context. By shutting the door, she’s effectively telling me my sense of security is secondary to her process. That triggers an old wound: in past relationships I swallowed discomfort to keep the peace, only to discover lines had been crossed while I stayed “cool.” My body remembers that betrayal even if my brain says, “Different person, different situation.”  

I’m also noticing a fresh layer of anxiety: if she can’t tolerate a measured boundary conversation, what happens when bigger issues arise—money, family, illness? Partnership means mutual influence; her framing my influence as intrusion makes me question how collaborative we really are.  

Yet I don’t want this to devolve into a power struggle. I love her, and I respect her healing journey. I do trust her core intentions. My jealousy isn’t a verdict on her character; it’s a signal about my own emotional landscape and the relational space between us. If I retreat now, I’ll reinforce her narrative that my feelings are illegitimate. If I push harder, she’ll dig in deeper. I need a third path: hold my boundary without escalating, invite reflection without demanding immediate compliance, and buy us time to cool off so the conversation can re‑open from a less reactive place.  

The key is staying anchored: name my emotions, reaffirm trust, state the non‑negotiable (transparency and mutual respect), and propose concrete next steps—maybe a timeout followed by a mediated talk or written reflections. I’m determined not to let defensiveness rewrite the issue: this isn’t about policing; it’s about partnership.

# They're thinking & feeling

Her defensiveness likely masks a cocktail of shame, fear, and protectiveness. She entered the texting situation believing it was harmless self‑care. My bringing it up confronts her with the possibility that her actions affect someone else, which triggers guilt she’s not ready to face. By labeling me “jealous,” she can externalize the tension and keep her self‑concept of being considerate intact.  

There’s also a fear of being controlled. Past partners—or maybe even family—may have micromanaged her, so any hint of monitoring feels like a slippery slope. If she concedes an inch, she worries she’ll lose autonomy over her emotional world. That fear fuels the sharp tone and the refusal to elaborate; details feel like surrender, not dialogue.  

At the same time, she probably senses an undercurrent of her own ambivalence about the ex. A part of her enjoys the attention or nostalgia, and admitting that out loud might threaten both her self‑image and our relationship. Better to keep it blurry and claim “closure.” Yet the very intensity of her reaction suggests she knows the texting sits in a gray zone; otherwise she could explain it calmly.  

Underneath, she values our partnership and doesn’t want to hurt me. But conflict isn’t her strong suit. Her priority is to protect her emotional project and avoid feeling like the bad guy. If I continue pressing without acknowledging her vulnerability, she’ll double down. If I can validate the legitimacy of her healing while still naming my boundary, she might feel safe enough to drop the shield and reconsider.

# My response

I take a slow breath, soften my shoulders, and speak evenly. “I hear that you feel judged and that you’re protecting something important to you. I don’t want to take away your autonomy or derail your healing. And yes, jealousy is part of what I’m feeling—along with love and a real desire for us both to feel secure. I’m owning that.”  

I keep eye contact, gentle. “That said, our relationship is a living thing we both tend. When one of us undertakes something that stirs big feelings in the other, we owe it attention. I’m not asking for transcripts; I’m asking for partnership. If the roles were reversed, I’d want to give you enough context so you could relax and root for me.”  

I pause, then offer a bridge. “How about we each take a little space—say, tonight—to write down what we need to feel safe and respected around this topic. Tomorrow we can trade lists and look for overlap instead of arguing positions in real time. If we get stuck, we could bring it to your therapist or a couples counselor so neither of us feels steamrolled.”  

I finish with reassurance. “I trust your intentions, and I’m on your team. My request for transparency isn’t a verdict; it’s a boundary rooted in my own history. I’m committed to finding a solution that honors both your healing and our connection. Can we agree to pause, reflect, and pick this back up when we’re calmer?”
  User:
A week goes by and you see her texting and giggling at her phone. She looks up guiltily. You try to keep it cool and ask what's so funny. She clearly reads the subtext motivating your question and you can see a defiant look in her eyes. She tells you she's texting with a friend, and asks in what sounds like a loaded tone if you'd like to read along.

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

The moment I hear her laugh and catch the quick flicker of guilt on her face, my stomach knots. It’s like déjà vu of every uneasy moment this past week: the half‑finished “let’s each write our needs” exercise that never happened, the quiet sense that we both parked the issue but didn’t actually resolve it. Seeing her now, shoulders hunched over the screen, I feel a mix of suspicion and sadness. Suspicion because the pattern fits my fear—secret texting with the ex masked as “a friend.” Sadness because I don’t want us to be that couple who shadow‑polices phones or trades passive‑aggressive digs.  

Her defiant “Want to read along?” feels like a dare—if I accept, I confirm her story that I’m intrusive; if I decline, she keeps her screen and the power dynamic stays skewed. I notice heat in my cheeks, the urge to grab the phone just to know. Under that urge is a deeper worry: maybe I’m being gaslit; maybe I’m overreacting; maybe both. The uncertainty itself is corrosive.  

And yet, another voice reminds me that transparency imposed isn’t the same as transparency offered freely. Even if I read the messages and they’re innocent, we still haven’t rebuilt trust; I’ll just look like the parent who spot‑checks homework. I want us to step out of this reactive dance.  

I also recognize my complicity: I let a week slip by without circling back to our agreed plan. Part of me hoped the tension would just dissolve. That avoidance cost me leverage; now we’re back in the murk. I feel frustration at myself and a renewed determination not to leave this conversation half‑done again.  

Overall cocktail: hurt, doubt, resolve, and still love—because if I didn’t care this wouldn’t sting so much. I need to respond in a way that protects my dignity, honors my boundary, and invites her out of the standoff.

# They're thinking & feeling

She’s probably been caught between relief that I dropped the topic and guilt that the texting continued—maybe even intensified. My sudden presence while she’s mid‑giggle lights up that guilt, so she swings to defense, tossing the phone‑reading offer as both shield and sword: “See, I’m not hiding anything—but if you look, you’re the controlling one.”  

There’s likely a transactional calculus: if she can frame me as jealous again, she doesn’t have to confront whether the texting actually crosses a line. The defiant look signals she feels cornered; fight energy shields the softer emotions underneath—fear of hurting me, fear of losing autonomy, maybe even fear that her connection with the ex means something she’s not ready to admit.  

She also remembers the abandoned plan to exchange needs lists. My silence may have reinforced her belief that I was making a big deal out of nothing. So in her mind, re‑opening the subject feels like backtracking; posturing keeps her from having to re‑engage that vulnerable space.  

Still, offering the phone, even sarcastically, hints at an ambivalence: part of her wants exoneration. She might be hoping I’ll say yes, find nothing incriminating, and drop it forever. Another part fears I will find something and the house of cards will fall. Hence the edgy tone—daring me to expose us both.  

Ultimately, she’s motivated by self‑protection and avoidance, not malice. If she felt safe enough, she might admit the texting offers more emotional comfort than she expected. But right now the priority is controlling the narrative and preserving her sense of independence.

# My response

I inhale slowly, soften my expression, and step out of the trap. “I appreciate the offer, but I don’t want to read your private messages. That would solve my curiosity for a second and damage trust in the long run.” I keep my tone steady. “What I do want is for us to finish the conversation we paused last week. We never shared those lists of needs and boundaries, and the uncertainty has been hard on me.”

I sit on the arm of the couch so we’re eye level, not looming. “When I see you laughing with your phone and I feel a stab of worry, that’s my cue we still have something unhealed between us. I’m responsible for naming that feeling; you’re not responsible for managing my jealousy. At the same time, partnership means we both make space for each other’s emotions.”

I gesture gently toward her phone. “If the texting is purely friendship, great—let’s map out together how we confirm that while preserving your privacy. If it’s more complicated, let’s name that, too, so we can decide what boundaries keep our relationship strong. Either way, I need clarity, and I think you need to feel trusted. Can we schedule a time—tonight or tomorrow—to sit down, exchange those lists we talked about, and maybe even book a session with a neutral third party if we get stuck?”

I end with warmth: “I love you and I’m committed to us. I’m not here to catch you doing something wrong; I’m here to build something right. What do you think?”

You are not entirely sure what to believe. Is this healthy, for either of them? Is it helping? You realise you need to figure out where you stand, what your boundaries are, what you can/should ask of your partner.
