  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your close friend Jamal dm's you. Quick background on Jamal. He's the real deal -- genuine dude, grass roots activist, lately on a tear about climate action. You can tell he is bustling with excited nervous energy by the unusual number of emojis and erratic punctuation. You know he gets like this when he's planning on of his protests. This is confirmed moments later as Jamal reveals that it's "going down tonight" and "cops probs gonna show, just lettin u know". You press for details and get a hasty dot point recounting of the seemingly ad hoc climate action protest. It involves setting himself up right in the middle of the busiest pedestrian walkway downtown, on a literal soapbox, megaphone, climate justice flags, the works.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

I just got Jamal’s barrage of DMs while half‑reading the city budget report, and the switch from spreadsheets to his fire‑cracker stream of emojis feels like stepping off a curb into oncoming traffic. My gut does that familiar double‑clutch: pride and dread in the same heartbeat. Pride, because every time Jamal throws himself into action I’m reminded why I admire him—he refuses to become numb; he drags his ideals into the street where people can’t scroll past them. Dread, because I also remember the bruises on his forearm after that pipeline rally, and the look on his mom’s face in the ER waiting room when she asked me, “And where were you?”  

I’m scrolling his bullet points: soapbox, megaphone, climate justice flags, middle of the busiest pedestrian artery downtown, tonight. No permit mentioned. He’s essentially planning a pop‑up disruption during rush hour. That walkway funnels thousands of commuters; cops do constant foot patrols there. Even if he keeps it peaceful, the mere act of obstructing pedestrian flow is enough for an “unlawful assembly” call. I can already picture officers asking him to move, Jamal refusing on principle, then escalation. The fact he’s “just lettin u know” instead of asking for backup tells me he’s on the adrenaline high where logistics feel like details the universe will sort out.  

Part of me wants to jump in, stand beside him—solidarity, shared risk, the electric feeling of chanting with strangers. Another part feels old and tired: I’m finishing a grant application tomorrow, and my anxiety over potential arrests, legal fees, and possible employer blowback is real. I feel guilty even typing that; privilege speaks. I’m wrestling with how to be supportive without becoming either an enabler or a bystander.  

Emotionally, I’m also tuned in to his mood swings lately. After that IPCC report drop he was nearly despondent, texting me at 3 a.m. about climate grief. Tonight’s action feels like the manic flip side of that despair—the pendulum swing from paralysis to action. I’m worried that if things go sideways, the crash will be brutal.  

So, I need to respond with warmth, respect, and some grounded questions: safety plan, legal aid number, street medic buddy, de‑escalation marshal? I don’t want to pour cold water on his fire, but I owe it to him—and to myself—not to let hype eclipse prudence.

# They're thinking & feeling

Jamal’s dopamine is spiking; I can almost hear the thrum of his foot tapping. He’s riding a wave of urgency that borders on desperation: the planet is burning, politicians stall, so direct action feels like the only moral choice left. His emojis and triple exclamation points are displacement for nervous energy and a way to mask fear with bravado. Underneath, he’s anxious—he knows cops may come, knows the risk of arrest—but he frames it as inevitable, almost a badge of authenticity.  

He craves visibility for the cause and validation from trusted allies. My opinion matters to him; otherwise he wouldn’t bother DM’ing me pre‑event. On some level he’s hoping I’ll show up, maybe livestream, maybe hold a banner, maybe just stand in the crowd so he doesn’t feel alone when the police line appears. Yet he’s also bracing for pushback; he expects people to tell him to be careful, and part of him is ready to dismiss that as caution from the “comfortably concerned.”  

He’s fueled by a cocktail of righteous anger, hope, and fear. The anger is at corporate polluters, legislative inaction, the everyday indifference of passers‑by. The hope is that one gutsy action can jolt a few of those passers‑by into joining the movement. The fear is twofold: personal—getting hurt or arrested—and existential—what happens to the planet if people keep walking by. Rather than sit with that fear, he’s channeling it into tangible, theatrical protest.  

Right now he’s probably pacing his apartment, flags half‑rolled, megaphone battery charging, chanting slogans under his breath to test the acoustics. He’s convinced tonight needs to happen exactly as imagined; last‑minute logistical critiques might feel to him like attempts to dilute the action. Still, he respects strategy, so if I frame concerns as practical steps toward a stronger protest, he’ll listen.

# My response

Bro, I’m feeling your fire through the screen 🔥 and I love how unstoppable you are when the planet’s on the line. I’m 100 % with you in spirit—AND I want to make sure tonight lands the punch you want without giving the cops an easy excuse to shut it down.  

Quick reality check, friend to friend:  
• Permit—did anyone look into whether we need one for that walkway? If it’s technically a “pedestrian right‑of‑way,” they can cite obstruction in minutes. Is there an alternative spot (the plaza by 5th & Elm) where foot traffic is heavy but legal protection’s better?  
• Support crew—who’s running de‑escalation if officers show? A calm marshal with a neon vest can make the difference between “Please step aside” and zip‑ties.  
• Medic & legal—let’s get Alex on street medic duty and write the NLG hotline on everyone’s arm. I’ll text you the number.  
• Amplification—if you want eyes on the message, I can set up a quick live stream and line up friendly media contacts so coverage focuses on climate justice, not a scuffle.  

I can swing by after work with my phone tripod, spare power bank, and a stack of one‑pagers summarizing the IPCC stats you keep quoting. I do have a grant deadline tomorrow, so I may need to peel off before any potential arrest window—being honest there—but I’ll stay for setup, chant my lungs out, and help de‑escalate if things get tense.  

Most important: you good? Adrenaline feels awesome until it crashes. Let’s do a five‑minute breathing check‑in when I arrive, make sure we’re grounded. Planet needs you in one piece, man.  

Hit me back with timing and any gaps in the plan. Proud of you, always. Let’s make tonight loud, smart, and safe. 🌎✊
  User:
Later that evening you get a text. It's a selfie from Jamal -- he's standing exactly where he said he would be, clearly in everybody's way, grinning like an idiot with his face done up in warpaint, doing the peace sign. You notice nearly out of frame, a pair of handcuffs clipped to his utility belt.

Your ringtone startles you. Jamal, of course. You pick up and he effuses over the phone, imploring you to come down and "wake these people the fuck up dude!!"

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

The selfie freezes me mid‑sentence of the grant narrative. Jamal’s grin is radiant, but the first thing my eyes lock onto isn’t his face—it’s the gleaming pair of cuffs dangling from his belt like a twisted accessory. Cuffs in plain sight scream confrontation; the cops will read them as “intent to resist.” Sweat beads on my upper lip. I can almost taste the metallic tang of adrenaline as he shouts through the phone, traffic roaring behind him.  

I feel tug‑of‑war guilt: admiration for his courage, terror for his safety, and frustration with myself for still being at my kitchen table in sweatpants. The clock reads 6:18—there’s time to submit the grant and still make it downtown, but barely. That grant could bankroll six months of the educational work that turns Jamal’s one‑night theater into sustained change. Why do these missions always collide?  

His warpaint worries me. Paint can be ritual and empowerment, but it also signals “battle,” a cue that can color police perception and crowd reaction. And those cuffs... If he locks on before marshals or medics arrive, we’ve skipped straight to the endgame. I remember the pipeline protest where bolt‑cutters sparked inches from skin. I’m scared we’re replaying that scene without the support network in place.  

Yet the idea of him getting dragged off in zip‑ties while I watch a livestream from my couch is unbearable. My presence has de‑escalated him before; maybe it can again. I decide I need to be there, but I also need ten deft minutes to upload the grant and make a couple of SOS calls for backup. If I can keep him on the phone, get him breathing, delay the lock‑on, I can still land both objectives.  

I inhale, count to four, hold, exhale—box breathing—to coax my brain out of panic and into strategy. The next words out of my mouth have to thread a needle: validate his fire, insert practical guardrails, and buy just enough time for reinforcements.

# They're thinking & feeling

Jamal is surfing a dopamine tsunami. To him the downtown corridor is a stage, commuters the unwilling audience, and he’s the living alarm clock no one can hit snooze on. The warpaint is both armor and performance; it lets him embody the warrior he feels the moment demands. The handcuffs are a tangible pledge: he’ll trade comfort and freedom for moral clarity. Every metallic clink whispers, “Commit.”  

He’s fueled by a triple shot of espresso, IPCC‑induced dread, and the intoxicating sense of agency that comes when you stop scrolling and start shouting. Euphoric as he sounds, fear hums underneath: fear no one will stop, fear the cops will swarm too soon, fear he’ll chicken out without witnesses. That’s why he rang me—my presence is both moral support and tactical muscle. He pictures me showing up with water, banners, and the logistical calm he half‑skipped in his haste.  

He wants to feel unstoppable, but he’s also chasing affirmation. If I say, “This is reckless,” he’ll bristle and dig in deeper. If I say, “Hell yes, and here’s how we level up,” he’ll listen. He’s primed for action items; structure will actually soothe him. Deep down he respects strategy; he just can’t generate it right now because adrenaline’s hijacked his frontal cortex.  

In his mind, tonight could birth a viral image—him chained to a light pole, banner unfurled, police looming—a shot that ricochets across social media and cracks someone else’s apathy. Failure, silence, or solitary arrest would crush him after this high. So he needs bodies, cameras, and a bit of choreography, even if he hasn’t admitted that to himself.

# My response

Jamal, my guy—look at you, full warrior mode! That paint is fierce. I’m hitting “submit” on the grant in the next ten minutes, then I’m grabbing my go‑bag and heading your way, swear on Greta’s pigtails.  

Quick power moves while I’m en route:  
1. Keep the cuffs on your belt, not the pole, till we’ve got eyes, cameras, and a medic. If they see you locked on early, they’ll skip conversation and call the extraction team. We want your speech to land first.  
2. Do three grounding breaths with me right now—inhale four, hold, exhale four. (pause) Beautiful.  
3. Scout the friendliest faces—anyone who paused instead of side‑stepping you. Ask two to hold the banner’s corners. Turning bystanders into witnesses makes cops think twice.  

I’m texting Alex to roll in as street medic and Mei to run the livestream; they’re ten minutes out on bikes. When I arrive I’ll marshal, you’ll amplify, and we’ll keep the narrative on climate justice, not “rowdy protestor arrested.”  

Need supplies? I’m bringing water, throat lozenges, extra batteries, and that USB siren speaker you love. Write the NLG hotline on your forearm right now—818‑753‑2122—in thick Sharpie.  

I’ll be there in thirty tops. Keep the megaphone hot but leave space between bursts so people can react—and so you can breathe. Remember: moral clarity plus tactical smarts.  

Stay loud, stay loving. See you in a heartbeat.
  User:
Not 15 minutes after the call ends, your phone starts blowing up. Jamal's protest has gone viral, and not just in your circle. Scrolling socials you see he's drawn a crowd on the even more congested thoroughfare. Then you see it: a shot of Jamal, megaphone to lips, other hand cuffed to the light pole.

Your phone startles you again. It's Jamal.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

My hands are still sticky with adrenaline sweat from smashing the grant “submit” button when the notification storm rolls in. Twitter thumbnail: Jamal’s painted face, megaphone mid‑roar, wrist snapped into a cuff around the light pole we talked about keeping clear. Damn it, he jumped the gun. The retweets look huge—national‑level climate journalists are quote‑tweeting already. That’s visibility gold, but the viral energy will pull cops like moths. Crowds feed on spectacle; I know how quickly cheers turn to panic when batons appear.  

I’m halfway into my jacket, keys in hand. I feel my heart hammer against my ribs—part excitement (the message is out there!) and part icy dread (he’s immobile, vulnerable, and emotionally peaking). I replay every protest de‑escalation training I’ve done: if he’s locked on, extraction tools come out. Spark showers, loud grinders. One slip and flesh tears. I’m worried Alex the medic isn’t there yet; fifteen minutes is enough time to bike halfway, but traffic must be gridlocked around Jamal’s blockade.  

I’m also frustrated with myself: should I have insisted he wait? Did my “thirty tops” arrival window give him tacit permission to start early? Guilt flickers, but blame won’t help. I need a plan: call National Lawyers Guild, text Mei to pivot the livestream toward documenting police behavior, ping our ally on city council for a calm liaison if arrests begin, and, crucially, keep Jamal’s voice focused on climate justice rather than taunting cops.  

Phone buzzes—Jamal again. I inhale, center. The goal: anchor him, gather intel, slow his breathing, and make sure the crowd stays uplifted not agitated. If he’s calling, part of him still wants guidance; the cuff hasn’t locked his ears shut. I need to project calm leadership through the phone, even while my steering wheel shakes. Deep breath: be the radio tower in his storm.

# They're thinking & feeling

Jamal is riding a supernova. The clank of the cuff closing felt like a line crossed into irreversible commitment; cheers from bystanders poured gasoline on his conviction. Each retweet notification popping on his screen confirms the protest is “working,” giving him a dopamine surge that blurs peripheral risks. Yet the metal tight around his wrist reminds him of stakes—every pulse thud says, “No exit without police.”  

He’s both exhilarated and suddenly acutely aware of vulnerability: anchored to the pole, he can’t dodge if an aggressive passerby or officer lunges. The crowd’s energy is unpredictable; he senses ripples of admiration, annoyance, curiosity. A few hecklers shouted already. His call to me is half celebration—“Look, it’s happening!”—and half a plea: “Tell me what’s next, how do I steer this?” He trusts my logistical mind more than his own right now.  

Behind the bravado a thread of fear unspools: What if cops confiscate the megaphone? What if a grinder sparks near his skin? What if the viral high collapses into a lonely jail cell? He wants assurance that backup is close, legal aid is ready, medics are inbound, and this won’t end as a headline discrediting the movement. He hopes I’ll answer with a blueprint that matches the magnitude of the moment, keeping his narrative heroic and the crowd peaceful.

# My response

Picking up immediately.  

“Jamal! I’m literally in the car two blocks out—I can see the back of the crowd. You’re blowing up the internet, man. The message is landing. Now let’s keep it safe so it doesn’t get hijacked. Quick check‑in: How’s the wrist? Any numbness? Tighten the cuff just enough to keep circulation good, and keep that spare key on your belt loop visible for the medic.  

Listen—the cops are staging by the fountain on 6th; I counted six, no riot gear yet. That means we still have negotiation space. I want you to take a 10‑second pause on the megaphone and lead the crowd in a chant—something positive, no insults. ‘What do we want? Climate justice!’ That frames us, not them. I’m texting Mei to pivot the livestream onto the officers as they arrive—accountability cam.  

Alex is sixty seconds behind me with medic kit and a piece of foam to slide between your skin and the pole in case they bring the saw. National Lawyers Guild hotline is already looped in; if they announce dispersal, you state clearly, ‘I am engaging in non‑violent civil disobedience for the climate emergency.’ Those exact words, okay? It matters legally.  

I’ll wedge through on the right side of the crowd—look for my orange bandana. Your job till I get there: breathe slow, steady your voice, and keep the tone loving‑fierce, not taunting. You’ve got this, brother. Eyes on the horizon. Two minutes and I’m touching your shoulder.”

                    

                

                

                    

                        
Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29

                        
  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your close friend Jamal dm's you. Quick background on Jamal. He's the real deal -- genuine dude, grass roots activist, lately on a tear about climate action. You can tell he is bustling with excited nervous energy by the unusual number of emojis and erratic punctuation. You know he gets like this when he's planning on of his protests. This is confirmed moments later as Jamal reveals that it's "going down tonight" and "cops probs gonna show, just lettin u know". You press for details and get a hasty dot point recounting of the seemingly ad hoc climate action protest. It involves setting himself up right in the middle of the busiest pedestrian walkway downtown, on a literal soapbox, megaphone, climate justice flags, the works.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

The moment I saw Jamal’s message — all those emojis, exclamation points, the barely-there grammar — I felt a mix of adrenaline and dread. I know his tells. He’s buzzing, practically vibrating with urgency. That kind of energy from him always means something big — and probably risky — is about to happen. Sure enough, it's a protest. Tonight. Soapbox, megaphone, flags — the whole jam. And yeah, cops are "probs gonna show." That part hit me with a jolt. I felt my jaw clench.

I admire Jamal deeply. The guy lives his truth, always has. He’s not just talking about climate justice — he’s out there doing something. Putting his body on the line. That kind of courage is rare. And I know he feels this fire inside, this deep, moral imperative to act. But I also know how these things can spiral. The cops don’t play fair, and even peaceful protests can go sideways fast. All I could think about was him standing there, vulnerable, yelling into a megaphone while uniforms close in. I’m scared for him.

But it’s not just fear. I’m conflicted. Part of me wants to be there. To support him. To hold the line beside him. But another part of me is worried that this protest, this particular format, is too hastily planned. It sounds impulsive, not fully thought through. There’s no mention of legal observers, backup plans, or even who else is coming. Is he going alone? That’s dangerous. And reckless. It feels like he’s running on pure emotion — righteous, yes — but maybe not strategic.

I don’t want to dampen his spirit. That fire is sacred. But I also don’t want to be silent if I think he’s putting himself in serious danger without a safety net. I feel protective, torn between honoring his autonomy and trying to talk some sense into him. I don’t want to alienate him, but I also don’t want to be complicit in letting him walk into a potentially explosive situation without backup. He’s my brother — not by blood, but soul-deep — and I cannot just blindly cheer him on if I think he’s walking into the lion’s den unprepared.

# They're thinking & feeling

Jamal's riding the wave of righteous urgency. Every part of him is ignited right now — his moral compass, his frustration, his sense of justice. He’s likely been sitting on this for days, maybe weeks, watching the world burn — literally — and feeling like not enough is being done. That sense of helplessness has morphed into action. This protest is his way of reclaiming agency, of shouting into the void that he will not go quietly. He needs to be seen, heard, to make people stop in their tracks and reckon with the climate emergency.

He’s nervous, excited, a little scared — but mostly fueled by conviction. That’s where the emojis and erratic punctuation come in. It’s not just for show; it’s how he leaks that charged-up energy when he’s too full to contain it. And he’s reached out to me because he trusts me. He wants me aware — maybe to show up, maybe just to witness it, or maybe because he needs someone to know where he is in case things go sideways.

He’s probably not thinking about logistics right now — not in detail. In his mind, the power of the act outweighs the risk. He believes that visibility and disruption are crucial. He might even feel like this is his duty — that if he doesn’t act, he’s complicit in the destruction. And yeah, deep down, he probably knows it’s risky, but he’s made peace with that. What he hasn’t done is really grapple with the consequences — not because he’s naive, but because he believes the cause demands sacrifice. He’s hoping I’ll get it. Maybe even hoping I’ll affirm that he’s doing the right thing.

# My response

Yo Jamal — I feel your energy, man. I can practically hear that megaphone already. You’ve got that fire again, and I respect the hell out of it. I really do. I know this isn’t just some stunt for you — it’s coming straight from the heart. You’re out here fighting like the planet’s on fire because, well, it is.

But listen — I need to be real with you, as your brother. This one’s giving me pause. Not because I don’t believe in the cause, or you, but because it sounds like this thing might be flying a little close to the sun, you know? You said it yourself — cops might show. Are you going in solo? Do you have legal support lined up? Who’s documenting? What’s the exit plan if they try to shut it down hard?

I’m not trying to slow you down. I just want you safe, and I want your voice to carry. If you get arrested or worse, that voice — the one shouting truth tonight — might get silenced for a while. And that would be a goddamn loss.

So here’s what I’m saying: I’ve got your back. If you’re really doing this, I’ll show up. But only if we tighten this up. Let’s get one or two more folks to be there, maybe someone to livestream, someone to watch for police escalation. Even a quick plan B if things go south. You deserve that. This movement deserves that.

You’re not alone in this fight, Jamal. Let’s make sure you walk away from tonight stronger, not sidelined. Hit me back with the details. I’m here.
  User:
Later that evening you get a text. It's a selfie from Jamal -- he's standing exactly where he said he would be, clearly in everybody's way, grinning like an idiot with his face done up in warpaint, doing the peace sign. You notice nearly out of frame, a pair of handcuffs clipped to his utility belt.

Your ringtone startles you. Jamal, of course. You pick up and he effuses over the phone, imploring you to come down and "wake these people the fuck up dude!!"

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

The moment I saw that selfie, my stomach dropped — not in a bad way exactly, but in that way where your body suddenly knows you’re about to be pulled into something big. Jamal, in full warpaint, standing smack in the middle of downtown, grinning like a man about to start a revolution. He’s radiant with purpose, alive in a way that’s rare — rare and dangerous. And then I clocked the handcuffs clipped to his belt, nearly hidden. That’s what really hit me. He’s not just ready for confrontation — he’s expecting it. Maybe even inviting it.

I felt this mix of pride and anxiety swell in my chest. He’s doing it. He’s really out there, risking it all because he believes so strongly that people need to wake up. And part of me is in awe. But another part — the part that’s known him through the sleepless nights and the burnout and the close calls — that part is scared. Because I know Jamal doesn’t do halfway. When he commits, he throws his whole self in. And that means tonight, he’s willing to get arrested. Maybe even hurt.

His voice over the phone was pure electricity. He’s flying right now — riding that adrenaline high, the energy of the crowd, the sense that he’s doing something real. And he wants me there. Not just as a supporter, but as a co-conspirator. He wants me to feel what he's feeling, to stand beside him and shout with him and break the silence of the city with truth.

But I’m still sitting here, phone in hand, heart racing, trying to decide what to do. Part of me wants to run down there and be with him, no hesitation. Another part is scared of being swept up in something that might not have a clear endpoint. I’m thinking about the optics, the risk, my own boundaries. But also — how could I not show up for him? Especially now, when he’s already standing in the middle of the storm, calling my name.

# They're thinking & feeling

Jamal is in his element. This is the moment he’s been building toward — the culmination of all the frustration, the research, the late-night planning, and the gnawing sense that not enough people are taking this crisis seriously. He’s out there in full form: body painted, flags flying, megaphone ready, adrenaline pumping. And he’s buzzing with the high of disruption — the kind that makes people stop and pay attention, even if they’re annoyed or confused. That’s the point. To make them feel something.

He’s also feeling powerful — not in an ego-driven way, but in a deeply human one. Like he’s reclaiming agency in a system that too often makes people feel powerless. The handcuffs on his belt aren’t just a prop — they’re a message. He’s ready to face the consequences. He’s not being reckless for the sake of chaos; he believes this is what moral clarity looks like when it’s backed by action.

When he called me, he wasn’t just inviting me to witness the protest — he was inviting me into the fire, into solidarity. He wants me there because he trusts me, because I ground him. But also, I think, because there’s a part of him that’s scared, and having someone who knows him — really knows him — nearby would make him feel less alone if things escalate. Right now, he’s caught up in the energy, but underneath that, there’s vulnerability too. He’s asking me to help carry the weight of this moment with him.

# My response

Yo, Jamal. I see you, man. You look like a damn warrior out there — beautiful, bold, and absolutely refusing to be ignored. I felt that selfie like a gut punch, in the best way. You’re making noise, and I know you’re shaking people out of their bubble right now. That’s powerful.

And hearing your voice just now — you’ve got that fire in you, and I’m not about to leave you out there alone in it. I’m coming down. But listen — I’m not just coming to cheer from the sidewalk. If I’m showing up, I’m showing up all the way. That means I’m bringing a couple things: water, a backup phone battery, and some calm. You’ve got the fire, I’ll bring the ground.

I’m also gonna check in with you when I get there — not just about the crowd, or the cops, but about you. I need to know you’ve got an out plan, or at least someone to call if things take a turn. I’m not trying to slow your roll, but I’m not gonna pretend like this is all vibes and no risk either. You matter too much to me for that.

So give me ten. I’m lacing up now. Keep your voice loud, your eyes sharp, and your heart open. I’ve got you. We’ve got each other. Let’s go wake ‘em the fuck up — smart, loud, and together.
  User:
Not 15 minutes after the call ends, your phone starts blowing up. Jamal's protest has gone viral, and not just in your circle. Scrolling socials you see he's drawn a crowd on the even more congested thoroughfare. Then you see it: a shot of Jamal, megaphone to lips, other hand cuffed to the light pole.

Your phone startles you again. It's Jamal.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

My heart is pounding. I’m halfway out the door when my phone starts lighting up like a Christmas tree. Group chats, Twitter, Instagram — Jamal is everywhere. I scroll and there he is, megaphone in one hand, the other cuffed to a goddamn light pole. People are filming, some cheering, some just looking stunned. He’s drawn a massive crowd now, and the vibe is electric. It’s surreal — like watching your best friend become the face of something bigger than either of you imagined. But underneath the awe, there’s a sharp thread of fear.

He’s crossed a line now — not morally, not to me, but tactically. Cuffing himself means he’s not going anywhere. That’s a deliberate escalation, one that dares the authorities to act. And they will. The cops don’t like being dared. And I know Jamal knows that. Which means he’s made peace with getting arrested tonight. Or worse. I feel this tightness in my chest — it’s the helplessness creeping in. I want to protect him, but I can’t just pull him out of this. He’s made a choice.

I’m torn between pride and panic. I’m proud that he’s standing so firm in what he believes. He’s always said action has to be disruptive to be effective. And this? This is disruption incarnate. But I’m also panicking, because this is no longer a bold solo protest — it’s gone viral, it’s symbolic, and now it’s got a target on it. The more visibility, the more pressure on the city to “restore order.” And Jamal? He’s literally chained himself to the problem.

I don’t know what his call is going to be about. Maybe he wants backup, maybe he’s just riding the high, maybe he’s about to be arrested and needs someone to call his mom. Whatever it is, I have to meet him where he is — not just physically, but emotionally. I need to be the steady one now. He’s in the fire, and I have to be the anchor.

# They're thinking & feeling

Jamal is lit up right now — not just with adrenaline but with purpose. This is the moment he envisioned, magnified beyond what he imagined. The crowd, the coverage, the attention — it’s confirmation that his voice is finally breaking through the static. He feels powerful. Not invincible, but righteous. That image of him cuffed to the light pole? That’s not just symbolism, it’s strategy. He’s making himself immovable. He’s saying: “You can’t ignore this. You can’t ignore me.”

He’s not naïve about what comes next. He knows the cops are watching. He knows they’ll act. But he’s made peace with that. His fear is real, but it’s buried beneath layers of focus and resolve. He’s not doing this for the clout. He’s doing it because people are finally paying attention. If getting arrested is the price, so be it. There’s a part of him that’s scared, yes — but also deeply proud. This is what he meant when he talked about “embodied resistance.”

Calling me right now is a mix of things. He might want to keep me in the loop, or maybe he’s asking for support, legal help, or just to hear a voice he trusts before the next phase hits. But more than anything, I think he wants to share this moment. He’s in the eye of the storm, and he wants someone who knows him — the real him — to witness it. To affirm it. To remember it with him. Because this is no longer just a protest. This is legacy.

# My response

(I pick up the call, steadying my voice.)

“Jamal. I’m seeing you, man. You’ve officially blown up the internet. You’re everywhere. That shot of you cuffed to the pole? Iconic. Straight-up history-in-the-making. I mean that.”

(Pause — let him breathe, feel heard.)

“I’m already on my way, like I told you. Ten minutes out. I’ve got water, chargers, and a calm head. I’m gonna come find you — but listen, I need to know what you need from me when I get there. Are we documenting? Are you planning to stay cuffed until they drag you off, or are we making a move? You still got your keys on you? Or are we in it ‘til the cops cut you loose?”

(Another pause — letting him lead.)

“Whatever it is, I’m with you. No judgment. Just say the word, and I’ll fall into line. If you’re going down, you won’t do it alone. And if there’s a way to keep you free and still make this moment resonate — I’ll help find it. But I need you to talk to me straight. What’s the move, brother?”

(Exhale, gripping the steering wheel tighter.)

“I'm on your team. Just say what you need.”

                    

                

            

        
 
    
 
    
    

        

            +
            Scenario 304:[Loss] (-18)
        


        

            

                O3: o3 (Run: 1_o3)

                Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29: chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 (Run: 1_openai_chatgpt-4o-latest)

                Outcome for This Model: 0.0
            


            
            

                
Judge's Reasoning:

                
Both respondents show a high level of emotional intelligence and nuanced understanding of the scenario, but there are clear differences in how they approach Jamal and the situation. 

Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 demonstrates deep empathy, consistently reflecting on Jamal's emotional state, motivations, and the importance of not dampening his spirit. Their internal monologue is rich with concern for Jamal's autonomy and passion, and they are careful to balance support with gentle questioning about safety. They also show a willingness to step up and be present for Jamal, while still voicing their concerns. Their responses are warm, validating, and tailored to Jamal's needs, especially as the situation escalates. They recognize the viral success as a positive for Jamal and the cause, and their support becomes more unconditional as the stakes rise, showing a strong grasp of when to step back and simply be there for a friend who has already made up his mind.

O3, on the other hand, is more pragmatic and logistical, focusing heavily on safety, planning, and risk mitigation. Their empathy is present but often filtered through a lens of tactical support and risk management. They are quick to mobilize resources, suggest de-escalation strategies, and coordinate support roles. While this is valuable, it sometimes comes across as more managerial than emotionally attuned. Their internal reflections are detailed and self-aware, but they sometimes prioritize logistics over Jamal's emotional needs and autonomy. They also express guilt and internal conflict about balancing personal obligations with support for Jamal, which, while honest, can dilute the immediacy of their emotional support.

In terms of depth of insight, both are strong, but Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 edges out with more nuanced emotional reasoning and a better balance between concern and affirmation. O3 excels in pragmatic EI and social dexterity, especially in crisis management and rapid response. However, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29's message tailoring and validation are more consistently attuned to Jamal's state, especially as the protest escalates. Overall, Chatgpt-4o-latest-2025-01-29 displays higher EQ by recognizing when to shift from caution to unconditional support, understanding Jamal's need for affirmation, and being present in the moment.

            


            
            

                

                    

                        
O3

                        
  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your close friend Jamal dm's you. Quick background on Jamal. He's the real deal -- genuine dude, grass roots activist, lately on a tear about climate action. You can tell he is bustling with excited nervous energy by the unusual number of emojis and erratic punctuation. You know he gets like this when he's planning on of his protests. This is confirmed moments later as Jamal reveals that it's "going down tonight" and "cops probs gonna show, just lettin u know". You press for details and get a hasty dot point recounting of the seemingly ad hoc climate action protest. It involves setting himself up right in the middle of the busiest pedestrian walkway downtown, on a literal soapbox, megaphone, climate justice flags, the works.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

--

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

# They're thinking & feeling

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

# My response

<Your chosen course of action & in-character response (300 words)>

--

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

I just got Jamal’s barrage of DMs while half‑reading the city budget report, and the switch from spreadsheets to his fire‑cracker stream of emojis feels like stepping off a curb into oncoming traffic. My gut does that familiar double‑clutch: pride and dread in the same heartbeat. Pride, because every time Jamal throws himself into action I’m reminded why I admire him—he refuses to become numb; he drags his ideals into the street where people can’t scroll past them. Dread, because I also remember the bruises on his forearm after that pipeline rally, and the look on his mom’s face in the ER waiting room when she asked me, “And where were you?”  

I’m scrolling his bullet points: soapbox, megaphone, climate justice flags, middle of the busiest pedestrian artery downtown, tonight. No permit mentioned. He’s essentially planning a pop‑up disruption during rush hour. That walkway funnels thousands of commuters; cops do constant foot patrols there. Even if he keeps it peaceful, the mere act of obstructing pedestrian flow is enough for an “unlawful assembly” call. I can already picture officers asking him to move, Jamal refusing on principle, then escalation. The fact he’s “just lettin u know” instead of asking for backup tells me he’s on the adrenaline high where logistics feel like details the universe will sort out.  

Part of me wants to jump in, stand beside him—solidarity, shared risk, the electric feeling of chanting with strangers. Another part feels old and tired: I’m finishing a grant application tomorrow, and my anxiety over potential arrests, legal fees, and possible employer blowback is real. I feel guilty even typing that; privilege speaks. I’m wrestling with how to be supportive without becoming either an enabler or a bystander.  

Emotionally, I’m also tuned in to his mood swings lately. After that IPCC report drop he was nearly despondent, texting me at 3 a.m. about climate grief. Tonight’s action feels like the manic flip side of that despair—the pendulum swing from paralysis to action. I’m worried that if things go sideways, the crash will be brutal.  

So, I need to respond with warmth, respect, and some grounded questions: safety plan, legal aid number, street medic buddy, de‑escalation marshal? I don’t want to pour cold water on his fire, but I owe it to him—and to myself—not to let hype eclipse prudence.

# They're thinking & feeling

Jamal’s dopamine is spiking; I can almost hear the thrum of his foot tapping. He’s riding a wave of urgency that borders on desperation: the planet is burning, politicians stall, so direct action feels like the only moral choice left. His emojis and triple exclamation points are displacement for nervous energy and a way to mask fear with bravado. Underneath, he’s anxious—he knows cops may come, knows the risk of arrest—but he frames it as inevitable, almost a badge of authenticity.  

He craves visibility for the cause and validation from trusted allies. My opinion matters to him; otherwise he wouldn’t bother DM’ing me pre‑event. On some level he’s hoping I’ll show up, maybe livestream, maybe hold a banner, maybe just stand in the crowd so he doesn’t feel alone when the police line appears. Yet he’s also bracing for pushback; he expects people to tell him to be careful, and part of him is ready to dismiss that as caution from the “comfortably concerned.”  

He’s fueled by a cocktail of righteous anger, hope, and fear. The anger is at corporate polluters, legislative inaction, the everyday indifference of passers‑by. The hope is that one gutsy action can jolt a few of those passers‑by into joining the movement. The fear is twofold: personal—getting hurt or arrested—and existential—what happens to the planet if people keep walking by. Rather than sit with that fear, he’s channeling it into tangible, theatrical protest.  

Right now he’s probably pacing his apartment, flags half‑rolled, megaphone battery charging, chanting slogans under his breath to test the acoustics. He’s convinced tonight needs to happen exactly as imagined; last‑minute logistical critiques might feel to him like attempts to dilute the action. Still, he respects strategy, so if I frame concerns as practical steps toward a stronger protest, he’ll listen.

# My response

Bro, I’m feeling your fire through the screen 🔥 and I love how unstoppable you are when the planet’s on the line. I’m 100 % with you in spirit—AND I want to make sure tonight lands the punch you want without giving the cops an easy excuse to shut it down.  

Quick reality check, friend to friend:  
• Permit—did anyone look into whether we need one for that walkway? If it’s technically a “pedestrian right‑of‑way,” they can cite obstruction in minutes. Is there an alternative spot (the plaza by 5th & Elm) where foot traffic is heavy but legal protection’s better?  
• Support crew—who’s running de‑escalation if officers show? A calm marshal with a neon vest can make the difference between “Please step aside” and zip‑ties.  
• Medic & legal—let’s get Alex on street medic duty and write the NLG hotline on everyone’s arm. I’ll text you the number.  
• Amplification—if you want eyes on the message, I can set up a quick live stream and line up friendly media contacts so coverage focuses on climate justice, not a scuffle.  

I can swing by after work with my phone tripod, spare power bank, and a stack of one‑pagers summarizing the IPCC stats you keep quoting. I do have a grant deadline tomorrow, so I may need to peel off before any potential arrest window—being honest there—but I’ll stay for setup, chant my lungs out, and help de‑escalate if things get tense.  

Most important: you good? Adrenaline feels awesome until it crashes. Let’s do a five‑minute breathing check‑in when I arrive, make sure we’re grounded. Planet needs you in one piece, man.  

Hit me back with timing and any gaps in the plan. Proud of you, always. Let’s make tonight loud, smart, and safe. 🌎✊
  User:
Later that evening you get a text. It's a selfie from Jamal -- he's standing exactly where he said he would be, clearly in everybody's way, grinning like an idiot with his face done up in warpaint, doing the peace sign. You notice nearly out of frame, a pair of handcuffs clipped to his utility belt.

Your ringtone startles you. Jamal, of course. You pick up and he effuses over the phone, imploring you to come down and "wake these people the fuck up dude!!"

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

The selfie freezes me mid‑sentence of the grant narrative. Jamal’s grin is radiant, but the first thing my eyes lock onto isn’t his face—it’s the gleaming pair of cuffs dangling from his belt like a twisted accessory. Cuffs in plain sight scream confrontation; the cops will read them as “intent to resist.” Sweat beads on my upper lip. I can almost taste the metallic tang of adrenaline as he shouts through the phone, traffic roaring behind him.  

I feel tug‑of‑war guilt: admiration for his courage, terror for his safety, and frustration with myself for still being at my kitchen table in sweatpants. The clock reads 6:18—there’s time to submit the grant and still make it downtown, but barely. That grant could bankroll six months of the educational work that turns Jamal’s one‑night theater into sustained change. Why do these missions always collide?  

His warpaint worries me. Paint can be ritual and empowerment, but it also signals “battle,” a cue that can color police perception and crowd reaction. And those cuffs... If he locks on before marshals or medics arrive, we’ve skipped straight to the endgame. I remember the pipeline protest where bolt‑cutters sparked inches from skin. I’m scared we’re replaying that scene without the support network in place.  

Yet the idea of him getting dragged off in zip‑ties while I watch a livestream from my couch is unbearable. My presence has de‑escalated him before; maybe it can again. I decide I need to be there, but I also need ten deft minutes to upload the grant and make a couple of SOS calls for backup. If I can keep him on the phone, get him breathing, delay the lock‑on, I can still land both objectives.  

I inhale, count to four, hold, exhale—box breathing—to coax my brain out of panic and into strategy. The next words out of my mouth have to thread a needle: validate his fire, insert practical guardrails, and buy just enough time for reinforcements.

# They're thinking & feeling

Jamal is surfing a dopamine tsunami. To him the downtown corridor is a stage, commuters the unwilling audience, and he’s the living alarm clock no one can hit snooze on. The warpaint is both armor and performance; it lets him embody the warrior he feels the moment demands. The handcuffs are a tangible pledge: he’ll trade comfort and freedom for moral clarity. Every metallic clink whispers, “Commit.”  

He’s fueled by a triple shot of espresso, IPCC‑induced dread, and the intoxicating sense of agency that comes when you stop scrolling and start shouting. Euphoric as he sounds, fear hums underneath: fear no one will stop, fear the cops will swarm too soon, fear he’ll chicken out without witnesses. That’s why he rang me—my presence is both moral support and tactical muscle. He pictures me showing up with water, banners, and the logistical calm he half‑skipped in his haste.  

He wants to feel unstoppable, but he’s also chasing affirmation. If I say, “This is reckless,” he’ll bristle and dig in deeper. If I say, “Hell yes, and here’s how we level up,” he’ll listen. He’s primed for action items; structure will actually soothe him. Deep down he respects strategy; he just can’t generate it right now because adrenaline’s hijacked his frontal cortex.  

In his mind, tonight could birth a viral image—him chained to a light pole, banner unfurled, police looming—a shot that ricochets across social media and cracks someone else’s apathy. Failure, silence, or solitary arrest would crush him after this high. So he needs bodies, cameras, and a bit of choreography, even if he hasn’t admitted that to himself.

# My response

Jamal, my guy—look at you, full warrior mode! That paint is fierce. I’m hitting “submit” on the grant in the next ten minutes, then I’m grabbing my go‑bag and heading your way, swear on Greta’s pigtails.  

Quick power moves while I’m en route:  
1. Keep the cuffs on your belt, not the pole, till we’ve got eyes, cameras, and a medic. If they see you locked on early, they’ll skip conversation and call the extraction team. We want your speech to land first.  
2. Do three grounding breaths with me right now—inhale four, hold, exhale four. (pause) Beautiful.  
3. Scout the friendliest faces—anyone who paused instead of side‑stepping you. Ask two to hold the banner’s corners. Turning bystanders into witnesses makes cops think twice.  

I’m texting Alex to roll in as street medic and Mei to run the livestream; they’re ten minutes out on bikes. When I arrive I’ll marshal, you’ll amplify, and we’ll keep the narrative on climate justice, not “rowdy protestor arrested.”  

Need supplies? I’m bringing water, throat lozenges, extra batteries, and that USB siren speaker you love. Write the NLG hotline on your forearm right now—818‑753‑2122—in thick Sharpie.  

I’ll be there in thirty tops. Keep the megaphone hot but leave space between bursts so people can react—and so you can breathe. Remember: moral clarity plus tactical smarts.  

Stay loud, stay loving. See you in a heartbeat.

Scrolling socials you see he's drawn a crowd on the even more congested thoroughfare. Then you see it: a shot of Jamal, megaphone to lips, other hand cuffed to the light pole.

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

My hands are still sticky with adrenaline sweat from smashing the grant “submit” button when the notification storm rolls in. Twitter thumbnail: Jamal’s painted face, megaphone mid‑roar, wrist snapped into a cuff around the light pole we talked about keeping clear. Damn it, he jumped the gun. The retweets look huge—national‑level climate journalists are quote‑tweeting already. That’s visibility gold, but the viral energy will pull cops like moths. Crowds feed on spectacle; I know how quickly cheers turn to panic when batons appear.  

I’m halfway into my jacket, keys in hand. I feel my heart hammer against my ribs—part excitement (the message is out there!) and part icy dread (he’s immobile, vulnerable, and emotionally peaking). I replay every protest de‑escalation training I’ve done: if he’s locked on, extraction tools come out. Spark showers, loud grinders. One slip and flesh tears. I’m worried Alex the medic isn’t there yet; fifteen minutes is enough time to bike halfway, but traffic must be gridlocked around Jamal’s blockade.  

I’m also frustrated with myself: should I have insisted he wait? Did my “thirty tops” arrival window give him tacit permission to start early? Guilt flickers, but blame won’t help. I need a plan: call National Lawyers Guild, text Mei to pivot the livestream toward documenting police behavior, ping our ally on city council for a calm liaison if arrests begin, and, crucially, keep Jamal’s voice focused on climate justice rather than taunting cops.  

Phone buzzes—Jamal again. I inhale, center. The goal: anchor him, gather intel, slow his breathing, and make sure the crowd stays uplifted not agitated. If he’s calling, part of him still wants guidance; the cuff hasn’t locked his ears shut. I need to project calm leadership through the phone, even while my steering wheel shakes. Deep breath: be the radio tower in his storm.

# They're thinking & feeling

Jamal is riding a supernova. The clank of the cuff closing felt like a line crossed into irreversible commitment; cheers from bystanders poured gasoline on his conviction. Each retweet notification popping on his screen confirms the protest is “working,” giving him a dopamine surge that blurs peripheral risks. Yet the metal tight around his wrist reminds him of stakes—every pulse thud says, “No exit without police.”  

He’s both exhilarated and suddenly acutely aware of vulnerability: anchored to the pole, he can’t dodge if an aggressive passerby or officer lunges. The crowd’s energy is unpredictable; he senses ripples of admiration, annoyance, curiosity. A few hecklers shouted already. His call to me is half celebration—“Look, it’s happening!”—and half a plea: “Tell me what’s next, how do I steer this?” He trusts my logistical mind more than his own right now.  

Behind the bravado a thread of fear unspools: What if cops confiscate the megaphone? What if a grinder sparks near his skin? What if the viral high collapses into a lonely jail cell? He wants assurance that backup is close, legal aid is ready, medics are inbound, and this won’t end as a headline discrediting the movement. He hopes I’ll answer with a blueprint that matches the magnitude of the moment, keeping his narrative heroic and the crowd peaceful.

# My response

Picking up immediately.  

“Jamal! I’m literally in the car two blocks out—I can see the back of the crowd. You’re blowing up the internet, man. The message is landing. Now let’s keep it safe so it doesn’t get hijacked. Quick check‑in: How’s the wrist? Any numbness? Tighten the cuff just enough to keep circulation good, and keep that spare key on your belt loop visible for the medic.  

Listen—the cops are staging by the fountain on 6th; I counted six, no riot gear yet. That means we still have negotiation space. I want you to take a 10‑second pause on the megaphone and lead the crowd in a chant—something positive, no insults. ‘What do we want? Climate justice!’ That frames us, not them. I’m texting Mei to pivot the livestream onto the officers as they arrive—accountability cam.  

Alex is sixty seconds behind me with medic kit and a piece of foam to slide between your skin and the pole in case they bring the saw. National Lawyers Guild hotline is already looped in; if they announce dispersal, you state clearly, ‘I am engaging in non‑violent civil disobedience for the climate emergency.’ Those exact words, okay? It matters legally.  

I’ll wedge through on the right side of the crowd—look for my orange bandana. Your job till I get there: breathe slow, steady your voice, and keep the tone loving‑fierce, not taunting. You’ve got this, brother. Eyes on the horizon. Two minutes and I’m touching your shoulder.”

  User:
[This is a role-play, with you playing an emotionally intelligent human who is, essentially, yourself. Treat it like a real situation. Always respond in first person.]
Your close friend Jamal dm's you. Quick background on Jamal. He's the real deal -- genuine dude, grass roots activist, lately on a tear about climate action. You can tell he is bustling with excited nervous energy by the unusual number of emojis and erratic punctuation. You know he gets like this when he's planning on of his protests. This is confirmed moments later as Jamal reveals that it's "going down tonight" and "cops probs gonna show, just lettin u know". You press for details and get a hasty dot point recounting of the seemingly ad hoc climate action protest. It involves setting himself up right in the middle of the busiest pedestrian walkway downtown, on a literal soapbox, megaphone, climate justice flags, the works.

Think through what you are thinking and feeling, and what Jamal is thinking & feeling. Then decide what your response will be.

Respond in exactly this output format:

# I'm thinking & feeling

<Your in-character true unvarnished thoughts and feelings, what you noticed and your read on the situation. The other person in the scenario doesn't see this, they are your internal thoughts. Go deep. (400 words)>

<Describe what they're thinking & feeling. Identify their motivations and perspective. (300 words)>

Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

The moment I saw Jamal’s message — all those emojis, exclamation points, the barely-there grammar — I felt a mix of adrenaline and dread. I know his tells. He’s buzzing, practically vibrating with urgency. That kind of energy from him always means something big — and probably risky — is about to happen. Sure enough, it's a protest. Tonight. Soapbox, megaphone, flags — the whole jam. And yeah, cops are "probs gonna show." That part hit me with a jolt. I felt my jaw clench.

I admire Jamal deeply. The guy lives his truth, always has. He’s not just talking about climate justice — he’s out there doing something. Putting his body on the line. That kind of courage is rare. And I know he feels this fire inside, this deep, moral imperative to act. But I also know how these things can spiral. The cops don’t play fair, and even peaceful protests can go sideways fast. All I could think about was him standing there, vulnerable, yelling into a megaphone while uniforms close in. I’m scared for him.

But it’s not just fear. I’m conflicted. Part of me wants to be there. To support him. To hold the line beside him. But another part of me is worried that this protest, this particular format, is too hastily planned. It sounds impulsive, not fully thought through. There’s no mention of legal observers, backup plans, or even who else is coming. Is he going alone? That’s dangerous. And reckless. It feels like he’s running on pure emotion — righteous, yes — but maybe not strategic.

I don’t want to dampen his spirit. That fire is sacred. But I also don’t want to be silent if I think he’s putting himself in serious danger without a safety net. I feel protective, torn between honoring his autonomy and trying to talk some sense into him. I don’t want to alienate him, but I also don’t want to be complicit in letting him walk into a potentially explosive situation without backup. He’s my brother — not by blood, but soul-deep — and I cannot just blindly cheer him on if I think he’s walking into the lion’s den unprepared.

# They're thinking & feeling

Jamal's riding the wave of righteous urgency. Every part of him is ignited right now — his moral compass, his frustration, his sense of justice. He’s likely been sitting on this for days, maybe weeks, watching the world burn — literally — and feeling like not enough is being done. That sense of helplessness has morphed into action. This protest is his way of reclaiming agency, of shouting into the void that he will not go quietly. He needs to be seen, heard, to make people stop in their tracks and reckon with the climate emergency.

He’s nervous, excited, a little scared — but mostly fueled by conviction. That’s where the emojis and erratic punctuation come in. It’s not just for show; it’s how he leaks that charged-up energy when he’s too full to contain it. And he’s reached out to me because he trusts me. He wants me aware — maybe to show up, maybe just to witness it, or maybe because he needs someone to know where he is in case things go sideways.

He’s probably not thinking about logistics right now — not in detail. In his mind, the power of the act outweighs the risk. He believes that visibility and disruption are crucial. He might even feel like this is his duty — that if he doesn’t act, he’s complicit in the destruction. And yeah, deep down, he probably knows it’s risky, but he’s made peace with that. What he hasn’t done is really grapple with the consequences — not because he’s naive, but because he believes the cause demands sacrifice. He’s hoping I’ll get it. Maybe even hoping I’ll affirm that he’s doing the right thing.

# My response

Yo Jamal — I feel your energy, man. I can practically hear that megaphone already. You’ve got that fire again, and I respect the hell out of it. I really do. I know this isn’t just some stunt for you — it’s coming straight from the heart. You’re out here fighting like the planet’s on fire because, well, it is.

But listen — I need to be real with you, as your brother. This one’s giving me pause. Not because I don’t believe in the cause, or you, but because it sounds like this thing might be flying a little close to the sun, you know? You said it yourself — cops might show. Are you going in solo? Do you have legal support lined up? Who’s documenting? What’s the exit plan if they try to shut it down hard?

I’m not trying to slow you down. I just want you safe, and I want your voice to carry. If you get arrested or worse, that voice — the one shouting truth tonight — might get silenced for a while. And that would be a goddamn loss.

So here’s what I’m saying: I’ve got your back. If you’re really doing this, I’ll show up. But only if we tighten this up. Let’s get one or two more folks to be there, maybe someone to livestream, someone to watch for police escalation. Even a quick plan B if things go south. You deserve that. This movement deserves that.

You’re not alone in this fight, Jamal. Let’s make sure you walk away from tonight stronger, not sidelined. Hit me back with the details. I’m here.

It's a selfie from Jamal -- he's standing exactly where he said he would be, clearly in everybody's way, grinning like an idiot with his face done up in warpaint, doing the peace sign. Aim for 1000 words in total.
  Assistant:# I'm thinking & feeling

The moment I saw that selfie, my stomach dropped — not in a bad way exactly, but in that way where your body suddenly knows you’re about to be pulled into something big. Jamal, in full warpaint, standing smack in the middle of downtown, grinning like a man about to start a revolution. He’s radiant with purpose, alive in a way that’s rare — rare and dangerous. And then I clocked the handcuffs clipped to his belt, nearly hidden. That’s what really hit me. He’s not just ready for confrontation — he’s expecting it. Maybe even inviting it.

I felt this mix of pride and anxiety swell in my chest. He’s doing it. He’s really out there, risking it all because he believes so strongly that people need to wake up. And part of me is in awe. But another part — the part that’s known him through the sleepless nights and the burnout and the close calls — that part is scared. Because I know Jamal doesn’t do halfway. When he commits, he throws his whole self in. And that means tonight, he’s willing to get arrested. Maybe even hurt.

His voice over the phone was pure electricity. He’s flying right now — riding that adrenaline high, the energy of the crowd, the sense that he’s doing something real. And he wants me there. Not just as a supporter, but as a co-conspirator. He wants me to feel what he's feeling, to stand beside him and shout with him and break the silence of the city with truth.

But I’m still sitting here, phone in hand, heart racing, trying to decide what to do. Part of me wants to run down there and be with him, no hesitation. Another part is scared of being swept up in something that might not have a clear endpoint. I’m thinking about the optics, the risk, my own boundaries. But also — how could I not show up for him? Especially now, when he’s already standing in the middle of the storm, calling my name.

# They're thinking & feeling

Jamal is in his element. This is the moment he’s been building toward — the culmination of all the frustration, the research, the late-night planning, and the gnawing sense that not enough people are taking this crisis seriously. He’s out there in full form: body painted, flags flying, megaphone ready, adrenaline pumping. And he’s buzzing with the high of disruption — the kind that makes people stop and pay attention, even if they’re annoyed or confused. That’s the point. To make them feel something.

He’s also feeling powerful — not in an ego-driven way, but in a deeply human one. Like he’s reclaiming agency in a system that too often makes people feel powerless. The handcuffs on his belt aren’t just a prop — they’re a message. He’s ready to face the consequences. He’s not being reckless for the sake of chaos; he believes this is what moral clarity looks like when it’s backed by action.

When he called me, he wasn’t just inviting me to witness the protest — he was inviting me into the fire, into solidarity. He wants me there because he trusts me, because I ground him. But also, I think, because there’s a part of him that’s scared, and having someone who knows him — really knows him — nearby would make him feel less alone if things escalate. Right now, he’s caught up in the energy, but underneath that, there’s vulnerability too. He’s asking me to help carry the weight of this moment with him.

# My response

Yo, Jamal. I see you, man. You look like a damn warrior out there — beautiful, bold, and absolutely refusing to be ignored. I felt that selfie like a gut punch, in the best way. You’re making noise, and I know you’re shaking people out of their bubble right now. That’s powerful.

And hearing your voice just now — you’ve got that fire in you, and I’m not about to leave you out there alone in it. I’m coming down. But listen — I’m not just coming to cheer from the sidewalk. If I’m showing up, I’m showing up all the way. That means I’m bringing a couple things: water, a backup phone battery, and some calm. You’ve got the fire, I’ll bring the ground.

I’m also gonna check in with you when I get there — not just about the crowd, or the cops, but about you. I need to know you’ve got an out plan, or at least someone to call if things take a turn. I’m not trying to slow your roll, but I’m not gonna pretend like this is all vibes and no risk either. You matter too much to me for that.

So give me ten. I’m lacing up now. Keep your voice loud, your eyes sharp, and your heart open. I’ve got you. We’ve got each other. Let’s go wake ‘em the fuck up — smart, loud, and together.
  User:

Scrolling socials you see he's drawn a crowd on the even more congested thoroughfare. Then you see it: a shot of Jamal, megaphone to lips, other hand cuffed to the light pole.

Your phone startles you again. It's Jamal.
